This request was not heeded instead the member of staff insisted on draining the jug of its almost cold remains. We did mention our disappointment at reception. Arriving earlier on other mornings we found cold meat and hot water but still tepid cooked hot food.On the day of our departure at 5.30am my husband went ahead of me to book out. When I arrived with luggage I found that we needed our travel documents to prove that our breakfasts had been pre-paid.For us except for the staff who help us with our luggage we did not find the staff as helpful or attentive as we had during the rest of our stay in Japan. They did not reflect Japanese hospitality as we had experienced elsewhere.

In many respects this is a conventional city hotel. Typical rooms and facilities etc. We booked a “Tower View” room and yes we could see the old Tokyo Tower and south across the city. When we checked in, on a rainy day, the staff mentioned that on a clear day you could see Mt Fuji from the reception area. In fact it turned out the tower view rooms also have a Mt Fuji view if the sky is clear (which doesn’t happen that often, but luckily for us it cleared on our last morning). It has a mostly convenient location that’s close to the Ginza area and stations. So what’s quirky? The location is decidedly unusual and a bit hard to get your head around. For a start it’s on the top of an office block with reception on the 25th floor. The best access is underground through a network of passages that lead to the stations, shops and restaurants. It’s an “art” hotel which doubles as a kind of art gallery. Despite the name there are no nearby parks. It has a glass outside lift. It’s right the middle of a modern commercial area so there’s no “old Japan” atmosphere in the vicinity. All that being said, it’s comfortable and roomy with attentive staff.

Room 3028 - Standard City View room. Found Hotel amenities good, establishment frequented by Westerners, average breakfast, little confusing on the choice and extent of service, not a lot on offer for lunch or dinner. Japan is expensive so from a Australian perspective there was not a lot on offer of alternatives. It was either Japanese or French Japanese available. Staff were friendly but did not speak a lot of good English. Not a good variety on TV as most was Japanese. Our room was a little dirty with marks on walls which did not look very nice, with the added bonus of bad sewer smells being omitted from the pipes in the bathroom that’s why had deodoriser spray in the room. Overhaul good base camp for exploration of Tokyo and beyond.

We spent 6 nights here and were sorry to leave.The hotel actually starts on the 25th floor of the building so when you enter from the ground floor you need to make your way up to the 25 th floor to check in.The staff were most helpful and polite.The hotel is situated close to Shimbashi train station and Shiodome subway stations.It is a 20 minite stroll to the Ginza district and a similar distance to the fish markets.We found the hotel food to be expensive but there are plenty of restaurants closeby who serve great meals at bargain prices.The carpet in our room and corridors was starting to show some wear but our room was spotlessly clean with comfortable twin beds.Room size was good ( 21m2 ) by Japanese standards.

It was an absolute treat to spend three nights in one of the artist rooms, of which there are 53, all on the 31st floor. I was fortunate to be allocated The Castle (you find out which room you've been assigned after checking in) as it was super cool, featuring fabulous artwork by Kazuki Mizuguchi. This included beautiful, meticulous and elegant castle renditions spanning three walls, with associated imagery covering the ceiling and other wall space. To make it even more special, the castle was reflected in the windows at night, superimposed on the Tokyo's night landscape. In his statement the artist linked this with thoughts of reality, illusion, transience and impermanence. It looked amazing. Everything else at the hotel was good as well. The 31st floor had an art concierge in situ every day to assist artist-room guests and each morning there were complimentary pastries and hot drinks for those guests. There were three art exhibitions (31st, 32nd and 35th floors) with work for sale and also a large video installation stretching upwards from the reception lobby into the central space which could be viewed from all floors. On the reception level there were some excellent ceramics and other items for sale. Staff were courteous and attentive. I'd booked a queen-sized room and it was spacious with a comfortable bed, choice of pillows, window seat, easy chair, footrest, table and desk. The red curtains and other decor complimented the art. Adjustable lights (I liked that they could be very bright, not always the case in Japan) and air conditioning. Lots of storage and hanging space, safe, fridge (with mini bar), decent-sized tv (with the first thing that comes on being evacuation info - admirable), full-sized mirror, cups & glasses. Adjoining powerpoints spaced so both could hold transformers at the same time (yay). Yakata and in-house slippers. Bathroom was a good size too with ample bench space for cosmetics etc, and complimentary toiletries were provided. Apart from the joy of the castle, there were great views of Tokyo in several directions and I enjoyed watching the trains coming and going. The hotel's location is excellent, next to Shiodome Station and with Shimbashi Station across the way, so easy access to most Tokyo destinations. There's a wide range of shops and eateries in the vincinity. Taxi rank outside and staff arranged for me to travel to the airport via reasonably-priced limousine (shuttle) which only stopped at about four places. I definitely hope to return.

We always try to book hotels because of location and in this respect Park Hotel was excellent. Right at Shimbashi Station which is on the direct train line from both airports and hence easy to access all parts of Tokyo . Also next to metro line. It is in the middle of office blocks We arrived in Golden week( 10 days of public holidays celebrating change of Emperors ) so the area was really quiet as no one was at work so it felt a bit weird. On the plus side the area didn’t have the massive crowds that were everywhere else The hotel was a bit tricky to find as GPS didn’t work underground. We actually went to the wrong hotel at first - The Park Royal which is just across the road On the negative there was not much around the hotel which was open at night.The hotel was fine and staff helpful and friendly. Our room was an OK size by Japanese standards ( we have stayed in tiny tiny rooms) Shower was above bath. Dinner in the lobby restaurant was truly awful - worst pizza I have ever had ) plus expensive. We ate breakfast at one of the bakeries at the station We would stay again as we finally got the hang of transport system

We stayed here for 5 nights in April, on our first trip to Japan. We loved the Park Hotel – we had a fabulous view over the city from our room, and the view from the Reception area overlooking Mount Fuji was terrific. Our room was spacious and the breakfast was really good, we especially enjoyed the Japanese breakfast options. We didn’t eat at the hotel, but had cocktails in the evening at the bar, which were really good, unusual cocktail options, which we really enjoyed. The cocktails were quite expensive – but it’s Tokyo, it is expensive!The location of the hotel was great, near to Shimbashi station, so easy to get out and about in the city. It’s also not far from Tsukiji fish market (highly recommended for a morning out and sushi lunch) and if you’re staying here and are looking for a nearby beer, I’d recommend the craft beer bar in Shimbashi station, or the Dry Dock bar nearby.We hope to return to Tokyo, and would definitely consider staying at the Park Hotel again.

My wife and I had mistakenly booked a budget hotel. We were looking for a hotel in the heart of Tokyo with beautiful views of the city. The Park Hotel did not disappoint. Everyone on the staff was wonderful. The reception desk was fast and very friendly, as was the bellboy who not only stored our luggage, but had it brought to our room. Very happy I stayed here.

We stayed in room 2909 with fantastic view of the Tokyo Tower. We arrived around 2pm and were let in early. The view from our window was amazing. Room was clean with a very large bed. Within the bathroom was a shower, bath & heated loo. My favourite over the stay. The fridge was fully stocked but we did not use it. There was a lovely window seat to view the tower and Tokyo - my favourite place in the evening and watching the sun in the morning - on our first morning we viewed Mount Fuji for around 3o mins before it got cloud cover, never seen again until our last night.Breakfast was included in our room deal and it was amazing, lots of choice, from Japanese, English, American lots of choices and waited on for tea/coffee.The Park Hotel must pipe in something to make you relax as I never felt more relaxed on a holiday than anywhere else. It is also an art gallery where you can view local artist work in and around the hotel.The hotel is a short walk to Shiodome Station and that will take you all over Tokyo. We very rarely went into Shimbasi (as this was very big and confusing)If you want a lovely place to stay with approachable english speaking staff then please go here - you won't be dissapointed.

Customer service at the Reception of this hotel was fantastic and I love the art concept, but they can not hide the fact that this hotel has seen far better days. We checked into our room and it was so dirty, I had to complain, which I never do! There was hair that wasn’t mine in the bed, a filthy toilet, gritty carpets, and an unidentifiable stain on the window seat cushion. The hotel rooms and hallways sorely need to be gutted and refurbished. The lady at reception was most apologetic about the room and said she would look into it. She ended up upgrading us to a much nicer room, but I still don’t feel that it was cleaned properly each day. Housekeeping was sporadic, at best, and inexplicably, the large information booklet (with room service menu etc) went missing from the desk of our room on the second last day! Why?!All in all, the price paid does not reflect the standard I would expect.

My family and I stayed here for 3 nights. Service was very good as in almost all hotels in Japan. Our rooms were not ready when we arrived (early) but we got all the paperwork done and they kept our bags for us. Lobby is on 25th floor and the rooms are on higher floors so a good chance to see Mount Fuji, if the day is clear. Breakfast is very good (except for coffee). On the rooms, I highly recommend to upgrade to the bigger size as the standard room of 574sf is super tightOn the rooms, the air is a bit stale (light) as it appears not to have any fresh ventilation.Best thing about this hotel is the location next to a major subway station, Shimbashi.

Stayed for 3 nights upon arrival in Japan. Hotel reception is on the 25th floor with bedrooms on the 9 floors above; ours was on the 33rd. Fantastic views of the city skyline with Mount Fuji visible in the distance. Staff were welcoming and very helpful. Breakfast was excellent with a mix of traditional Japanese and conventional western fare. Hotel has 2 restaurants, but we chose to eat out as there are plenty of local restaurants. We went (twice) to the Ootoya in the nearby Shiodome building and we weren't disappointed. Location is convenient for several JR and Metro stations.

Perhaps I just had an unfortunate experience here, but this was the dirtiest hotel I’ve stayed in to date. My room looked nice, but on closer inspection there was stains on the bed linen, and black hairs in and on my bed, and in the bath... I also found something else in the bath tub, so disgusting it’s unprintable.The upsides are that the staff, location and hotel itself were fine, but the standard of cleanliness, was gobsmackingly bad.

Second night of a four night stay here. Fantastic hotel with very comfortable bedroom ( toiletries supplied in bathroom and tea/coffee making facilities in bedroom) and staff that are utmost courteous and go out of their way to assist you.

I stayed here in May 2017 for 10 days and it was a fantastic hotel. Could not fault it at all! 10/10. The hotel was really close to Shinbashi train station and all the main railway lines. An incredible experience! I hope to visit this amazing hotel again in the near future.

Panoramic view of the city from the rooms which start at the 26th floor. Customer service was impeccable. Enjoyed a lovely massage to help recover from the long flight there. Excellent breakfast buffet with lots of variety. Western option were greatly appreciated.

This is the 4th time I have stayed at the Park Hotel Tokyo. Best value hotel in the best location. The Hotel is almost on top of the Shimbashi Train Station and is a 5 minute walk to Ginza. It's also a 5 minute walk to Hamarikyu Gardens and the Fish market. The view from the Tokyo Tower side are amazing. Nothing like watching the sunset or day break over tokyo from your room. The breakfast was great (not sure of the cost) and there were plenty of choices. The rooms are small by western standards but most japanese hotels only have rooms.

Really impressed by this hotel. We stayed in one of the Artist's Rooms for a few nights as part of our honeymoon. Not only did were have a spectacular view across Tokyo but the room itself was stunning. Small but beautifully decorated. Breakfast was great and I loved that you could use your breakfast voucher later in the day if e.g. you had jet lag or wanted a lie-in.They also gave us complimentary champagne to celebrate our honeymoon which was a) delicious and b) very kind. I also had a very nice and relaxing massage and facial in the spa.I would 100% recommend this hotel

I travelled to Japan from London for the Tokyo Marathon. I arrived very early on a overnight flight, and my room was not ready. The reception staff were very polite and put my bags away whilst I went to the marathon expo to register. When I arrived back at 14:00 my room was ready. The staff had brought my bags up for me which was very nice. I was very pleased with my room. It was very comfortable and clean. I had one evening meal in the hotel restaurant after the marathon which was very good. The staff are very good in this hotel and always greeted you and were eager to help if you needed anything. There are two train stations nearby and loads of bars and restaurants. I would recommend this hotel and would stay here again.

We stayed here for three nights on our arrival from San Francisco on our first leg of our vacation. The rooms had everything and with great views of the city. We had chosen the Artist Room on the 31st floor and were surprised to find a lounge dedicated to the floor serving wine, beer, spirits, coffee/tea and other juices free to the guest of that floor.The art painted on the walls by local artists is amazing. They also had art all over for sale. The buffet breakfast was huge covering both Japanese and western choices. The Shiodome station is next door and a very short ride to Tokyo or Ginza. The staff spoke excellent English.

Excellent with helpful staff. Convenient for adjacent station all wheelchair accessible only 5 minutes away. Choice of restaurants with excellent Japanese food and decent buffet breakfast Good Taxi rank.

This hotel was by far the most expensive one we stayed in during a 2 week visit to Japan, however fell short on a number of aspects when compared to cheaper alternatives offering better value for money. Overall this is an average hotel, not good and definitely not great in terms of value for money and overall experience. This review only reflects what we experienced during our stay and compared to what else we saw during out trip. Pros: Great, central location. Amazing staff and complimentary drinks for artist rooms was a great perk.Cons: Having to pay extra for water in the room when charging over £200/night was very cheeky indeed, especially when all the other 4 hotels gave us 2 bottles for free each day. Breakfast was also ludicrously expensive. Our room felt very dated in terms of furnishings and also had a strange smell (no fresh air). Bed and pillows not very comfy.

Incredible experience before countdown to 2019 in artists hotel. Everything was perfect to woke up to see the excellent city view view, the room, the service, the amenities, the lounge, the restaurant....amazing! I will stay here next time If I’m back to Japan. Thank you mojo will recommend to all of my friends. Highly recommended.

Great place to stay and close to Ginza. Only stag to this hotel is having to take the elevators up to the lobby. Lobby is not on the 1st floor but doesn't bother me. The staff is very friendly and so helpful. The gym is very small. Do expect a lot.

A great location near Shimbashi station and ample shopping. Walking distance to Ginza and more. The hotel hosts a private Whisky room with a stellar selection worth a discriminating palate. The rooms are well equipped and the staff is ultra friendly

I try to stay in different parts of Tokyo each visit and this was my first to Ginza, an area that came personally recommended. Moving past my first impression that this would be a location more for shoppers or businessmen, the Park Hotel was well situated in terms of access to transportation and diverse places to eat, from the high-rise retail restaurants of mainstream Ginza to the neighborhood joints of off-hours Shimbashi. The staff and service in general was extremely professional and the breakfast selection was one of the best I've experienced in terms of selection and quality. Tip: The lobby in general was a great place to grab a drink, made cozy by the impeccable service.

Loved the location with access to Shimbashi station and then oeda line for Shiodome. Easy to get to both east and west Tokyo while being able to be in a less crowded area than shibuya or shinjuku. The main lobby is located on the 25th floor so the hotel is only accessible by the elevator on the first and third floor. Staff as most staff in japan are amazing. Great place to base to see all the sites in Tokyo, and only one quick subway stop from tsujuki fish market. Will return here again.

Staying favorite place makes me comfortable and relaxing time during the travel all of the world. The place is one of them for me. I used the hotel since they opened. That is why I can see how they improve their service. Half of the staffs are native foreign language speakers so most of their guests look like European and North American when I stay the place nowadays. International breakfast buffet also my family’s favorite things. Japanese and French restaurants are available. Both are high standards restaurant. Location is 20 minutes from Tokyo JR station by cab. Airport limousine bus stop to the hotel, so you do not need carry your heavy luggage all the way to hotel by yourself. Please make reservation ahead of time.

The artist rooms are so fun, well done, exquisite and a large selection from which to choose. One-of-a-kind experience to have hand-painted art on the walls of your room. Thoroughly enjoyed it.The only reason I can't give it five points is that we both hated the pillows. Hard, lumpy, cheap. Also, we stayed the night before the Tokyo Marathon. As we drove, we wanted to know whether we were going to be able to drive out of the parking garage the next morning or whether there would be road closures. The response was, "read that brochure", the Tokyo Marathon brochure located on a table. No. I'm asking for help. Help me figure it out. That's the level of customer service I expect from Japan and from the price we paid.Go for the art.

We had an artist room which was quite nice. The Zen room is really cool with a nice view of Tokyo. The other one was a bit older and needed a bit of renovation. The lobby of the hotel is really nice at something like the 25th floor. Rooms go up. I found the breakfast overly expensive. Other than this the hotel was really good. Probably the “non artist” rooms have less of “cachet” and might be classic and a bit old so be careful with this.

Spent three pleasant nights here. Nothing fancy or elaborate with the accommodation; although thee rooms are only modestly sized and quite basic, they are clean and comfortable and come with all the essentials including in room tea and coffee making facilities. The hotel starts on level 25 of the Shiodome MediaTower so you are almost guaranteed views over Tokyo city. The in room TV has limited channels with only BBC and CNN in English and they are spoken over in Japanese.The breakfast (Japanese or western) is excellent and sets you up for the day, whether it be business or pleasure. The hotel is just a seven minute walk from Shimbashi rail station and two minutes walk from Shiodome subway station.

If you want enjoy nice view and really perfect bar staff in 24 level this one is perfect choice to Tokyo under night lights. Very good selection of japan whisky and global alcohols drinks are available.

On first arrival we were a bit confused as where to go. There is no doorman to help with luggage so you are on your own until you get up to the lobby. That is the next thing, after scanning around the place eventually you will find the small sign that points to the lifts to the right which take you up to the lobby. That really needs to be made clearer as over the coming days as we would leave/return for our daily activities we could see other new customers arriving and looking equally confused on where to go.The hotel has direct access down to the metro which once you figure out all the different entrances and exits is extremely helpful to get you down to the Shiodome station.Breakfast was good, with a nice selection of both Japanese and Western food. Nice to have some decent scrambled eggs again after several prior countries that think scrambled eggs should be a runny sloppy mess.Pricing was good value. Japanese toilets are a laugh and not sure if i'll get used to having a separate bed to my wife...feels like I've been sent to the naughty corner.

Unfortunately this hotel was the worst in our tripWe were on the 34th floor (top) directly over the railway, so constant train noisesThe room was small with an outdated bathroom showerOn our final night we were asked to move due to air filtration cleaning, we were told it was an upgraded room so obliged.We packed and a lady arrived to help with our cases and give us our room keyWe had a better view ( still noisy ) but even smaller!!! My husband had minimal space from the bed with no room for a bedside table The bathroom was even more outdated with a cheap small shower nozzle. We also found 3 black hairs in our sink and felt the room had not been cleaned satisfactory.We also ate in the hotel which was good but the drinks are very expensive.The only good thing is the location right into Shimbashi station, however I think there are better hotels around for future reference

The stay was pleasant as it was up to standard. Although the bathroom was smaller than expected, the view from the room was extraordinary as we booked a room with a Tokyo view. The room was serviced everyday and staff were nice and friendly as expected from a 4/5 star hotel. There were trainees, however they all displayed professionalism. Staff always accommodated to our needs. Hotel was close to Shidome and Shimbashi station which was convenient. Beds were comfortable and overall, it was a nice stay.

I stayed in this hotel for 7 days during a business trip to Tokyo, the first 6 in an Artist King room and the last night later in my trip in a regular room.On arrival the lobby is really quite impressive with an amazing view and unlike some of the sprawling enormous hotel complexes and chains in Tokyo this one has a more intimate feel. The check-in and arrival experience is all extremely proper and polite.The King Artist room was a reasonable size with a great view and all the facilities you'd expect. The only thing missing was an iron and ironing board in the room which when you ask for from housekeeping you will receive a miniature ironing board about 2 foot long with 6 inch legs that sits on the table (or on the floor) and is entirely impractical. Although entertaining to your other half as you sit on the floor attempting to iron 6 shirts.All rooms on the 31st floor - artist rooms - come with a free breakfast of pastries or toast in the gallery room which was really nice. And you can also pop in there to get a half decent coffee when you like too.I stayed in a regular room on the last night and it was interesting to compare, it is a little bit smaller, with slightly less room around the bed. It's also far less glamorous and looks a little more tired. I got the feeling that the artist rooms were a great excuse to give some old rooms a fresh lick of paint which these regular rooms are in need of. The shower in the regular room also left a lot to be desired and could do with a refurb.The only other real negatives for me was that I wanted to have a business meeting / chat with a customer I'd arranged to meet at my hotel and was told that to hire a meeting room would cost me 17500 yen per hour. This came as a shock when most hotels I've been in elsewhere will often find you a room for free, or at most £50 for a couple of hours. The receptionist really couldn't give a hoot when I said this seemed high. I guess that's just their rate they have to charge, maybe this is normal in Tokyo? The porter helpfully told me to just use one of the sofas and tables in the lobby which I did for free arriving 30 mins before my meeting to secure a good one!I was also surprised to find out on leaving the hotel that 3 coffees I'd bought in the lobby bar had cost me over 2700 yen. But again maybe this is normal for hotels, the receptionist seemed to surprised I cared.It left a bit of a negative impression on an otherwise perfectly good hotel. I'd probably come back just to stay and make sure I go elsewhere for anything else.

A great location and a little different to what we Aussies are used to..the hotel starts on the 25th floor, and for a couple of Aussies who’s only Japanese is Arigatou and konichiwa it was easy to check in and find our way around. Close to Shiodome and Shimbashi stations navigating Tokyo was quite easy from Park Hotel Tokyo with places to eat both western and local within walking distance.Tip- pay to upgrade to a corner king room with Tower view...we’ll worth it!

Reception on the 25th floor, checking was good but why the need for paper breakfast vouchers these days !! Room a good size for Tokyo, good wifi however shower head on the wall could of been higher. Breakfast choice good with Asian and western choices, a good hotel for business whilst in Tokyo however I have to call out the gym. It only fits 1 person, 3 pieces of kit and you have to pre book for 45 min slots and for a 200 bedroom hotel there is no alternative. Every time I wanted to book it’s was full so I gave up

We stayed at the hotel this past weekend. Originally booked a queen room but it turns out that I booked an artist room. It was a beautiful room. The artist rooms are all on one floor, each one different and painted by a different artist. Upon looking at some of the photos of the rooms, my husband wanted the Mount Fuji room but it was booked. The person that was checking us in suggested that we take the Wabi Sabi room. She wasn't sure we would like it because it is dark. Well the room wasn't dark, but the painting was dark colors. As it turned out, it was perfect. It gave you the feeling of calm, especially with the snow falling outside. In the morning, we got a wonderful surprise, Mount Fuji in the distance. The artists rooms also come with a Gallery Room, which is available only to guests staying on this floor. So coffee, tea, juices during the day and in the morning a danish. It was relaxing to come to this Gallery Room to relax and recharge before heading out for the day. There are other art exhibits on other floors. All the staff was helpful and friendly. I would definitely recommend the hotel and would stay again when in Tokyo. We didn't eat in any of the restaurants, but might try them next time. Thank you for a wonderful stay!

City Twin Room on level 28, view is not too bad! Quiet & clean except carpet rather a little dusty & dirty! Bed rather quite hard & pillow are too soft! Location is convenient but overall is a little expensive! Near Shimbashi & Shiodome station so travelling is not too bad!

We stopped in here for a few days after skiing in Hokkaido. Had a room on the 34th floor - amazing view of the city. Close to trains and subway. Lots of great restaurants nearby. Top notch service from all the staff, very helpful, especially organising our transfer from the airport to the hotel. Average size rooms but really nicely done, especially if you are on the art floor. Only down side is it is a long way to Narita airport, okay from Hands airport.

We were there for the third time and again on the 31th floor with Artist Rooms. Ask for a room with a view to the West, with possibly a view of Fuji-san, otherwise you look towards office buildings. The one I liked best so far is the Dragon room. The Artist rooms come with a complementary quick breakfast, coffee/tea and an afternoon drink served in a small private lounge. A great bar on the 25th which is also nice if you not stay in the hotel

The lobby of this hotel is on the 25th floor of the tower. It is not easy to find your way to the hotel! Situated within an easy walk of the station and the nearby Hama-rikyu Gardens .The service is excellent, The rooms comfortable. The breakfast from 6.30am both Western and Japanese. Really I could not fault the hotel. Hairdryers, safes, complimentary tea and coffee. We stayed 3 nights. You have to present your voucher in the morning for breakfast.I can recommend this hotel to stay in Tokyo- as it is so near to the metro it is situated in an excellent place to get around.

We came here as a couple for 3 nights. When arriving, we were met by smiling and really friendly staff.We were easily checked in and got a room with a view to the Tokyo Tower and Mt. Fuji in the background - which we did however also pay for when booking. Nonetheless, the view was really worth paying for (we paid around 1300 yen extra per night for that view). The room is small, but that is standard for Japanese hotel rooms. Also, there usually isn't a lot of room for storage of luggage in Japanese hotel rooms and that goes for this one as well. The location of the hotel is really nice - it is within walking distance from Ginza and the great shopping area of Ginza. The nearest station is Shimbashi which is serviced by the Yamanote line among others. This one takes you to Tokyo station in 5-6 minutes or so from where you can continue to/from Narita airport and Haneda presumably as well. Shinjuku and Shibuya is 20-25 minutes journey away with public transport as well.We didn't have breakfast included, but this was around 3200 yen per person for the breakfast buffet which was perfectly fine with a great selection of different types of food - Japanese and continental. The staff at the lounge/restaurant is really polite and friendly as well.The bar at the hotel offers a lovely view over the skyscrapers at Tokyo Bay and was quite a nice and calm place to end a day around city.

I didn't initially planned to stay there, but I had to find an hotel when my train was cancelled because of a typhoon. It offered great value and was conveninently located, one station away from Central Station. The hotel is in the top levels of a huge office tower. I was in an ''artist room'', which means I had access to a few extra perks such as the small artist lounge on my floor, where there's a happy hour in the evening and a basic breakfast in the morning. Other than this, the view was nice (been very high) and the rooms were clean.Rooms were nice but didn't feel up to date. You can see the hotel was constructed in the early 2000 and the room still feel like that era. I mean it still isn't that old, so its not a real issue, but they'll probably be due for a refresh somethime soon.

This room is spacious for Japan, has wonderful views of the Sky Tree and the city. We upgraded to the Artist room just to compare. I would say although the artwork is lovely, the room size is smaller. We would go back to the room with views of the Sky Tree. Buffet breakfast is great and the service was spot on. Would come back next time I’m in Tokyo.

This hotel was recommended by my Japanese friend, who is a professional executive tour guide in Tokyo. Was she right! The hotel is located in the Shiodome Media Tower, and its lobby is on the 25th floor. It is a very short walk to Shimbashi Station and the Ginza. As opposed to the wonderful craziness of Shinjuku, this location is quiet and convenient -- which is a plus for me. The hotel itself is modern, and the staff very courteous and helpful. The hotel is known as the "artists hotel" so named because several rooms are uniquely and colorfully decorated by artists; this design feature also added to the attraction of the hotel. Although I did not have an artist room, I did have a great room (#3409) on the top floor with an entrancing city view, centered by the Tokyo Tower; in the daytime I was able to see Fuji-yama in the distance. The room itself was moderate in size, well-appointed and designed, and very comfortable. The buffet breakfast in the lobby was also excellent. Very highly recommended.

Stayed for 1 night at the corner triple room and was impress by the view in the hotel. We were able to see the skytree from our hotel room and manage to catch the mt. Fuji view upon checking out. The hotel was linked to a monorail station through a short bridge and no problem for us to push our baby stroller from station to hotel. Good hotel location to visit around odaiba area. We book our airport shuttle at the hotel to haneda and pick up is right at the hotel.

We stayed at the Park Hotel Tokyo for two nights in January 2019. We had two rooms on the Artists Floor for our family of two adults and two teenagers. The hotel is lovely, rooms very comfortable and the artists rooms a unique touch. The breakfast provisions in the artists gallery lounge were limited - essentially toast, croissants and drinks - but adequate to get us going in the morning. There isn't a lot immediately around the hotel in terms of night life, restaurants etc, but it is close enough to subway stations to easily get elsewhere and both Ginza and the Tsukiji Outer Market are within a 10-15 minute walk.

The views are indeed very nice from the hotel but the cleaning service is really basic and there are no efforts to make the room and organise it. Bags can stay on the floor and the bathroom is not reorganised. Looks like they just make the sheets and that’s it. Breakfast is nice, don’t expect too much, but convenient. The sitting area is a bit too close to the buffet area and it’s not a great experience.

Lovely hotel in the top floors of a highrise, providing wonderful views of Tokyo. Many of the rooms and public spaces feature works of contemporary Japanese artists, keeping the feeling youthful and community-engaged. There are three dining options at the hotel... The Art Lounge in the lobby offers (mediocre) western fare and drinks, Tateru Yoshino Bis serving exquisite French food with a Japanese twist, and our favorite... Hanasanshou for a traditional and phenomenal kaiseki meal. One of the great pleasures of our trip.

We stayed at the Park on two occasions during our visit to Japan.The hotel was excellent with outstanding service, very good rooms and a fabulous breakfast selection. The hotel staff were most helpful and welcoming. Very convenient location for rail hubs.Will definitely reccomend.

Other reviewers have given details on the excellent location of this hotel. You can easily get there on the airport limousine bus. We used the underground walkway to go to Shimbashi station every day, the map provided by the hotel was very useful. There are 3 Family Mart convenience stores between Shimbashi station and the hotel. We didn’t use Shiodome station as Shimbashi has so many train lines. The foyer/atrium area of the hotel is beautiful with gorgeous artwork. However, I agree with previous reviewers that the hallways and rooms could do with updating. We requested and received Mt Fuiji and Tokyo Tower views, a spectacular view (same view from reception desk). There was a wide window seat to sit on to admire the view. Our city view room was a reasonable size for Tokyo. The bathroom was small, usual for Tokyo, with a shower curtain over a bath tub. Plenty of bathroom amenities provided (shampoo, conditioner, foldable hairbrush, cotton buds, shower cap and hair tie, toothbrushes, toothpaste, razor and so on). There was a small mini bar, kettle and tea/coffee provided but no milk. I bought milk from Family Mart. The beds are very comfortable: firm mattress with both a soft Western pillow and a firmer Japanese pillow (only one side of the Japanese pillow had beans so, if you don’t like the beans, you can just turn it over).There is a coin laundry on 26th floor but we didn’t use it. We also didn’t use the gym or Thann spa. I am coeliac and I find Japan a difficult place to find gluten free food. So I was pleased to see that the Western food at breakfast had allergy labels for a variety of allergies. It wasn’t the most extensive breakfast buffet but included eggs cooked in several ways, bacon, sausages, vegetables, salad, yoghurt, fruit, cereals, pastries and cold meats. The Japanese breakfast unfortunately didn’t include allergy labels (except for the miso soup) and I would suggest that the hotel provides these in future. We ate dinner in the hotel once. Again not an extensive menu but there were 2 types of gluten free pasta. For non coeliacs, there were Western and Japanese options for dinner. The staff were all very professional and helpful, they are an asset to the hotel. We had a couple questions and they were promptly and thoroughly answered. I speak Japanese so had no language problems. We travelled with friends who don’t speak Japanese and they said that the staff spoke excellent English.I would recommend this hotel for its excellent service and location. Just keep in mind that the city view rooms aren’t as gorgeous as the foyer/atrium area (maybe try one of the artist rooms).

Very nice hotel in a good location. Walking distance to tsujiki market and Ginza. 5 min walk to shinbashi station which has alot of connections.Breakfast was very high quality and had good variety. Would definitely recommend. Only minor complaints would be that gym required a reservation and the room's bathroom was a little small.

Five stars for service level in main lobby restaurant. Food quality excellent. However menu very limited. Art work throughout hotel is really impressive, beautiful and lively. A superb 5 star amenity. Housekeeping was excellent. Shampoo and full array of amenities including razors, qtips, etc were kept well stocked. Large king bed. Beautiful view of Mt Fuji and Tokyo tower (king corner room). Shower was excellent though not a walk-in and tub floor was very slippery with no matt to prevent slipping. Room size was not expansive, but for Tokyo, at this price, a great value. Breakfast buffet was good, ambience is great, quiet jazz in a beautiful enclosed atrium with extensive art collection. Service level is outstanding. People know english and are exceedingly polite and helpful. On the food side, it was the tale of two extremes. Very good and poorly executed. Overall selection was excellent. Warm, cold, American, European, Japanese and other selections all of high quality except somethings were not fully cooked. Specifically the first day the chicken sausage was atone cold. After pointing this out to the chef, he was very apologetic and thoroughly cooked the saunas again and brought it to our table. The next couple days he brought me well cooked sausage (this was a buffet). So they handled the issue well for me. Though not sure if temp was properly maintained. Other issue was the scrambled eggs: if 0= raw and 10 = well done, they were a 0.5 every morning. Disgusting. Luckily they had delicious well cooked frittatas and hard boiled eggs, so we were ok. But just looking at a huge tray of mushy eggs was revoltingly. Having said that, everything else was excellent including the wide selection and quality. The hotel is beautiful in every way except the hallway carpeting. Clearly the room carpet had been replaced, the flooring is very nice everywhere except beyond the elevator foyer on the room floor levels. After the beautiful wood floor outside the elevators, the carpeting is very very old and stained. If they spent a few books to recarpet these hallways they would not clash so bad with the great artwork throughout the hotel. Overall excellent stay and a GREAT value.

Many ways to reach hotel from Shimbashi train station (along Yamanote Line)...by outdoors surface sidewalk, underground, or skywalk. The last two routes need some navigating which became clearer with each passing touring day. Shiodome Station is literally outside this hotel building ! Good English speakers at this hotel. Great view of Tokyo Tower from the hotel lobby window. Many places to eat in Shimbashi , around this hotel inside office towers, and near Shiodome Station. Ubiquitous Family Mart at B2 level of this hotel tower. This area felt like a refuge after a frenetic day of touring around Tokyo...especially on a Sunday! Took the very convenient 1-hour shuttle bus ride to Narita Airport rather than the train. Would stay in this area and in this hotel again.

Hotel is connected to Shimbashi Station so it was really easy to get around on subway. Walking distance to Ginza. Many restaurants in the vacinity. Rooms were adequate. Our room included breakfast. Friendly staff.

Service: 4/5Room: 3/5F&B: 2/5Location: 4/5Service: The hotel staff were mostly fluent in English (a big bonus for me since it means that I do not have to struggle with communications) and very hospitable. There’s hardly any bone to pick even if I wanted to with the kind of efficiency they work with. Room: Though a little small, there’s still sufficient space to lay out 2 large-sized luggages with minimal impact to walking space. What I really didn’t like about the room was the tiny tiny tiny (I emphasize this 3x) and flat pillows. That was really weird and uncomfortable for me to sleep with. The bed was quite tough too though I somehow got used to it by end of the week. The TV channels were also limited, and mostly played in Japanese language only.F&B: I didn’t order any food from the in-room dining menu as the options were very limited and didn’t appeal to me.Location: Park Hotel is located within 5 minutes walk to Shiodome station and 10 minutes to Shimbashi. It was relatively convenient for me to travel on the subway since I could access quite a few transit lines via these two stations. You can also easily find convenience stores and eateries in the surrounding streets.

We, as a family of your, stayed three nights as part of a surprise Christmas trip for our daughters. We booked two Executive Artist rooms and my gosh they were beautiful. My husband and I stayed in the 'En' room and my daughters stayed in the 'Sumo' room and they were just exquisite. The hotel is situated within walking distance of the old fish market which is great to wander around for a couple of hours, just don;t venture there on a Saturday as its super busy. It's also great for exploring Roppongi Hills and the vinicity.We had a great three night stay there and would highly recommend the place! Only complaint, the pillows were horrendous and felt like they were made from straw and beads,

I was so lucky to have booked this hotel with such fantastic rates. Let’s just say it’s not easy to find a high quality yet cheap 3-person rooms in Tokyo with great views AND is close to the metro!The hotel itself is not the easiest the find - it is best to access via level 3 (pedestrian bypass) rather than ground level. This is because there are very few crossings on ground level which means you have to walk up the stairs to cross the road via the pedestrian bypasses in order to get to the entrance of the main building entrance on level 1/ground level.The hotel is located right next to Shiodome station (Oedo and Yurikamome lines), but is also a short 5 minute walk away from the main Shimbashi station which has access to JR, Ginza, Asakusa and Yurikamome lines. It was easy enough to travel from Narita airport via the Sky access train which takes you directly from airport to Shimbashi station in an hour and 20 minutes. On arrival we were politely greeted by all staff who then promptly checked us in. As I booked via Expedia I had VIP benefits - which consisted of a welcome drink each and also a complimentary bottle of water per person per night. I had booked the room with Tokyo tower view and we couldn’t have arrived at a more perfect time - we could see the sunset, Tokyo tower and Mt Fuji - it was an amazing view!The toiletries were of good quality and quantities!! They provided shampoo, conditioner, shower gel, body lotion, shaving kit, small washing towel (bit like loofah material), toothbrush/toothpaste, shower cap + hair tie. In addition to this they also had tea/coffee making facilities, room slippers, robes and fabric/air freshener provided.I would highly recommend this hotel - staff were all super friendly and it’s in a great location with good access to public transport and close to local attractions. The only downside is that the hotel didn’t have a pool - but this wasn’t a big issue for me as I didn’t really have time to swim anyway!

We (family of four from Singapore, 2 adults and 2 children) stayed for 3 nights at Park Hotel Tokyo.Hotel looks new, posh and is very clean. Service is great.Reception is on 22nd floor, and there is one particular lift that takes you directly from 22nd floor to the basement (B2 for shops, B4 for carpark).The basement exit of the hotel is connected to the underground walkway to Shimbashi station, a 7-8 mins walk away. Location is superb: hotel is right next to Shiodome where the famous winter illumination is.Nearest convenience shops and bakeries are located at Shimbashi station. There are a couple of restaurants near the hotel (2-3 mins walk) but I’ll recommend going Shimbashi station where you have more choices.If you are driving, there is basement carpark within the hotel.Room size is a little on the small side: do not expect to fully open two 27" luggages and still have ample walking space.Room comes with attached bathroom, with bath tub and full set of amenities. On the whole, we enjoyed our stay at the hotel.Price per night (about SGD 290, overnight parking per night is JPY 2000) is reasonable.Very glad that we picked the right one.

Enjoyable 2 night stay at the Park Hotel Tokyo. The best thing about this hotel was the friendly staff - they always greeted us with a friendly hello and were very helpful :). Location was good - near train station and shops. Rooms an ok size - but bathroom on the small size with shower over bath. Great view of Mt Fuji from reception!

On arrival at the hotel staff to welcome us, when checking in I started to take out the receipt for our luggage ( we hadn't mentioned at this stage that our luggage had been sent on) but I didn't even get it out and our luggage was there behind us. Our luggage was then brought up and staff explained where everything in our room was and explained that our 2 friends were on the floor directly below us so they would have the exact same view which we thought was a really thoughtful gesture. Lovely and vast breakfast, we say Mount Fuji one morning from the reception. Service was amazing from the staff who arranged a to go breakfast on more morning we had a very early start to the concierge girl who arranged a car to take us to the airport for our flight home and it was so much cheaper than car transport we had looked at online. The member of staff who took our luggage down on departure was so efficient and stood and waved as we left. We had a lovely stay made stress free by the staff and the efficiency.

We stayed in one of the incredible art rooms (Geisha Goldfish) and were mind-blown by the art and the view!! There is a complimentary breakfast and a delicious buffet breakfast (2,800Y) and the 'Thann' brand body milk, shower gel, shampoo and conditioner are to die for.

A fabulous start to our first trip to Japan. Hotel was in a great location just 2 minutes from the nearest subway station and only a 10 minute walk to major subway and JR station at Shimbashi. Staying on the 32nd floor with a wonderful view across the city for 5 nights and on our last night we moved one floor to an artists room on the 31st floor. Due to length of stay we received 1 free breakfast coupon which I used. To be honest as in most places on our trip this was one thing we would not recommend. To my mind heavily overpriced (if paying) to sit in a vast space which is the bottom of the atrium and the choices were okay but not very exciting. Far better to walk a few minutes to a local cafe or similar - in our case we went to the Excelsior Cafe every day just across the first walkway outside at 3rd floor exit. The rooms were spacious and the beds comfortable with amazing views - and we were lucky enough on our last morning that the weather particularly good and off in the distance we could see Mount Fuji. The artist room was interesting but not sure would pay the extra for more than one night although as a resident on that floor had access to a small lounge there where free wine and hot drinks throughout the day. They also serve pastries there free in morning but the night we stayed our departure from Tokyo was earlier than time this started.Staff on reception level all very good welcoming and helpful at all times. Would stay here again if and when we return to Japan.

Park Hotel Tokyo was our choice for a five night stay in this lovely city before moving on to Hakodate then Kyoto. It was a little difficult to find but once there it proved to be a real gem of a hotel. We were lucky enough to be given a room on the 29th floor which had a wonderful panoramic view of the city from its huge window. The room was spotless, the beds more than comfortable and the staff were marvellous. The breakfast buffet was superb and as vegetarians we had no problem at all finding plenty of choice. You could have eaten enough to keep you going all day. We would have no problem at all recommending this hotel to our friends.

My wife and I just returned from two weeks at this hotel . We are both retired and have been to Tokyo a number of times . Thought this hotel was good value , make sure you use the various price comparison sites as big variation in prices ( surprisingly I found the hotels own site was the cheapest).We stayed in a city queen room . You can pay extra for the 'artist' queen room . Might be ok for a couple of nights , but only same size as non artist room so we didn't think it worth all the extra money for two week stay. We found the room size adequate , wardrobe quite big so after putting most of our stuff in wardrobe , just put our cases in corner by window and quite happy with amount of space . We could see Hamarikyu Gardens from window . Only ten minutes away so make it one of your first visits . Beautiful park.Takes a little while to orientate yourself to the area . We used our first morning doing that, couple of hours checking out Shimbashi area.We mostly used Shiodome station . My tip for finding hotel when arriving at Shiodome station is .. follow signs that have 'exit 7-10' on . (or 7-8) .After couple of minutes and a couple of escalators later you will see a large raised flower bed .Keep to right and take diagonal across to door with Park Hotel sign on ( just ask if you get lost , everyone very helpful)Before going it is well worth getting a Pasmo card , it's like the London Oyster card , makes things so much easier .I think you can prepay for one before your holiday otherwise you can get one at airport station .Re getting around , we are a couple of pensioners yet have found it very easy because we use HyperDia , just put in departure station , arrival station and it comes up with all the info you need ( what platform , where to change etc The hotel has a loyalty scheme . Worth joining as there are a couple of freebies depending on your length of stay . We got 4 complimentary breakfasts . You also get English language paper pushed under door every day .To join loyalty scheme go to the FAQ page on hotel website, scroll down to Amenities and Services then click the link .The breakfast is good but about £20 .Also it is served in the large atrium that the rooms are built around . You are surrounded by art but we found it a bit too formal and quiet ,like having breakfast in a cathedral . If you just want something cheap and a bit noisier then there is a Tullys nearby , about a fiver for breakfast set .(Lift to 3rd floor then turn right through corridor with lots of local art in , turn right at exit , Tullys is by station entrance .)Just one more thing re food , if you are vegetarian/vegan then there is an excellent restaurant nearby called Chaya . When you come out of 3rd floor exit you will see the famous Ghibli clock on your left . Go down stairs next to it , you will see Rose and Crown pub (overpriced , seek out one of the Hub bars nearby in Shimbashi)Opposite pub in right hand corner is Chaya restaurant.We will stay at Park Hotel again .

We love this hotel. When we come to Japan, we spend a couple of days at Ryokan Shigetsu in Asakusa and then a few days here. By checking different booking engines and the hotel website, we can usually find a good room rate, (Midweek is often best.) If possible, book an "artist room," on special floors where each room has been decorated by a different artist with a different theme. Those floors have a lounge where a continental breakfast is available, and coffee, juice and other beverages are on hand throughout the day. Staff is cordial and international, We usually go out for meals, but we found the restaurants reasonably-priced for what they offer, and the waitstaff uniformly helpful and courteous. You can walk from the hotel to Ginza shopping/restaurant district, Subway connections to museums and other venues are easy.

We stayed 4 nights at the Park Hotel, in an Artists Room on the 31st floor, and were so delighted with our Corner “Washi” Room that we booked it again for our final night in Japan before our flight home. The room was large and very comfortable. The bed was a large King Size, and the room also had a sofa and armchair, as well as desk/dressing table and roomy wardrobe. The artist’s paintings on the Washi paper on the walls were very beautiful and a great introduction to Japanese painting. We loved it!The Artists Floor has its own Concierge, and a small lounge with free drinks available (not open 24 hours a day though).The room was clean and very quiet, with great views towards the Tokyo Tower, and the bathroom was spotless with plenty of toiletries.On arrival, it wasn’t really very clear where to go – the hotel occupies floors 25 to 34 of the Shiodome Media Tower, and so we knew reception was on the 25th floor, but there were no big signs pointing you towards the lifts when you stepped out of a taxi at ground level. We did find them though, and later learnt that you took one of these lifts to get to the underground level that led to Shimbashi station (oh, what a warren that underground area is ... be warned!!!). The staff on Reception were helpful, though check-in took quite a long time, and were great in assisting us organise our luggage transfer to our next destination. The Concierge girls were particularly helpful when we finally left with all our luggage to catch our return flight.Breakfast was buffet style, and good, with plenty of choice of Western or Japanese food.We ate in their Hanasanshou (Japanese) restaurant on our first and last nights in Japan. We had a sushi platter and mixed tempura both times. The first night it was very good and the service prompt, but unfortunately our second visit wasn’t as good – the service was slow and our waitress seemed not to be at all engaged in serving us, and the food itself also suffered as the tempura certainly wasn’t as hot as it should have been. We did mention our disappointment to a manager, but no compensation was offered.Other evenings, we ate in the basement level of the next-door Caretta Shiodome, finding some interesting and inexpensive places to eat, and quite often being the only non-Japanese in the restaurant (which we were very happy about!).All in all, with its location near Shimbashi station, and the lovely room that we had, we would heartily recommend staying at the Park Hotel in Tokyo.

I stayed at this lovely hotel on my own. Great breakfast. Lovely helpful charming staff. Room tight but very clean modern and offered a great view of the city. Great location too with a underground just a few minutes away and easy walk to Ginza!

This is a smallish hotel that does what it sets out to do very well. Rooms are compact but well organized and furnished comfortably. Staff are very pleasant and helpful. One thing to keep in mind is that most of the rooms are exposed to train noise. The hotel starts on the 25th floor with rooms up to the 34th, but even on the 32nd floor you will hear trains on the busy tracks below. It’s not loud and it does fall off after midnight but it is still present.

This hotel is an excellent choice in this area of Tokyo. Good size rooms with an efficient layout and excellent views on the upper floors of one of the Shiodome skyscrapers make it peaceful as well. Staff were unobtrusive and efficient, but also friendly.My only small complaint would be the shower which is over the bath (as are most in Japanese "western" hotels) could have been more powerful.Prices are also reasonable, especially if booked well in advance.
user_name:
AlantheTrekker
Isle of Skye, United Kingdom

review_body: Very nice welcome. The hotel is nice and clean. The view from the bedroom is great. Close to shops, subway and restaurants. If you need you have often taxis waiting at the entrance. The perfect place to discover Tokyo.

We stayed 5 nights to start our Japan trip. The hotel was very convenient since they have a subway station readily accessible by taking the elevator down to the basement level. Our room was a city view tower queen. What I would have changed is to upgrade to a corner king which would have provided some more space. Breakfast got a little old but that’s true in a lot of places. Would certainly recommend this hotel.

Nice city view and service. Can see Tokyo tower and Mount Fuji when sky is clear. High on the levels, tall and beautiful lobby, fast WiFi. Every room has a different art theme. They also got nice restaurants in the hotel. The hotel is connected to the subway.
user_name:
Jiechao W
New York City, New York

review_body: Beautiful view of Tokyo Tower. The room needed dusting, the top of our headboard had a 1/4" of dust and the walls had dust bunnies all up and down them and the AC grate and ceiling was pretty dirty too. Also laying on the bed it looked like they had just replaced the main light and there were handprints all around it in the ceiling. Or maybe the room we had had just been closed up so long and nobody had used it? Also hard water all over the shower head - I've noticed this all over Japan though so maybe it is just expected? But beautiful otherwise.

We stayed here for the last three nights of our honeymoon. It was a good call, we got a good rate on Expedia and had a very plush room. The room felt modern and very clean. There is a laundry room which was handy for us, the main downside of the room being that ironing boards are not included as standard. You either have to ask for one or use the one in the laundry room. We had drinks in the bar on a few occasions. This wasn’t cheap but it felt posh and had an amazing view by the window, so worth it for a treat. The hotel is a little hard to find from the station as it is in a new complex in an area which is a maze of underpasses, steps, different levels etc. This is quite a businessey, corporate area of Japan. When I booked it I thought it was close to the Minato area with the water and fake Statue of Liberty. It’s nowhere near this. It’s personal preference but we preferred the shinjuku area of Tokyo (over an hour away from here) so would probably stay there is we went back (a bit more life - feels a bit more ‘Japanese’).

Took airport limousine bus directly to the hotel so didn’t have any difficulty finding the place. There is a signboard near the lift entrance informing that the hotel lobby is on the 25th floor. Nearest station is shiodome subway, while shimbashi JR station ( 1 station from Tokyo station) is a longer 8-10 min walk all accessible by underground passageway. Service here was quite good and friendly although the city room was rather small.

Super location, great views of Tokyo Tower from the Reception, especially when lit up at night. Rooms were comfortable and clean and we had a great view over the Tokyo skyline ( we were in the 34th floor) There was a good range of toiletries available and the toilet was a high tec style! Shower was good over a small bath.Breakfasts were lovely with plenty of choices and very fresh food. Staff very helpful and friendly in all areas. We ate in the western restaurant one night and had the wagyu beef which was very nice but drink prices were expensive there. If we come back to Tokyo we would happily stay here again.

An excellent hotel inthe perfect location. The view from our room was second to none, unless you do not want see Mt Fuji in the morning and the Tokyo tower light up againt the skyline at night. The staff is attentive and gracious. Best Manhattan in Japan and the rooms at perfect.

Perfect location to enjoy Tokyo the are is very well comunicated. The hotel is confortable with good breakfast and amazing views. The personal is correct and helpfull it´s not the best hotel in the city but is a good chice to enjoy Japan.
user_location: Las Palmas de Gran Canaria, Spain
user_name:
gmarod
Las Palmas de Gran Canaria, Spain

review_body: Our room on the 34th floor overlooked the river with long views to the sea. Stunning outlook. The room itself was a decent size, nicely decorated and contemporary. Friendly, helpful staff. The hotel features contemporary Japanese art in its public areas and one floor has rooms individually designed by an artist. Great location for accessing the subway and there’s a range of convenience shops in the building’s basement mall which connects to the station.

The rooms are not big but sufficient and probably normal (or even large) for Tokyo. But there is pretty few space to put things, except the large window sill. But breakfast was great and varied, there is a nice bar with drinks we liked. Only the japanese restaurant had a very slow service, albeit good food.The hotel is located some 10 miinutes walk from Shimbashi station, through which the public transport grid can be easily entered.Only problem might be eating outside on a weekend, since the main food hub (Shiodome City Center) was very much closed on the weekend we visited. The "Fish Bank" on 41F has great food and a great view though. There are also some western chain restaurants/bars nearby, if you want to eat there in Japan.

The Park Hotel is situated on 25th floor of a very tall building. Obviously you need to use the lift to get to the reception area. The reception area is well laid out and the rooms are situated all above the 25th floor. If you don’t like heights then this perhaps isn’t the place for you. Our room was immaculately clean, fresh and the view was stunning. Around the hotel there are plenty of shops and restaurants. However if you want to visit the centre of Tokyo you will need to use the train or underground system. My advice here would be to study the various maps before you set off as for the novice user it can be quite confusing, although it must be said the locals are happy to help guide you in the right direction. We enjoyed our four nights here and would definitely return.

Arrival at hotel was efficient and quick check in with rooms ready even though we were very early.Rooms were small but clean and comfortable, but on 30th floor with good views.The bathrooms were well supplied with towels and toiletries and the wc was of high Japanese standard.Breakfast was served behind the main reception and was efficient and quick albeit with a limited choice.The advantage of the hotel was its location, with access to the metro via the lift in the basement. The first attempt at using it was a little confusing, but we soon got the hang of it.Using the metro was simple with plenty of people to ask.We had occasion to use the concierge for advice on restaurants and sightseeing and they always had a good level of knowledge and a large supply of maps.On check out, they called a cab and took our cases downstairs and into the cab.Overall an excellent stay.

We stayed here twice, at the start and end of a holiday in Japan, and think the hotel has a lot going for it: excellent location, very near two interesting sites (Tsukiji Outer Market and the Hama-Rikyu park) and the transit station; interesting views (hotel is on floors 25 to 34); good breakfast and a choice of three restaurants within the hotel, useful if you have just landed; and, as you might expect in Japan, the staff were unfailingly polite and helpful. There are plenty of restaurant nearby and the area felt very safe to walk around in at night. We would have rated it as excellent other than the fact that the rooms are very small. We appreciate that this is the norm in Tokyo and many other Japanese cities but if you are here for a two week break and have packed accordingly it is awkward getting by in a room of this size with limited storage (although the storage arrangements were better than in other places we stayed in). We would have no hesitation in staying here again.

As other reviewers have pointed out, this hotel is very well-situated for travel by train and is close to many of Tokyo’s main attractions. Rooms are comfortable and well-equipped, maybe a little on the small size but with space at a premium in Tokyo it’s hardly surprising. There are three restaurants on site as well as a café and a fitness centre. The main restaurant serves a variety of food (Oriental, Continental etc.) at breakfast and we had a delicious evening meal there. All the staff were very helpful and friendly and we experienced no linguistic difficulties! Excellent views across the city as the hotel starts on the twenty-fifth floor of the building! As we were travelling by train we were able to arrange for our luggage to be transferred to our next destination (for a reasonable fee) which made life a lot easier en route. All in all, a great introduction not just to Tokyo but to the wider area.

This hotel was in a great location, the train/tube station just opposite and shops and restaurants just around the corner! The rooms are small so 4 of us had to share 2 rooms but the rooms were lovely! Would definitely go again!!

Spent five nights here in a corner room with view on the Tokyo Tower. The hotel is on floors 25 to 34 of the Shiodome Tower and my room was at 28th. All was fine, the room was large enough for the tokyo standards. The bath had only the bathtub, I would have preferred the shower box but I did not ask if they had another room, not a problem for a few days to have a shower in the bathtub. For the rest, nothing to complain about. The location is also great for connection to Narita or Haneda via the Shimbashi station that is directly connected via walking tunnel to Shiodome station. Also walking distance to Ginza and fish market.

Great location close to the subway. Very nice rooms, clean and comfort. The staff is amazingly kind and proffesional.Views of the city are amazing. Breakfast is very good although not extrem variety. We enjoyed a lot our 5 night stay.

I’ve been here twice this year, and it is a wonderful hotel. Why - the rooms are unbelievably good, and reasonably priced. Both the bathroom and the bedroom offer wonderful space, perhaps to stretch or easily get out of a nice king bed on both sides. Just a gem in this busy city. Stunning city views, I think from every direction, and you’re right in the middle of an extremely nice part of Tokyo - Ginza is a 5 minute walk, Marunouchi is 15 minutes walk. It’s not crazy busy. Definitely best value for money I have experienced in Tokyo, but I’d choose this hotel over other ones for many reasons.

Stayed here 4 years ago because of the location and views. My room corner king Tokyo tower view was different this time. There is a new building that partially hides the view of the Tower, which is unfortunate. The rooms are small but not unusual for Japan. Location is within walking distance to many Metro lines and inter buildings walking system make it very easy to navigate. Also within walking distance to a western breakfast Bubby’s restaurant which came in handy. All in all a good value with extremely helpful staff.
user_name:
NYTraveler11_11
New York City, New York

review_body: Really nice, modern, clean hotel once you find it, but even with the map we downloaded we struggled to find it having arrived at Shimbashi station the first time.Once located though, we found it an excellent base to explore Tokyo from.The rooms are small, but the views are great. We could hear the trains, as with most of the hotels we stayed at, but it didn't cause us any issues with sleeping.

Having spend two weeks travelling around Japan we needed a hotel for one night in Tokyo for a flight home early in the morning.The hotel entrance was quite difficult to find (different entrance levels and above another building) also there is a 'Royal Park Hotel' in the same area just to confuse us!Were had a top floor room and the views were amazing, but the room was the smallest we staying in during our trip around Japan and the bathroom very average, but everything was very clean. Also even though we were on the top floor we could still hear the trains passing through the main train station below. Glad we were here just for one night.

Stayed here for the last two nights having travelled back from Kanazawa. We reserved an artists room which is situated on the 31st floor and we were allocated the Bamboo Room. The room is not particularly large but as it is only used for sleeping it did not bother us. The amenities were well provided and those guests using these rooms have their own relaxation area. Our room overlooked the railway station amongst other sites where the Shinkansen trains run through on a regular basis. The hotel is at the top of the media tower and the centre is hollowed out. The restaurant was very reasonable and as we could not utilise breakfast on our last morning, a discount was given against our dinner. Do take the opportunity to have breakfast at Sushi Zanmai in the fish market at Tsukiji.

All-in-all a very good hotel. Superb views, clean, and great location (especially after a while when you discover all the surroundings, such as underground passageways, subway and train stations, elevated walk-ways, near-by restaurants, and shops). The rooms are small, as typical in Japan. Would recommend the breakfast, which is not cheap, but in Japanese terms an excellent European / North American fare.

Sadly, we were there for only two nights. It is a very, very nice hotel starting on the 25th floor of a high rise.The breakfast buffet is spectacular, mostly western, but enough Japanese dishes to make us happy. The lay out of the fruit is beautiful and their croissants could have been made in France. Oh, wait, I think the hotel chef is French trained. The rooms are small, but there was room enough for my husband and me and two suitcases and two computer bags. I miss all those Japanese toilets now that we are back in the states. And the view we had! Very OMG. Everyone is very helpful and their English good. This hotel started the whole Art in Hotels movement that is going on now. They have several rooms that are decorated by various artists, but unless you choose one you won't see them. But, you can go to the 34th floor and there is a small exhibit of a single artist. And they have a booklet of the art in the special rooms. What a great idea it is to foster art in this way -- Santa Fe needs to take a note!

This hotel has a wonderful location!Tokyo is Huge!, so trying to be near everything is almost imposible.The best thing about this hotel, is that two train/subway stations connect with it trough a sublevel passage.This hotel is located a the top of Shiodome Media Tower.In fact, the lobby is located at the 25th floor.The rooms are very nice and clean but small.The breakfast buffet is very good, which is nice because it is the best way to start your day.Ginza District is just a subway station away.Try to stay on the artists floor.

The location has its goods and bad sides.Rather central, walking distance from Ginza and near the Shimbashi rail center (metro, train).But the area is all office towers and hence a bit inhuman.The hotel itself is very comfortable, rooms are clean and amenities are ok by all means.Staff is helpfull and competent and speaks a good english.Very nice bakery at ground level with incredible "pain de mie feuilleté" ! not to be missed.

I was spending 5 nights at this hotel, and it was one of the best. The view is amazing from the rooms, and in clear weather, you can see Mount Fuji too! The breakfast was delicious with all kind of dishes! We celebrate our anniversary at the hotel, and they send us champagne to the room and decorated it with candles! It was the perfect stay!

We stayed here as part of our honeymoon tour of Japan.The hotel lobby is on the 25th floor, which was an odd experience to begin!The staff were incredibly helpful when we arrived. They took our bags to our room whilst we struggled with jet lag, and offered us a complimentary bottle of champagne. Our room was on the 35th floor (top) with a breathtaking view of Tokyo.On our first night, as we were so tired, we ordered room service, which was standard western food (a little disappointed in that). The room itself was absolutely spotless.Breakfast was a wide selection of traditional Japanese or western. This was served in the spacious atrium backing on to reception. Art and sculptures surrounded us, making the whole experience very enjoyable.The staff helped us find our way around the city, recommending visiting certain places and sights.When we come back to Tokyo, this is definitely where we'll be staying.

We loved the Park Hotel! We stayed there twice, once at the beginning of our trip, and again at the end. The Park Hotel is part of the regular stops for the “airport limousine bus” (which is just a bus, not in any way a limousine), so it was super convenient as our first and last place to stay in Japan. (Note there are two Park Hotels in Tokyo, so make sure you get the bus to the one in Shidome and/or near Shimbashi station.) The hotel and rooms were clean, well kept, very modern. We stayed in an “artist” room for our second stay, and it was beautiful. The hotel is on very high floors so our rooms had great views of the city both times. The hotel is within walking distance of the Ginza neighborhood and the Tsukiji Fish Market (15-20 minutes). It’s also near the Shimbashi station (on JR line) and a couple of different subway stations, all of which are reachable by underground passages—pretty nice when it’s raining. The bar at the hotel was very nice, with great views and great cocktails. We ate one dinner at the Japanese restaurant at the hotel, Hanasanshou, only because there was a typhoon that night. It was very good, albeit a little high-priced. We generally went out for breakfasts, and found a great bakery near the entrance to Shimbashi station, and a Tully’s, which had the best latte that we could find. We would definitely stay here again.
user_name:
Lance W
South Bay area, Ca

review_body: 3 night stay, clean, quiet and well equipped room. Super buffet breakfast, adequate dinner choice but very limited if you don’t eat meat/fish so only had one dinner at the restaurant, also only serves food till 22:00 In lounge area other two restaurants serves to 21:00.Customer service a little ‘off’ but would stay again if in Tokyo.

It is located in Shiodome and close to the Tsukiji Fish Market, Ginza shopping district and Imperial Palace grounds.The hotel is located above the 25th floor in a skyscraper, our room was on the 28th floor. We had our teenage son with us so we shared a corner room. It was so spaciaous we didin't have any issues sharing the room which had an amazing view of the Tokyo skyline. We could easily spend all our time in the room the view was that stunning.I would definitely go back to this hotel in a heartbeat.

A very luxury hotel. 35 floors hotel with a 360° view on Tokyo. Spacious room with skyline, delicious and varied breakfast for all requests. Easy to reach by underground line. A direct entrance from the underground. Itinerant exhibitions cheer guests. Staff always available e courteous. Absolutely recommended for your trip in the capital!

Stayed here after returning from Ishigaki and returning home via Narita the next day. Easy to get to from Haneda via monorail and train to Shimbashi Station. Able to access underground which was nice in the rain. Note this hotel is in the Shiodome "Media" center to assist you in getting there. My travel agency booked me on the Artist floor which had rooms painted by different artists, and concierge on the floor, Nice view from room. Couple of nice restaurant choices and good breakfast buffet. English speaking staff. Appreciated staff assisting on unrelated shuffle pick up to airport as they allowed me to wait in the lobby on the 25th floor, monitored the shuttle arrival, and even walked me down to the shuttle when it arrived.

A solid option, member of Design Hotels, and great value for money in central Tokyo, only a 15 minute walk from Hamamatsucho station, directly linked by monorail from Haneda Airport. The location is also great for getting around Tokyo. Whether at road level or using the elevated walkways, it’s very easy to reach any part of central Tokyo. The Giant Ghibli Clock is located just outside the hotel, again, connected by elevated walkway, while Shiodome underground station is also close by.I booked a corner room with a view of Tokyo Tower which was worth paying extra for. The room was a good size, with a comfortable bed, multiple charging points including USB, and with the usual bathroom amenities (by Japanese standards) of heated toilet seat and mirror, quickly clearing up after being steamed! The bathroom was stocked with Thann products.Breakfast, served in the main lobby area, had both Western and Asian options. Overall, staff were helpful and attentive. The property is at the top end of what I expect from a 4* hotel. I would happily return and recommend it to others.
