Great location near the park and the trains, but no noise. Excellent service, good English. Fine breakfast with mostly western dishes, small Japanese section. Hard beds. Staff are very helpful in planning excursions, selecting restaurants and showing you how to get around.

We had stayed here 10 years ago and liked the hotel but this time we loved it even more.We had a lovely room on the top floor with a view of Tokyo tower.We decided to have breakfast each morning in the lunge which had quite a good western breakfast although a little steep at 2,800 jpy per person.The bed was really comfortable and we both slept really well. What makes this hotel fantastic was the staff all really friendly. The bar is also fantastic with a friendly bar tender who took the time to chat to each person and who made fantastic unusual cocktails.The hotel also has 2 washing machines with dryer which we used. We thought it would be useful for the hotel to advise guests that they should take out their washed/dried clothes after it finished so other guests could use them. Overall we had a fantastic time at the hotel and would highly recommend it for a stay in Tokyo.

I made a reservation and quickly realized that I had booked it for the wrong night. I quit my browser immediately, yet 5 minutes later I got a confirmation email from hotels.com. I called hotels.com as soon as I got the email and they called the hotel. We also sent emails to the hotel on 9/28. On 10/3 they messaged me back saying they never got any communications, despite the evidence I had that hotels.com emailed them! They refused to move the booking over one night from Sunday to Saturday. Very unfortunate that this happened before we even got there, but I'm glad it did as I would not want to travel internationally at a place with such poor concierge and support services.

The hotel is very nice, modern and provides a great base for touring because it is located near two major subway stations. We stayed in the "artists" rooms which were very lovely and one of the side benefits was the private lounge for snacks, coffee and drinks. This hotel is a high-rise with great service and accommodation. We would go back again.

Good value for money. Hotel situated in the second half of a tower building. Small gym. Walking distance to Shiodome and Shimbashi. Close to Hamarikyu Gardens. Rooms facing Mount Fuji offer great views during the day and at night. Experiencing the sunset behind Mount Fuji from your room is a memory for life.

Nice boutique hotel in Shiodome. Good Tokyo tower view and cosy art design hotel room. As golden member of Expedia they also provide me with welcome gifts which are nicely designed. Very good service and friendly staff. Highly recommended for a stay.

Treated ourselves to stay here for the last night of our Japanese tour. Stayed on the 33rd floor in a corner room. Fantastic views. So good. that we had room service and ate just overlooking the view with dimmed lights in the room. A must experience

From to check in to check out this hotel was absolutely perfect. Nothing less. Only thing that doesn’t really make me happy is the area of Shiodome. It’s a business area but at least Shinbashi Station and the lively neighborhood around it. Also the Shiodome metro station is connected directly with the building of the hotel.The rooms are large in size compared to what I have stayed at in Japan and the breakfast was definitely above average as well.I had a view of Shinbashi Station from my room and I find it very interesting to follow the life of the city from above when I’m on the phone or using my computer. There was no noise from the city at all.So to sum up: Wonderful hotel!

This hotel is conveniently located between Shiodome and Shimbashi stations and occupies a building from the 25th floor and up. Walking distance to Ginza (Tokyo’s 5th Avenue/ Oxford Street). The rooms have great views over the city! They’re quiet and spotlessly clean. The staff are friendly, attentive and speak great English. We used their transfer service to Narita airport to avoid the rush hour on public transport, well worth it! Would stay there again

We stayed here for 4 nights in Room 3228 on the 32nd floor. The hotel foyer is on the 25th floor. Our room was amazing offering views of the Hama-rikyu Gardens & the Sumida River. The room had everything you need including safe box & a supply of very nice body cream. Our room had a very nice mural on one wall & was very quiet, clean, comfortable & spacious. They offer free Wifi with excellent reception. All staff speak very good English & are very friendly & helpful, especially Takasawa who spent a long time with us explaining the public transport system & giving us advice on what to see & do near the hotel area. The hotel is very near to the Fish Market, ( it will be moving in October) Hama-rikyu Gardens and the water bus. Shiodome Suway is just under the hotel & it is walking distance to Shinbashi Station where you can travel to Tokyo Station for all JR train transfers. It is also walking distance to shopping area & restaurants.

Stayed here for a leg of our honeymoon trip across Asia. Beautiful hotel, great staff, great service! We stayed on the top floor (34th) which offered amazing views of the city. Restaurant breakfast was great. The wifi is solid in the rooms, but was a bit choppy in the lobby - not really a big deal though. Easy to get to the metro and close to a lot of great places to eat, shop, tour around etc.

We stayed in this hotel near the Fish Market and The Empeor's Gardens. It was spotlessly clean, had great views over the city and some of the most beautiful art work I have ever had the privilege to enjoy. The service was fantastic and the staff could not have been more helpful. A tip was to use Japan's fantastic luggage forwarding system to move your cases from one location to the next so that you can enjoy the fabulous train system without being encumbered by big cases. It works a treat.

Location is really nice. Very close to a major stations. Rooms are very clean and well equiped. Rooms are also good size with Japan standard. Staff are friendly and helpful. Highly recommend this hotel

Very nicely run hotel with all services and even laundry facilities. The hotel boasts a nice art theme though the decor could use a little freshening up. My room was quite small but hey, this is Japan so I don't expect large spaces. Service is professional as you'll find in most any Japanese establishment. My only complaint is the cigarette smell permeating the lobby due to a smoking lounge off the lobby.The area is a little quiet which I found to be a plus from a day spent in the madness of Shinjuku or Akihabara. There are two major train stations nearby so getting around is very easy.

I stayed in this hotel for 20+ times. Hotel is not big but that is a pro for me as it keeps the hotel tranquille. Room isn't big either but is enough for a business traveller. Hotel location is good, with easy access to Shiodome and Shinbashi station although the exact location of the hotel is a bit hidden. Staffs are ok, not like a warm welcoming style but helpful when you need them.

We stayed in a triple room at this hotel for around 2 weeks. The rooms and service provided were excellent and the staff were always happy to assist.Throughout our stay we had 2 nights where we stayed at different hotels due to events and the Park hotel was more than happy to keep our bags until we returned the next day to check in again. They also assisted with transferring our bags to our next hotel in Kyoto.All in all a great hotel and we would definitely recommend it to others.

We arrived in Tokyo via the Bullet Train. A unique experience in itself.The Park Hotel Tokyo is less than 6 minuets walk from the station underground station so uniquely positioned for all areas and sights.The hotel is situated from the 25th floor of a huge sky scraper the welcome was subdued until we took the lift to the 25th floor check in but from then on it was wonderful efficient and overwhelmingly polite. The room had a stunning view across the river and was very well appointed. The area is pro dominantly a business area but has many very nice shops & restaurants also convenience stores.We would not hesitate to recommend and revisit this very trendy hotel and it’s 34th floor art corridor.

Request specific artist room and hotel met my request. Good location, nice Tokyo tower view at my room, direct tunnel connection to hotel building with elevator and escalator from subway. Walking distance to fish market (it will move on Oct 2018 tho) and Donkihote.Wake up with allergy hand, assume the bed sheet was dirty..........

Just my second trip to Japan, so my lovely wife organised a 2 day stopover in Tokyo. We stayed at the Park Hotel. As I didn’t quite know what to expect it was quite a surprise to enter a hotel on the 25th floor of a skyscraper. You stroll through a massive five story atrium to the reception with fantastic views over the city. Check in was smooth & the staff were consummate professionals – one person even insisted on going with us to the lift just to press the button for us. On entering our room I was initially disappointed, it had everything we needed, large bed, en-suite, however the colours of the décor & furnishings were quite dark, it wasn’t until I pulled back the curtains that we got the full WOW factor of the stunning views over the city skyline from the floor to ceiling window with its own seat. We enjoyed great breakfasts in the atrium dining room, had friends visit us for drinks & cakes. A great 2 day stay at the hotel, another nice touch was that as we were leaving one member of staff came down to the ground floor to ensure we caught the right bus to the airport – many thanks. Tip for you. Directly below the hotel right down in the subway section we found a family mart store, we bought snacks, noodles, sandwiches, wine & beer for just £11 & took them back to our room, we turned off the lights & just looked at the city skyline at night.
user_name:
David H
Oxford, England, United Kingdom

review_body: A quite retreat from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo. And close to the trains and other modes of transportation, including taxis and buses. We were very pleased with the space of our room and the bath facilities. The breakfast buffet was outstanding.

Great location and lovely staff. We were on the top floor and had amazing views over the city. There was a good selection of food for breakfast which helps start your day and eat dinner there twice which was nice.

The service is good - not outstanding - but very good service is absolutely usual in Japan so I'm not inclined to rate up for a service level that was average for the country.Location is good, though the hotel itself can be a bit difficult to find.The rooms are functional. Clean, large enough (again, Japanese hotel rooms tend to be on the small size).We ate in the hotel's own Japanese restaurant one evening. The food was ok but not outstanding, a few mistakes were made in the order, and we weren't given any choice about where we'd like to sit in a half-empty restaurant.

This hotel was lovely with great breakfast options. It was near wonderful shopping and the world famous fish market. We would stay there again without hesitation. We don't speak Japanese so we appreciated the very helpful concierge and desk clerks who spoke English well

Hotel is on the 25 th floor of a skyscraper tower but there was no staff member to direct you to reception only signs at the entrance to the tower. We had a fantastic room on the 34 th (top floor) that gave us a wonderful view.On arriving and throughout our 3 night stay we found all the staff to be friendly and helpful and spoke english very well.Our room had an art decoration on the wall of tulips and was modern with a small fridge and safe.Japanese style slippers and bathrobes were supplied. The subway is an few minutes walk away but negotiating the various lines and reading the underground signs which have limited english is a bit of a challenge. We only ate breakfast at the hotel which had many choices of food. It doesn’t start until 7pm which was a bit annoying one morning when we had to leave early to take the subway to meet a tour that we had booked. Didn’t spent much time in the area around the hotel during the day but at night when we arrived back around 10 pm everything seemed shut and the streets were pretty quiet.

Stayed for one night before heading back home to Europe. Have already been there 3 years ago on our last trip but for a few more nights. staff very friendly at the front desk and very helpful Good EnglishHotel full So could not get a late checkout even if we wanted to pay for it. Could use the shower of the gym before our departure for the airport. Even if I didn’t use it, could see how the gym looks like... 3 machines packed in a small room that you have to reserve in advance to be able to use it. ... disappointing...Breakfast very very disappointing Arrived for BF at 9:30.  It normally close at 10:30Almost half empty. Nobody cared about refilling the stands. Had to ask the staff to bring new food. Even with that the food came very very slowly. Have the feeling that the overwhole quality went down during the last years....Rooms are ok. But nothing exceptional A bit small but around the standard in Tokyo. Good location even though in a business area. Need to walk a bit to go to Ginza. Don’t know if I would come back.

Stayed in the hotel for 5 nights with my family and I can highly recommend it. Very quiet, very clean and conveniently located to do the usual Tokyo touristic tracks- although it is far from some of them the subway it is just meters away.

I had a wonderful experience with Park Hotel Tokyo. We were tired by the time we arrived, but the staff made us feel very welcomed. The next day I had to see a doctor and reception made the necessary arrangements for me. They called the medical clinic ahead of time and showed me how to get there. Our twin corner room was a decent size for 2 people. My mom was happy with it and she can be hard to please because she is so use to North American hotel room standards. We liked the view too. We could see Tokyo Tower from it. We felt safe and it was a home to come back to at the end of the day. We made the right choice to stay here. There were many subway lines underneath the Shiodome Media Tower so we could easily get to any site. There were plenty of eateries too. This included Family Marts and a 7-11. There is also a post office nearby. Staff was always friendly and they dealt with our needs and concerns. It was too bad that we didn't get a chance to enjoy a drink at the lounge. Lastly, if you have luggage or will travel with an aging parent, take a taxi from Tokyo Station after you get off the Narita Express. It is a bit of a walk from the underground subway station to the hotel when you have luggage with you. Overall, I would recommend Park Hotel Tokyo.

We made the right choice staying at this hotel. We were upgraded to an artist room, and wow, did it make our trip all the more magical. Our room, the Geisha Goldfish room, was beautifully hand-painted. It also had a view of the Tokyo Tower. The staff was extremely friendly and professional. Seriously, I believe we got the best hotel room in all of Tokyo. It was BEAUTIFUL!

Spent 3 nights here at the start of our trip to Japan. Arrived at midday, but allowed to go to our small but comfortable room early. The hotel starts on the 25th floor, so interesting views of the layers of railway and metro lines and roads from our window. Quite close (5-10 mins walk) to Shiodome and Shimbashi stations, with access to the Tokyo Subway and the JR Yamanote line. Half an hour train journey from Shinjuku, but not too far from the fish market and Hamarikyu garden. Breakfast was an excellent buffet with a huge choice of juices, fruit, pastries and big choice of western and oriental dishes. Dining options seemed expensive, however, so we ate in the restaurants in the subway area.

Family Holidays in Tokyo. This hotel is ideally located near Shibashi and near a subway station. Breackfast is various and qualitativ and service is 5*.Very clean rooms and everyrhing is made for customer satisfaction.

We stayed a total of nine nights and found the hotel faultless. Great views, comfortable rooms and decent breakfast. What stood out was the quality of their people. Smiling, helpful, personable and very efficient. Special mention for the restaurant concierge, Ieva, who recommended and arranged a number of meals, all excellent.Location is excellent for train and tube.

Very nice hotel with excellent service. Excellent rooms, but limited (expensive) restaurant options; nonetheless, excellent food. Location seemed to lack visitor options, but with guidance (not forthcoming) are probably exist.

We just had a 4 night stay at the Park Hotel in Shiodome. It is a modern wesyern style hotel with a bit of Japanese art thrown in. Big plus is the location with both the Shiodome and Shimbashi subway stations within 5 min walking distance. Tokyo Station, Akihabara, Ginza, Shibuya all very easily accessible by the metro. Also, lots of awesome food options in the izakayas with lively evenings again 5 mins away. Breakfast was excellent (especially their breads!) Which had both Japanese and Western options. Attentive, helpful staff. Also, wife and daughter went to the spa which they really enjoyed. Overall an excellent choice for a stay in Tokyo.

The location is excellent, few MTR station nearby with around 1 min walk distance.The windows is not huge but you can still have a good view as the hotel is built starting from 25th floor.There is no complimentary bottle water in the room. Rest room amenities are the luxury brand from Thailand.Service is good, like many other Japanese hotel. And they can all speak English.Breakfast is okay, love their fruits, soups and bread. Cocktail at the bar is also good, but the price is a bit too high.The hotel also provide bus service to the airport, price at around 3300 Yen.

This is my second visit to Tokyo on business and first with my wife tagging along. While searching for hotels my top priorities were on that was closed to my meetings in Toyosu, a reasonable sized room, free WiFi, proximity to a Narita Express stop, Tsukiji fish market and dive restaurants/bars, a lovely view of the city and supports the needs of foreigners for our 6 night stay. Yes, that was a laundry list. I did find all that in the Park Hotel Tokyo.Arrival via taxi was typical. No doorman at the ground level which was fine for this price level of hotel. There are 3 standard hotel size elevators which take you to the 25th floor for check-in. Although only one takes you to B2 to access the underground passage way to the Shiodome stations (Oedo line & Yurikamome) Shimbashi station, and the Tokyo Shiodome Building which houses the global headquarters of Softbank as well as some good western style breakfast café options. If you prefer to walk outdoors, take the elevator to level 3 for the elevated walkway for access to the same. By the way, being situated near the start of the Yurikamome line gives you a good chance of getting one of the 3 seats out the front of the train giving you wonderful views of the Rainbow Bridge, Odaiba and the 2020 Olympic village under construction. Check-in was smooth and a friendly staff member helped take our bags as he directed us to our room. We were welcomed to a clean well-prepared Tokyo Tower view room with a something little extra which I had requested for my spouse. The room’s A/C unit was struggling a bit the first day under what I was told record 37C temperature / 43C heat index. (My colleague from Tampa, FL mentioned it was hotter than home.) Although it regained control as the outside temperature returned to summer norms over the next few days. The window seat bench and the accompanying seat cushion is a nice touch although you may not sit for long if you are afraid of heights. There is enough room between the desk/vanity and the drapes to fit our 30” Samsonite suitcase. There is a modest size closet with in-room safe. The queen size bed is a bit on the firmer side. The sound insulation was generally very good. I never heard my neighbors, guests in the hallways or water flowing through the pipes, although you can hear the muffle of the trains to/from the Shimbashi station. Perhaps because our room is west facing, the winds from Typhoon Jongdari (38mph sustained / 50mph gusts as measured at nearby Haneda) were not perceptible from our room other than the calming noise of a few raindrops hitting the window and what sounded like a metal window sash. A local friend of ours helped pick up a local SIM card at a store on the other side of the Shimbashi station where there are many dive bars and restaurants available. There are a few Irish pubs in the neighborhood. The hotel offers a nice brochure of the best restaurants in the area for the various types of Japanese cuisine, Ramen, Teppenyaki (think Benihana but better food quality and typically 2x the cost), Izakaya, and Sushi.The English fluent front desk is staffed 24 hours a day which suffering from jet lag was welcome as I found myself working most effectively in the very early morning hours from the business center situated right next to the check-in desk. I spent several hours over the six days and found the two desks very comfortable with extra plugs for your laptop. I was able to fit my 2 laptops comfortably on the desk even with the large iMac present on each desk. Most of the plugs in the hotel & all plugs in the room are the US style 2-prong. I found only one US 3-prong electrical outlet in the business center. I recommend bringing an adapter if you plan on using a device with a 3-prong plug just in case. The desk chairs are really comfortable and the lower lumbar cushion is a very nice feature on the chairs. I wish I had the same chair at my desk in the office.The 2 coin operated laundry machines were a bonus. While the modes are limited, I threw in some t-shirts, undershirts and our undies even mixing (gasp) colors with whites without issue. I went with the 1.5kg wash mode which includes laundry detergent and a damp dry mode. This was good experience marred only by finding the front loading washer a bit dirty and I had to clean some left over junk from inside of the tub. The damp dry mode is fine. I hung our clothes using the over bathtub clothes line and the hangers in the closet. After about 4 hours in our air conditioned room my clothes were dry and my cotton undershirts were just as soft as if I had thrown a sheet of fabric softener with them in the dryer at home. Clothes that I laid flat on the bed or on the chair did not fare as well. Check-out was smooth and the front desk staff was kind enough to ask where we were headed next and prepared a card in Japanese for me to present to the Taxi driver. We had a great stay and I look forward to my next visit. I'll try the on premises restaurants next time.

I did not know much about the Park hotel until I arrived. It is located on the 25th to 34th floor of the Kyoto news building right off Shiodome station on the monorail (not the underground). The lobby is open from the 25th floor to the roof and there is a lot of art being displayed and for sale. stayed at one of the wonderful art rooms on 31st floor with Tokyo/Edo theme. I was pleasantly surprised when I got to the floor and the elevator openned to 2 artists painting right there on. The room is small but nicely decorated. I would say the fixtures are slighlty dated. They have a small room with free coffee, drinks and breakfast. The service is very good as they gave me a few ideas on where to walk around. I also enjoyed the lunch which was reasonably priced and pretty good. Great hotel, love the cool art and definitively I will stay there if I need to be in that area of Tokyo

Nice hotel situated in a good location close to shops and the fish market. Right in the JR and metro lines as well. The room was a good size with artistic features. Having the breakfast room with compliments was handy for the mornings. We didn’t eat in the hotel but overall recommend staying here. The view were stunning of the city and Mount Fuji was in the distant background

Very clean and stylish. Two adults and two teenagers: got two rooms. The rooms are nice and have a great view (all rooms are floor 25+). Friendly (which is of course not rare in Japan). Good copious breakfast with both Japanese and western choices. Metro station in the building brings you directly to Roppongi, Shibuya ... we had a great four day stay here.

The Park Hotel is above a office tower, and has some great views of the city and even Mt Fuji. Rooms are reasonable size for Japan but smaller than is usual in other countries. We’ll appointed facilities, very comfortable bed, very quiet.Service was excellent, and the breakfast and lobby bar was to a high standard. The location is in Minato - and very useful to the Tsujiki fish markets (walking distance) and the Hamarikyu gardens. It has underground access to several stations (the complexity of these underground passages presents some directional challenges). While the hotel location worked for us, it is in a business district and not in part of the city that has lots of restaurants, bars and tourist related activities. Check your requirements.

The hotel is located at the Shiodome metro station with direct access to the hotel from exit 7-8 from the metro. We flew into Haneda T1 and got the monorail from the station at the airport to Hamamatsucho and then walked out of this station to change to the metro at Daiman. this is a very short distance from Hamamatsucho. Shiodome is one stop on the E line eastbound. Tickets are relatively cheap but suggest you buy the 24h pass if you intend to travel around Tokyo. Works out at less than 1000 yen for 2 people.The hotel reception is welcoming with an art expo concept which is well worth viewing. Staff are attentive and helpful. We arrived just before 8am so had to wait until 12pm for our room to be available so we sat in the lobby next to the dining area for a few hours. Suggest you consider popping into Tokyo to eat up some time!The hotel lobby is on the 25th floor and we were allocated a room on the top floor (34) which has magnificient views of the city. The room was clean with a great view and there is also a cushioned window sill so you can sit and admire the skyline from your room! Our room was fairly small so having big cases provided a challenge. There is a room safe but bizarely, this was sat on top of a very small shoe rack which was not attached to the wall or floor so could be physically picked up and moved........There are a number of restaurants in the hotel (which closed at 21.00) but we did not eat here, instead we ventured out to Shimibashi which is a 10 minute walk from the hotel main lobby. This is a vibrant and bustling area full of street bars, noodle shops and eateries crammed with locals. A bowl of ramen plus a beer for 2 people cost around 2,800 yen which is very cheap and thoroughly recommended if you want to attempt some sort of authentice Japanese eating experience. We ate there every night during our 4 night stay. There are also many convenience stores in the vicinity for snacks, alcohol and water should you need this.Overall, a great hotel in a great location and thoroughly recommended.

Great location with lots of public transport (subway and trains) and walking distance of Ginza (trendy and expensive) and the fish market. Located on 25+ floor so great views. Rooms comfortable. Breakfast excellent. Tiny gym.

Stayed for 3 nights in July, we found the staff very helpful and friendly towards us, the breakfast choice was extremely varied both for locals and overseas visitors and the restaurant service and food was exemplary although a little pricey it was well worth it.The room was very comfortable with a good view of the park and also into the city.Located just 5 minutes from Shimbashi station its just a traffic free walk to the hotel.( Don't get mixed up with the Royal Park Hotel which is very close).All together a very enjoyable 3 nights stay.

We enjoyed our start very much. The art expo concept of the hotel makes it different and interesting. Great location in Tokyo. Attentive staff and good quality in food and rooms. Our only suggestion would be to extend the lobby cafe and/or room service hours at least until 23:00.

The staff in this hotel are exceptionally helpful and delightful. My room, while small (but not by Japanese standards), is very comfortable, and the bed and pillows are really good.Breakfast has a lot of variety, and there is plenty to eat.It is close to all modes of public transport, with a good walkway that mostly avoids steps to get to.

Perfectly located just 5 minute walk from Shiadome Station for the monorail and metro lines, and Shimbashi for normal rail and Narita Express- 2 stops from Tokyo Station. Fast wifi, very friendly staff most who speak English. Art on display everywhere. Hotel starts on 25th floor, we're were on 33rd.

A very friendly hotel and the food is lovely with a great selection to choose from.The reception staff were very helpful and nothing was too much trouble.If you don't like heights this is not the hotel for you!The spa is excellent.
user_name:
elainedawnharris
Santa Cruz de Tenerife, Spain

review_body: I have been visiting Japan for work, testing hotels as a travel agent. I knew Japan was expensive but it seems hard to find good value for money like in SE Asia.Park hotel has a good location and close by to lots of great transport links. Staff are friendly and I was grateful for the early check in after a very long journey. I stayed in a city view room which is the standard level. Everything very clean but not really what I would count as a 4*. Quite basic fittings and bathroom. The room was very small.I also saw a few other room types, I think the premium rooms are more in line with 4*Good breakfast choice.

It is simply a great hotel in heart of Tokyo. The rooms are cozy fitted with all the modern amenities. It offers great views of the city. The staff is really cordial. The breakfast suits the taste of international travellers and there is a lot to choose from.

Hotel is located between Shimbashi (JR) Station and Shiodome Station, with underground walkways to both stations. Whilst there are some signage, the underground passageways can be a bit complicated, so I recommend getting a map from hotel front desk. Rooms are clean and comfortable, coin-op laundry available.

A well positioned downtown Tokyo Hotel close to the important Shimbashi Station. The hotel staff were amazingly friendly and helpful. The room on the 34th (Art Gallery) floor was simply outstanding.Breakfast was everything you would expect from a 4*hotel. There are three restaurants within the lobby floor. You have a choice of Japanese, Western style and French restaurants. We tried the first two both very good but on the expensive end of the scale - but great surroundings made it value for yen.

This was one of the best attractions in Tokyo. If I ever go back to Tokyo I would stay here. Our room was on the 31st floor and was part of the art gallery so painted all over. Excellent breakfast enough to fill you up until lunch time. Excellent location close to main tube and train station. Views from main hall and rooms are just amazing!

We spent several nights here prior to a cruise out of Yokohama. We found the staff to be more than helpful from our arrival in the street level lobby to our departure on our last morning. We stayed in a standard queen size room overlooking the harbor area. Room was smallish, but adequate for our needs. Full size bathroom and decent closet space. Coffee / tea making setup was sufficient for our needs. We enjoyed the location, though we were not able to get to the near by fish market due to a substantial rain stormThere is a well stocked bake shop on the ground floor, as well as a limited menu 'coffee shop'. Both close early since they primarily cater to the workers in the office building.The lobby of the hotel is actually on the 25th (?) floor, with a dedicated set of elevators to take you up there just off to the right of the ground floor entrance to the building. There is a nice restaurant on the 25th (Lobby) floor where we ate one meal. Somewhat limited menu, but food was good.For variety we found that you could take the elevator down to the 3rd floor of the building, then walk across the walkway into the Shiodome where there is a large variety of restaurants available. If the skies are clear be sure to stop to admire the view of Mt. Fuji in the picture window behind the reception desk on the 25th floor!

NO ROOM SERVICE - which is a travesty as there is little food around this area at 2am. So plan ahead if you get hungry late at night. THe rooms that are individually painted are amazing and such a treat! The lack of even a takeout menu list or list of close places to try to access food was SURPRISING to me, especially for a fancy downtown hotel in a major international city like Tokyo. It is good hotel even without room service, but a list of options and a staff that can guide you at all hours of night and day to food is a must.

We stayed there 6 days for our Tokyo trip, and we were really satisfied by this hotel. It’s ideally positioned between two subway stations, so you can easily travel around Tokyo from these 2 stations (and their related lines), it s really close to Ginza and the fish market so you can walk from the hotel to these areas. The view on Tokyo tower is really really nice, and you can also get a glim of the mont-fuji if the weather allows it (i also stayed at the Shangri-la and I comparison the view on the Tokyo sky tree from there wasn t as great as the view on the Tokyo tower from the park hotel). The team is really dedicated and helpful so you ll get a great support for your activities. A good hotel with large room, with decent prices for Tokyo. We will book it again for our next trip. Don t forget to be a member of their program to get extra complementary services/advantage

I've stayed in a thousand hotels worldwide, and this Hotel is in my top 3. I followed the Hotels advice and slept with the curtains open to enjoy the city views at night. WOW. Everything was seamless; check-in/ out, cafes, room etc. etc. Staff and facilities were exemplary, from the café waiter with a comprehensive knowledge of Tokyo craft beers to the receptionist providing directions. Centrally located, 15 minutes to Ginza.

This is our first time in Tokyo. We went without the benefit of a tour guide. So we were using the subway/trains the whole trip. This hotel was magnificent. It is connected to the subway system, at the bottom of a dedicated elevator. You literally walk underground from the hotel to the subway station and it is such a huge place that I joked that you can have a concert in there. The whole area was clean and had plenty of shops towards the main station. The hotel itself was located ideally, within walking/subway to everywhere we wanted to visit. The concierge was very helpful. They even gave us pointers for how to see Mt Fuji and the cherry blossoms, which we saw just a little of what is left. Their input helped us plan our trips. They also were very punctual with our requests for extra towels, tissues, etc. And they don't take tips. Like everyone says, this hotel starts on the 25th floor, which is no big deal since the elevators were fast. It is also quiet. We totally enjoyed our stay and will probably come back here for the 2022 Olympic games.

Stayed for four nights on the first leg of our Japanese sojourn. Couldn’t fault anything. The location is close to all amenities within a few minutes. If I had the opportunity to visit this great country/city again, my preferred choice would be Park Hotel Tokyo. Thank you for starting our break with a bang.

We stayed here for several days & will do so again. The hotel is lovely, the staff are great, & the location is close to Shiodome station, with Shimbashi station also nearby, around 10 minutes away. It's close to the Tokyo Monorail from Haneda airport, the station being Hamamatsuo, one subway stop away.There's several food stores in the train station & hotel basement. Note - from Shiodome metro stop, go to exits 7 & 8, & the entrance to the hotel is just before that.We were on level 29, the hotel starts at level 25. The staff spoke fluent English & were lovely & helpful. Our room was very comfortable & quiet. Japan still allows smoking so if you're a non-smoker be specific. Also, Japan is not a morning country, & there's not a lot open before 9am.Highly recommended.

We visited early June with my wife and two teenagersThe hotel is located on the upper floors of an office building that is linked by covered walkway to a subway stationThis was a huge plusVery quiet and private, the lobby was well kept and the staff highly respectful at all times and always willing to helpRoom were updated and the lounge on 30 was nice- only problem was that there was nowhere to get tea or coffee prior to 7am without leaving the hotel-not a biggie though since there are in room coffee makersLocation was great and near most attractions-train super easy to useWould stay there again

Very good location for public transport. However, took wrong exit from subway when we first arrived and couldn't find hotel. Jet lagged with big cases, we took a 5 minute taxi ride at a cost of £4-money well spent. We had pre-booked a guide for the following day, who showed us how to find the two nearest stations-easy when you know how; she topped up our Pasmo cards (oyster card on steroids-you can use them in shops and taxis as well as public transport) and then took us on a very enjoyable and enlightening tour of Tokyo-you will not believe the cost of fruit in the market. Our room was comfortable and the staff were very friendly and helpful. We ate in the lounge on our first evening and in the French restaurant on our last night. Bit pricy but excellent food and service

Perfect location, a few minutes from Yamanote line. About other things, is just what you would expect from a 4-star hotel. They got a coin laundry room too. I got a queen room, the size is enough for a queen bed and luggage.

The Park Hotel Tokyo was a fantastic location for our first trip to Japan. The hotel itself was very well maintained, and has a unique style thanks to the artist themed rooms and generally artistic hotel decor. The staff was very helpful, and very easy to communicate with in English! In addition to these things, the hotel was both competitively priced, and very conveniently located near several train stations, and a short walk from downtown Ginza. We definitely want to stay here again on our next trip to Tokyo!The only confusion we had was that on the first night we accidentally walked to the Royal Park Hotel Tokyo, which is very close by, so just something to note when you're looking for it!

The best breakfast buffet that I had while in Japan! We also stayed on the Artist floor in a room with custom decor and an art exhibit and gallery on the floor. The hotel is right next to a subway and train station that can be accessed via underground passageway. The subway station is not on the best line, but with one transfer you can get to all of the popular sites and neighborhoods. The room was immaculate and the bed was comfortable. Room size was good. I would stay there again.

Located in the Shiodome Media Tower in Shimbashi, the Park Hotel offers very nice Western accommodations. The Artist floor is a must offering uniquely painted rooms by local artists. A welcome departure from your standard room decor. Artist floor also provided a separate concierge and complimentary breakfast coffee and danish. Service and hospitality is excellent. A lot of Western tourists. Convenient to JR and Tokyo Metro. A short 10 minute walk to the Tsukiji fish market, at least for now.

The hotel starts above the 30th floor which is a bit puzzling at first. Beautiful view and great location in area of Shiodome next to the famous Ghibli Clock. Easy to access trains and many restaurants close by. Nice bar and restaurant in the hotel and the rooms are pristinely clean and comfortable. There is a whole world above the traffic with gardens, shops and even sculptures. All the overpass walkways keep you very fit but also make for safe walking as you are above the traffic. Directions are confusing on maps as they always say take the crosswalk and turn but provide no street names. Despite this, walking was easy to many beautiful ancient temples, palaces and cool ultra modern streets. It is so safe for solo travellers I never worried, even at night. Everyone was always so courteous and polite, I would love to go back.

Our stay in the Park Hotel was outstanding. The hotel is located on the upper floors of an office tower, so it offers great views of the city. Service from the staff was excellent. The breakfast buffet was very good. While there are both Western and Japanese options, it seemed more Western than the breakfasts at other hotels on our trip. Rooms were on the small side, but noticeably larger than other hotels in Kyoto and Tokyo earlier in our trip. We had enough space to walk around in the room with both of our suitcases opened up on the floor, so honestly the smaller room size wasn't a big deal.

I am used to stay at this hotel when travelling on business in TokyoVery good solution, room comfortable and clean, not noize. Breakfast has a wonderful choice of food, good quality and comfortable environment.Staff is Always very kind.Super sunrise view at 4.30am !!!Area of improvement for me is the gym... very small and with limited machines...Overall a positive experienceAnother little aspect the step from room to toilet... not indicated... if you do not pay attention or simply are watching your mobile you risk...

My first trip to Tokyo was so memorable and the best apart about the trip was this hotel. It is my new favorite hotel and I am so glad we booked this gem. First off, the view from the lobby and rooms are insane. The staff is so friendly and welcoming. The concierge on our floor, Nozomi was the sweetest and most helpful and informative employee. She had so much patience with our questions and made recommendations and gave us directions throughout our stay. The location is awesome, the cleanliness was above average and I highly suggest to upgrade to an artist room. It is very much worth it. I hope to return to Tokyo in the summer and will definitely be staying here.

Outstanding views from these hotel rooms (the hotel is on floors 25-31 of an office tower); from some rooms Fuji is visible on clear days. The rooms are well-appointed and well-kept. We really enjoyed our three-day stay there.The hotel is accessible via underground walkways both to the Shiodome City Center, containing lots of inexpensive restaurants (and a couple of not-so-inexpensive ones on the top floor), and to the Shimbashi metro station. It's also walking distance to the Tsukiji fish marketA few things to keep in mind: first, the location is in a predominantly office building area. If you're interested in a livelier area, you should consider something elsewhere. Second, if you do stay here, note that the Royal Park Hotel is *right next door*, and taxis seem to preferentially deliver you there. So either be prepared to walk, or be very clear with the taxi driver. Finally, walking at surface level in this area is very confusing and difficult due to the elevated roads and train tracks that block crossings. Consider using the underground walkways or above-grade level pedestrian walkways.

We spent four nights at the Park Hotel Tokyo and have always felt very comfortable and safe. You can reach all known sights from this centrally located hotel on foot or by public transport.special:The hotel is located in Shiodome Tower from the 25th floor. The hotel has a triangular shape and has high atrium inside all floors.Location:Shimbashi Station and Metro Station are a 10-minute walk away. The Ginza is about 15 minutes on foot. The Hamamatsucho Bus Terminal is also 15 minutes away.Staff:The check in was very fast. Very friendly, attentive and helpful staff.Room:The rooms are really great and are always kept clean. You hardly hear the traffic on the street. The bathroom is rather small; but it is OK.Breakfast:In the hotel atrium on the 25th floor. There is a very pleasant atmosphere.The breakfast buffet is very varied, leaves nothing to be desired and tastes fine.We can only recommend the Park Hotel Tokyo; it will not disappoint.

We had the pleasure of staying at this hotel for 5 nights in an artists room (Mt. Fuji) lucky us - on the 31st floor. We actually got to see Mt. Fuji when the cloud lifted on two occasions. The room was very comfortable with good linen and everything we wanted and we enjoyed coming back to it each day after discovering Tokyo. The train station was close by and several attractions were within walking distance. The bonus of staying on the artists floor was the complimentary light breakfast and the end of day drinks. So good. The restaurant downstairs also was very good. The staff and especially the concierge were most helpful and pleasant.We would certainly stay at the Park when we next visit Tokyo and can highly recommend this hotel.

Great hotel, very happy with my stay. Excellent location as well, easily accessible to different parts of Tokyo. The hotel staffs are very friendly and helpful, managed to book a few great restaurants with their help.

The Park Hotel in Tokyo has an entire floor dedicated to hand designed art expression rooms. On my lengthy 23 day trip to Tokyo I saved this experience to the very end. Traveling solo I did not need a king sized bed so I opted for a queen size bed/room. I got the Cherry Blossom Room on the 31st floor! I love art and really appreciated the theme and this artists unique take on cherry blossoms. Nothing says transformation more than a butterfly!!! For this particular room, the westerly facing view was spectacular. Room had a partial view of the Tokyo Tower. At night, the view was even more amazing. Room had a window bench which was awesome!!! I must have sat and view the night sky for a few hours while enjoying some hot green tea. I found the room accommodations to be excellent for this class of hotel. The staff at the hotel were very kind and helpful even with my broken Japanese. Many people did speak enough English so we were able to communicate. The staff also made sure, with an envelop under my door, to note extra amenities that were occurring during my stay. This extra note, blew my mind, I mean this little extra touch was unexpected and raised my experience to a whole new level. The hotel did not want me to miss out on any part of what their hotel had to offer. As a result, I made every effort to experience every offering! I was lucky enough to stay during a open art gallery exhibit at the hotel which also enhanced my stay. I mean having a free art gallery in the same hotel was so incredible. I love art so this was super fun. I dined in 3 of the 5 restaurants and each had their own style and service. The "kaiseki" or traditional Japanese multi-course meal was the better meal I had at the hotel. Although, I also loved the Asian style buffet which offered Chinese style dumplings which I am a big fan. All the food was fresh enough which was expected for Japan and any hotel of this 4 star caliber. Don't hesitate to ask for the best food experience or recommendations. I did have better food on my trip outside of this hotel but that is not to say the food was terrible. I am just saying it was good just not over the top mind blowing. I did walk away from all of my dining experiences full and satisfied just not mind blown, I hope this makes sense. If you enjoy art and want a unique room and hotel experience then you should consider the Park Hotel Tokyo. When I return to Tokyo I WILL be staying at the Park again.

The room was small, there was no place to put our suitcases which made it difficult and when we checked in and turned our sheets over, they were dirty. We had to have the staff come and change all of our bedding. It was gross. Would not stay here again or recommend this.

We ended our 16 day trip around Japan with 2 nights at the Park Hotel Tokyo. The hotel lobby is located on the 25th floor, and the rooms go up to the 34th floor. Needless to say, the best views are on the higher floors. Book a Tokyo Tower view, but ask for a room that has the best view as not all views are equal - an office building has recently been built that partly blocked part of the Tokyo Tower view. I was not happy with the initial room I'd been allocated so I went to speak to reception who were wonderfully helpful and understanding and kindly showed me an alternative room. The situation could have been awkward but it was handled with kindness and professionalism.The room is a good size with air conditioning and safe. The bed was really comfortable too. I loved sitting in the window (daytime and evening time) watching the bustle of the trains, cars, and people down below. From the Hotel, you have direct access to the train line at Shiodome Station, and it's only a short walk to Shimbashi Station with several Lines (it can be confusing but once you've done it once, it's very easy)We took a short taxi ride (there are always taxis waiting out front) from the hotel to the Monorail Station to access Haneda Airport - you could walk if you don't have too much luggage. Overall it was a wonderful end to our Japanese adventure. We would definitely book to stay at the Park Hotel Tokyo again.

We stayed in tokyo for 3 nights and enjoyed our stay at the park hotel. The building itself was really nice and the breakfast was delisious. Especially for a buffet. The rooms were nice but simple and slightly tired particularly the bathroom. We were in one of the art rooms with was fun. All in all I would definatley recommend this hotel. But the rooms will need a spruce up fairly soon.

Park Hotel Tokyo is always a strong choice in Tokyo.Nice sized rooms with great views, great service and breakfast.Location in Shiodome is quite nice, a short walk away from shimbashi and all its restaurants.Overall, a high quality stay with reasonable prices.

We spent more than an hour traipsing around the subterranean world trying to locate the hotel. We found our way around Tokyo without difficulty and used the trains with ease but we found the combination of Walkways and different levels in this area quite confusing. Once we mastered this we could appreciate the location of the hotel. We had a great view of the Tokyo Tower and one night we saw the sun set over Mount Fuji from our room.

This hotel has the most pathetic gym -and you have to book a session (maximum time 40 minutes). There is no treadmill, just a bicycle and a step machine and a weight machine. The most ridiculous issue is that you cannot book two sessions in one day. That is just the rule and no one can tell you the reason for it! When I spoke to the manager, his English was extremely poor and he offered no explanation for the situation, just said "sorry for you".
user_name:
Sarah Gillian F... A
Cape Town Central, South Africa

review_body: Park Hotel proved an ideal choice for our Tokyo stay. Maybe not 5 star but very nice, more affordable, beautifully presented & clean rooms, amazing service & ideally located over a metro network, close to food options. If there was one aspect that I would have liked, is a bigger gym with more equipment options.

I am very happy overall with the Park Hotel Tokyo. I booked for a business trip, so I'm staying in a single room, their lowest category. The room is very comfortable -- it is small but not at all cramped, with a desk, seating area, and plenty of room near the bed. The bathroom is well equipped, and the public spaces are very pleasant.The service has also been excellent. I made a number of complicated restaurant reservations through the concierge before arriving, and they handled all of them flawlessly. The few requests I've made since arriving have been dealt with quickly.Overall I'd compare the hotel favorably to most of the nicer chains; not at the luxury level like Four Seasons or Mandarin Oriental, but it is better than most Westins, Pullmans, or Marriotts I've stayed at, to give a few examples. And the price, for Tokyo, is a terrific value, much less expensive than those chains. I would return without hesitation!

My wife and I chose this hotel for the Tokyo legs of our two week Japan tour. Well located by two metro stations (Shiodome and Shimbashi) which is important for getting around. The area has some reasonable restaurants nearby plus the usual family marts useful for those essentials when travelling. The breakfast was mostly western focused buffet style some nice pastries but coffee was filter out of a jug. Service was ok at the front desk and they organised taxis, restaurant reservations and the onward delivery of our luggage rather than taking it on the bullet train very efficiently. Rooms are a reasonable size with a large comfortable bed. The Wi-fi can be very variable in Tokyo so a good tip is to hire a portable Wi-fi router from Japan wireless. They deliver it to your hotel and bingo, permanent Wi-fi as you travel around Tokyo. We’ve rented it for our whole 2 week trip.

The Park Hotel Shiodome is a very good choice for a visit to Tokyo.  It's located in a good area right outside of Ginza. Easy walking distance to some great restaurants, shopping and the subway. The room was nice, and fairly large by Tokyo standards, with a great view of the city and the Tokyo Tower. Bed was comfortable and amenities were very good. The staff was very friendly, always offering advice and being very helpful. And a really good breakfast too!

Selected this hotel based on the reviews and photos of Tokyo Tower from Trip Advisor and was not disappointed. Paid for the Tokyo Tower view which I would recommend. The service from time of arrival to time of departure was great and staff made me feel welcomed. Views from the room was nice and relaxing. The location was great as it offered many options, multiple subway stations and walking distance to several sights like Ginza district. As previous TA posts suggested head for Exit 7 in the underground for the Subway for the Hotel exit. In the underground (Basement), there is a convenience store and easy access to the multiple subway stations. If you take the Pedestrian bridge (Floor 3 on Elevator) across the street, there is a few restaurants, Starbucks and Tulley's Coffee and English Pub as alternative to hotel restaurant. The hotel breakfast buffet would be my one negative comment, it was just ok, the offerings was minimum compared to other hotels I've stayed. Other recommendations would be to try the coffe shops, bars and restaurants near the train station along the track bridge which is about 5 minute walk. Arriving from NRT airport, took the Narita Express train to Tokyo Central, then took taxi to hotel, which cost about 170 JPY. Overall enjoyed the stay at this hotel and would recommend to others traveling to Tokyo.
user_name:
CodyDC
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Hotel has a good location near one of the main metro stations. Its a good base to for Tokyo sightseeing with plenty of tour guides meeting their clients there. Rooms - we had one of the artist rooms with launge access. They are lovely and very clean but pretty small. However, enough for a short stay.Launge has sone basic snacks and alcohol.Breakfast - very good quality, not a big choice to be honest but certainly sufficient with all western items and also traditional japanese food. Restaurant - not a big choice and very limited for vegetarians as everywhere in Japan but good quality and enough if you tired and want to stay in the hotel in the evening. Hotel also has a bar with quite an impressive choice of alcohol and great city views. Overall good choice and recommended.

Park hotel , just my favorite brand ! Not a surprise ! Big rooms super good breakfast buffet ! Nice design and super friendly staff ! I was suggested by friends and I’ll decently come back ! Thanks everyone .

Two families, (a total of 4 parents ad 4 young adults) travelling together spent 3 nights here for our Easter holiday/50th birthday-trip. We got adjacent rooms of a decent size and a great view of Tokyo city. 3 of us have stayed here before and the location is great. The hotel is on the Shiodome station of the Yurikamome line, and a short walk to the Shimbashi station of the Tokyo subway system and the JR Yamanote loop line.We got excellent assistance from the hotel concierge on several occasions. They were helpful booking restaurant tables for us (strongly adviced if you are a larger group like we were). Our 17 year old daughter injured her knee on the trip to Japan, and the concierge went out of their way lending us crutches and phoning ahead to find out if our next hotel in Osaka would have crutches. When this hotel didn’t they continued to make phonecalls to try and find crutches for sale in Tokyo. After about 20 phonecalls and a lot of internet searching they concluded that a doctor’s appointment was needed to buy crutches. Our travel insurance also suggested a visit to a doctor. Concierge was again very understanding and helpful and booked an appointment for us with an knee orthopaedic specialist. They also arranged for us to keep our room 3 extra hours on checkout day so we could stay in her room until the doctor’s appointment in the afternoon.Park hotel Tokyo was the perfect place to stay to see as much of Tokyo as possible in 3 days. We walked to the fish market, to Ginza and to the Hamarikyu garden, and had easy access to areas like Harajuju, Akihabara, Odaiba and Ueno by way of the monorail, subway and Yamanote. The friendly and helpful staff made us feel very welcome and offered support, good advice and a persistent helpful attitude when it came to our daughter’s painful knee condition.We will highly recommend Park hotel Tokyo and we will stay there again on a later occasion.

We arrived at this hotel on the 25th floor of the building wondering what to expect. Well, it had the wow factor. Wonderful greeting, staff couldn't do enough to make your stay enjoyable. The whole ambiance was relaxing. There was a calm about the building which we have never experienced before. The acoustics were incredible so you didn't hear any noise. It is certainly the place for a peaceful stay.Both the bedroom and bathroom were well equipped and everything was so neatly packaged and presented. The room is not large but adequate.Amazing views from the hotel rooms. We were on the top floor which was the 34th. On a good morning you can see Mount Fuji from the checkin desk.Food was very expensive but Tokyo is an expensive city.

We were looking for a Hotel in Tokyo after a 13 day cruise. We were looking for one that was close to shopping areas, near Haneda Airport, and walking ease from hotel to other areas.This hotel's lobby is on the 25th floor. We used coordinated transportation from the cruise port to the hotel Cost was 16,000yen. We had a private car to carry 4 large suite cases. Many taxis are not capable of handling this amount of luggage. This pricing from the hotel was reasonable. I check other sources, and having this booked to the room was easy so there was no monies exchanges. All charged to my credit card.......more points for me :):)Personnel was awaiting our arrival to the hotel and coordinate our luggage to the check in floor. Personnel were extremely friendly and spoke very good English. We were checking into the 30th floor - we reserved a Queen bed room with city view. Best decision made. At night with the lights out in the room, we could view the lights of the city with a glass of wine in our hands.The rooms are small. Just enough room to place on the floor 2 large suit cases. More or less the same size of a balcony cabin on a cruise ship. Bathroom has a very deep tub. Great water pressure and plenty of hot water. There is no shower spout. there is a hand held shower unit that hangs. Only item I found not favorable. The toilet has a warming unit plus other items to wash one self . Plenty of amenities plus extra razor, brush, tooth brush / paste, Room has a Frig and safe. Plus coffee / tea supplies. The hotel is walking distance to the luxury shopping area. In the basement you can get subway transportation to all areas in Tokyo. We took the train to the Asakusa area. Was 200 yen per person each way. Took 15 minutes. In addition there are eating areas approx 300 feet from the hotel exit door. Note many places do not open until 7:00 or till 7:30am in morning. Places open later on weekends. So coffee not available until 7:30am........including Big Mac. There are Family Stores for general items needed in case you forgot something plus other places for limited shopping.The hotel does have a western breakfast. Cost is around 2300 yen........while a breakfast Mac meal goes for 600-800yen.......Internet was great in the hotel.........no trouble using.We coordinate with the hotel for air port shuttle to Haneda - cost for 2 around 1800 yen. This was on a normal touring bus. Allow 4 hours from hotel - pick ups, etc, and getting to international terminal. Bus hits 2 other places prior to this terminal. We allowed 3 hrs and were lucky in checking in and by passed a long waiting line. We had just 45 minutes to get a small meal and a drink. If we had to wait in the long line we would have just made the plane.........Traffic to the airport can get very heavy so allow more time then expected...........Most taxi drivers do not speak English. Or very limited. So have printed data on where you want to go........We did find it interesting that there is no trash cans. You are expected to take your own trash with you for disposal. Also there is no smoking in shopping areas. There are fines. Streets are very clean.

Located in a good position close to Tokyo station and airport bus station but no restaurants around it. Rooms are beautiful and big, with confortable bed and really cleaned. No noise around. Buffet Breakfast is too expensive and with a reduced choice.There is no conciergery so it is not good for tourists because nobody speaks English and you cannot ask for information about the city.All people at the reception cannot speak English and it is unacceptable for a five stars business hotel. They have the attitude to help you but in the end they cannot help you because they cannot know how to explain anything. Those how know English have a small knowledge of the language even at their restaurants.

I booked a corner room with city view. High rise, the view from the room was very nice. Great breakfast, nice hotel. Rooms are not huge and bathroom was tiny, but ok for a few days stay. Room was very clean. Bad point is this curtain for the shower... why so many hotels still use curtains? Ugly and not convenient. Good location close to a train station, many restaurants in the area.

The hotel is very nice - the rooms as well as the lobby etc.. The view on Tokyo Tower is amazing. Early check-in was no problem at no surcharge. The prices are high, but normal for Tokyo. Would definitely go back there.

Located almost on top of the subway, The Park Hotel is a great place to stay if you can figure out the subway system. The service is excellent, the staff is friendly and helpful, especially the concierge. Most everyone I came in contact with spoke English.Several people wrote about the small rooms. I have heard people say what difference does it make because I am only going to sleep in the room. For me, feeling cramped in a small room dampens my vacation. The Park Hotel has larger rooms available. Instead of booking their standard room, I suggest moving up a notch to their deluxe rooms. They are larger and though a little more expensive, worth the extra money. If you look on the hotel's website, I think they tell you how big the rooms are.They have a Japanese restaurant, Hanasanshou. It's small so you might want to make a reservation. The fine dining experience is excellent. The food is wonderful, the service is great, and the view is exceptional. Ask for a window table when you reserve.Dollar for dollar, The Park Hotel is a good value. It is clean and well cared for. My wife and I really enjoyed our stay.

We stayed for three nights in this great hotel, and four days in Tokyo. We never needed a taxi (JR and subways within a five minutes walk), nor lunch (the breakfast buffet was astonishing good). The reception was professional, the room on the 27th floor very good. No critical remarks? Just one: the hotel has three restaurants but there is too little differentiation. All three are positioned on the high end of quality and pricing. No real problem, as there are many opportunities for a much cheaper local food-dinner in the tiny restaurants in (the vicinity of) the nearby JR/Subwaystation Shimbashi.

Right above the train station, great location. Talking distance to Tokyo Tower, awesome stuff, clean, friendly. They did stick a building in front of my tokyo tower view since the last time I was there.

Nice hotel with great staff and great views. Check in was quick and correct. Receptionist walked up with us to our room and showed us our room and gave tips about sightseeing. Staff is eager to help quickly and correct. Beds were comfortable and rooms were large for Tokyo. The views are fantastic!Breakfast was also good. Japanese breakfast was of great quality.

Hotel starts on 25th floor, so views are spectacular especially at night. Rooms very comfortable, and reasonable size. English speaking tv on some channels. Bathroom amenities catered for, shampoo, body lotion, tooth brush etc. Didn't eat there, too expensive for our budget. Walking distance to district that has the alleyways with little bars and restaurants, great food there. Train station right next door. Great hotel would recommend.

The room was nice and the view from th 34th floor was good too. The lobby is on the 25th floor. It is in a business district; no cafe after hours or weekend other then tje hotel cafiteria. The hotel is well maintained and clean, breakfast caters for Western food as well.Staff is friendly and courteous.

My husband and I stayed at the Park Hotel Tokyo for 4 nights from April 1 -5. The hotel is conveniently located near two subway/metro stops and the JR Yamanote Line (Shimbashi Station). If you have a JR Pass you will be using the JR Yamanote Line a lot to get around most places/tourist attractions in Tokyo. The Shimbashi station is a few stops from Tokyo Station which is also convenient if you need to get to Kyoto or the airport etc. The hotel is nice and clean, the rooms are tiny (it is Tokyo after all) - I believe we were in a City Queen Room which had nice views of the city. The room size didn't bother me given we were hardly in our room and just came there to sleep at night. The concierge was amazing and helped us secure a hard to reserve restaurant reservation. Nice impressive lobby, friendly staff, I would stay here again.

With the hundreds of choices, for our first trip to Japan we chose to stay four nights at the Park Hotel Tokyo. The location is really convenient- close to Ginza, the Tsukiji Market and the Hama-rikyu Gardens. Reasonably priced, clean and modern. The hotel provides, as do most in Japan, shampoos, rinses, shaving items, toothbrushes and toothpaste and hairdryers.Our room #3323 is a corner with 180* views - no Fuji-San though. Being American we were,at first, perplexed by the sophisticated toilet. (Though it could be dicey the Bellman should probably explain how to operate the controls ).The morning buffet is lavish and you may request anything you want. The hotel staff couldn’t have been more accommodating, although occasionally there was a slight communication difficulty.The only complaint- and this is throughout Japan is there are very few spaces - shelves, drawers, hooks to place clothing, suitcases or personal toiletry items. And there are no well lit mirrors for putting on makeup.

Stayed here as a couple for 4 nights. This is a great value hotel with good service, great views, good location (although the taxi driver did have trouble finding it initially). The arty rooms and the lobby art is great fun and makes for a different experience. We had dinner in the restaurant - exception steak - and breakfasts which were amazing. We also enjoyed a drink in the bar with the fantastic night views. Good sized rooms, good views.

Really nice hotel with small rooms and incredible views from our room. Service was good and the hotel is convenient to the subway system, but the immediate area is a bit business/industrial. Great value for a modern hotel close to good subway access.

We took the Skytrain and then JR line from Narita airport. It took us a while to locate the Park Hotel after walking from Shimbashi station as directed. The hotel is in a business district so it was busy with people leaving work as we arrived on Friday afternoon but we stayed for 3 nights and the surrounding area was very quiet and lacking in any atmosphere over the weekend. Our room was a little dated but spacious,clean and comfortable. Unfortunately we experienced some train noise from the nearby station, trains ran until early hours so our stay was not entirely restful. All of the staff that we encountered were welcoming and professional. Breakfast was very good, lots of Japanese and Western choices. There is a handy convenience store on the ground floor which is useful for supplies. Good transport links to the rest of Tokyo as Shiodome station is so close by but not too many dining or entertainment options around the hotel. Overall Park Hotel provided a good standard of accommodation but we would not stay in this area of Tokyo again.

My wife and I stayed in the Park Hotel for 6 nights. I read many of the reviews and agree with most of them. First, the hotel is located near the subway which is a major plus. But you should know that navigating your way is very difficult. My wife is a Japanese American and all I did was follow. If alone, I would still be in the subway trying to either get to where I wanted or get back to the Park. Now, back to the Park Hotel. I read many of the review and agree with most. It is an exceptional hotel for what you pay. But when people rate it 5 Stars, do not expect the same elegance you would get at a Four Seasons or other hotel whose name alone is sufficient to deserve a 5 Star rating. But at the Park, you can expect 5 Star service. Everyone was friendly, helpful, considerate, and did their best to accommodate us. The concierges were great. Most of the staff knew English and we always felt very comfortable. The Park is a really a wonderful compromise between the very pricy hotels and the very inexpensive ones. If we came back, we will stay here again.When on line and booking, check room sizes. They have smaller rooms and larger. We booked a deluxe room and were very happy. Remember, you get what you pay for and if upgrading only cost $30 or $40 a night, it is worth it. I am never happy with saying I will only sleep in the room so what difference does it make. When in the room, I want it to be comfortable. If you are not looking for the world, you should be, as we were, very happy when you choose the Park Hotel. Oh, their Japanese restaurant was absolutely marvelous and the prices are about 1/2 of what you will pay at other restaurants of this quality I other hotels. Make a reservation though. It is small and sometimes it’s full.

We stayed here five nights following a cruise. Customer service was excellent! We were greeted pleasantly each time we returned. Quick, efficient check-in and check-out They helped us decide where to visit; gave maps showing how to get there by subway, bus or on foot; wrote addresses in Japanese to give to cab drivers; waited with us on the ground floor for the airport shuttle we booked through them (excellent value). Beautiful city view from our 27th floor room that had good air conditioning. Paid to include breakfast buffet with our room, which made life easier. Able to access both train and subway lines with a few minutes of walking. Likewise many restaurants, mostly Asian of course, but also Subway, Taco Bell, McDonald’s, Italian, an English Pub and a NY chain called Bubby’s. I mention these because after three weeks in Asia, we were craving American comfort food for a change. Shopping close-by seemed to be largely convenience stores or pharmacies, as this is primarily a business area. Short walk to Hama-Rikyu Gardens, which were pretty even this early in spring; other than that, used subway and train to get around.

We spent 4 nights at the Park Hotel and loved it. Our room was comfortable with a great view. The hotel itself has all the amenities you would expect, including a good concierge and lots of English speaking staff. The location is also great, between two different metro stations. There is also numerous shopping centres within walking distance which gives you unlimited options for restaurants. All in all, this is a very good hotel and i would highly recommend it to everyone

Stayed here for two nights and we were lucky to be on the Art Floor where there is a small art gallery and each room is decorated with a Japanese art motif. The rooms were clean, not huge, but very comfortable and the views were phenomenal. Excellent, very attentive front desk staff who were only too happy to help. Breakfast was fresh, varied, delicious including a wide spread of fruit, proteins, and both Japanese and Western foods. We had dinner in the Japanese restaurant which was very reasonably priced. Food was delicious and well prepared and so convenient since we arrived tired in the early evening after a trans-Pacific flight.Easy walk to lovely quiet parks (Hama Rikyu) and the Tokyo Water Bus (located at the park) but also to the busy vibrant Ginza area and the very elegant Mitsukoshi dept store. Connected by tunnel to the railway station.

Stayed for w 3 day break, great staff, lovely rooms and excellent breakfast, nothing too much trouble for the staff. Only request perhaps complimentary water in room rather than charging from mini bar.

We had two days at the start of our holiday and two at the end in this hotel. Unfortunately a suitcase was damaged in transit from Kyoto and the staff were so caring and helpful in obtaining a refund for a new one and sorting everything out for us. We had an excellent room overlooking the water for our second stay.

This was my third trip to the Park Hotel Tokyo in 12 years, and the first with my son. I keep returning to this hotel because the rates are extremely reasonable and its proximity to the JR Shimbashi station. It's a business class hotel, not the Four Seasons or a Park Hyatt, but clean, contemporary, albeit a little sterileThe hotel and rooms are immaculate, as you would expect throughout Japan. I highly recommend the delicious breakfast buffet, with its combination of western and Japanese selections.

This is a good well run hotel in a good location. I had a fabulous view of Shimbashi station from my 29th floor room. A couple of notes: WIFI is not password protected, so bring your VPN. It did work well and was reasonably fast. Finding the hotel at street level is extremely challenging. If possible go downstairs into the Shiodome underpass and head towards exit 7-8 and you’ll get near the hotel entrance. There is good access to many subway lines, it will take you a day or so to figure out how to get in and out of the hotel. Easy walk to Tsukiji market, head for Turret Coffee for the best coffee I had in Japan. For informal dining, the Ginza is not really the best spot, but if you head along the train tracks towards Yurakucho, under the tracks are all kinds of good places at relatively reasonable prices.

This hotel is a stones through from a great restaurant/bar district and the Fish Markets. I thoroughly recommend the breakfast as it had a lot of choice. The rooms were well appointed and had wonderful views over Tokyo. Also handy was the underground train beneath the hotel.

Stayed here on our last night before departing Tokyo. Clean, comfortable, modern hotel with the lobby on the 25th floor. Ginza is within short walk and most major subway lines are easily accessed. Views at night are very nice.

We stayed five nights at the Park Hotel Tokyo and loved every minute! First of all, the rooms with a view of the Tokyo Tower are totally worth it! We picked up food and drinks to bring in several nights because our room had one of the best views in town. Why go anywhere else? The hotel itself is centrally located and easily accessible by metro and train. It's a short walk to Ginza and nearby gardens and a longer walk to Tokyo Tower and other great areas. The staff is welcoming and represents quite a few different countries. One final thing: the breakfast buffet in the morning, while pricey, kept us going until dinner. That, and our dinner "picnics" with our lovely view, meant we spent far less on food in Tokyo than we anticipated. Overall, a wonderful hotel experience! Highly recommended!

It was a great experience, service is amazing, rooms are classy and the restaurants are top! This hotel continues to deliver an extraordinary experience and the roof bar is simply stunning with live music and beautiful views. Location is out of the noise of central Tokyo and easy accessible. Japanese service remains unparalleled.

My husband and I absolutely love Tokyo! On our previous trips, we have stayed in Akihabara (my husband is a shameless tech nut, so loooooves the Electric Town), Kanda (for its proximity to Akihabara) and Shinjuku. On our most recent trip, we decided to stay in Ginza, and found a great combination airfare/hotel stay at the Park Hotel Tokyo. We thoroughly enjoyed our 13-night stay, and would definitely return to the hotel.  Room: We stayed in what I'm guessing was the cheapest of the rooms at the hotel. Billed simply as "Room" on Expedia, it had a queen bed, a soaking tub, a decent-sized cupboard, and a huge picture window with a window seat. We were on the 32nd floor, and looked over the surrounding buildings and a park, which, even in February, was filled with gorgeous flowers and a few early cherry and plum blossoms. Having stayed in a number of small rooms in Tokyo in the past, I was very pleasantly surprised by the size of the room. It didn't feel cramped or crowded, even with two tall adults, lots of shopping and a plethora of winter coats/hats/scarves etc hanging around. The room was also really quiet, which I appreciated in such a busy city. Location: The hotel was so handy for getting to Ginza on foot -- it was a 5-10 minute walk right into the centre of the shopping district. Shimbashi Station (which is filled with, and surrounded by lots of very reasonable little restaurants serving some seriously tasty food) was also really close, and easy to access via the underground passage between the station and the hotel -- that passage was a BIG plus on the colder nights of our stay. Staff: The staff spoke excellent English, were exquisitely polite and very helpful with answering questions about directions/local landmarks etc.
