Go for an Artist Room and ask for a room facing the Tokyo Tower for the best bang for your buck. This hotel is on top of a Tokyo skyscraper in the Shiodome district. Shimbashi JR Station and two other subway lines are accessible via raised walkways around the hotel or underground, without even having to go outside. I was impressed with the quality of service despite the reasonable room rates. Common areas are modern, sleek, and well-maintained. Standard (non artist) rooms are small and feature blond wood furniture and somewhat worn carpet. Queen size bed was comfortable and all necessary conveniences and amenities were available (there was even room to store my suitcase and some drawers for clothing). If you intend to spend any time shopping in Ginza this hotel is very conveniently located just a few minutes walk from the heart of the shopping district.

Hotel is in a great location for touring Tokyo. Staff are very helpful & welcoming. Rooms are comfortable with free wifi. Located above subway station so makes travelling around Tokyo very easy. Close to many restaurants in Shiodome City Tower & Caretta shiodome tower. All in all a great place to stay to see Tokyo.

Occupying Floors 25-34 of a skyscraper, this is an unobtrusively efficient hotel which offers excellent value for money. We stayed twice on our recent visit and especially recommend the Queen Artist rooms, which are individually decorated and offer access to a private lounge for rooms on the floor. This offers complimentary drinks and an excellent coffee/juice/croissant breakfast
user_location: Ashby de la Zouch, United Kingdom
user_name:
perrygrinate
Ashby de la Zouch, United Kingdom

review_body: The hotel building is connected with underground pass to Shimbashi and Shiodome station with 5 minutes walking time. There is a room with Tokyo Tower view option with amazing night view because the hotel itself is located between 25th to 34th Floor.

This hotel is only a ten minute walk from the Ginza shopping, but located in a quiet office area. It actually occupies the top floors, from the 25th, in an office building. The service is very friendly and efficient. The rooms are comfortable and well equipped, but a bit small. The views are very nice though. The breakfast buffet was good, but expensive if you do not have it included in your room rate. Overall, a good experience in a great location. I will happily stay here again.

My husband and I booked two nights here in March and thought the hotel was super lovely! Rooms were very comfortable and quite big for the usual in Japan. Based in what I thought was quite a businessy area - the hotel is close to tube/train stations and about a 5 minute walk from a huge choice of restaurants, by the railway bridge. The hotel is very modern, clean and sleek. The staff are super friendly and helpful too. We didn't dine at the hotel, only on the last night did we indulge in a dessert which was very nice. The only thing which was slightly annoying (but nothing serious!) is that you have to get a lift to the 25th floor, to then access another lift to take you to your room....nothing serious! There is a nice cafe downstairs on ground level which services food/drink breakfast etc...and a little bakery next to it which is nice too. Overall a great hotel which I would highly recommend and stay at again.

The hotel was a little hard to find on our first visit to Tokyo, but once we were there the greeting and hospitality were great throughout. There were three of us in an executive room and it was a little snug - I did enquire about moving to a larger room but was told this was the biggest, it would have been fine for two people. The breakfast was lovely a mixture of Japanese and Western food. We drank at the bar one night which had lovely views, a little on the expensive side for wine drinkers, but had a vast array of different Scotch. Overall a very good stay.

How did it take so long for me to discover Tokyo??? What an exciting city! And staying at the Park Hotel was really lovely. The staff are extremely friendly, and very helpfulThe room was a double room and not at all small, and you don't need to go to Tokyo Tower...just look out the windowI really liked the Park Hotel for these reasons and also that I could learn about Japanese art culture within the hotel walls, before venturing out to exploreIt's a strange concept to get used; the hotel being on top of a shopping centre/metro station/inside a commercial building...and kind of not being in walking distance of much, but once you understand the metro system, (use hyperdia.com to help you though) and take a taxi home when the weather is 2 degrees :-)...but I got to see all of what I wanted to see in Tokyo in 2 days while staying at the Park Hotel Tokyo. I will happily book there again

The staff are really friendly and views great (although skies in Tokyo are often white). The hotel has rooms featuring art which is great, tonight there was a visual of artwork being projected onto the wall with a data projector. The hotel can be hard to find by taxi, so make sure you bring a card from reception with the address on it. Let the taxi driver know that it is NOT the park royal, but it is the park hotel (they are nearby eachother)

hotel still seems all modern and new, like in the movie, but it is far and not a fun walk from Shinjuku stationgym is really cool with that pool, but has sense of "not being in the thick of it", buffet was as good as its counterpart in roppongi

Stayed here for 5 nights. The room was small but clean. The Tokyo Tower view was unfortunately partially obstructed by another building. Breakfast buffet was excellent although choice (especially for Japanese style) was limited. We asked for a late check-out but was told that the hourly charge was 1500 yen/hour.

We were really taken with this hotel! The price is very reasonable for this type of property. It's location is very convenient since it's located above the Shiodome station and a short walk to the Shimbashi station.You enter the lobby on the 25th floor, which is beautiful, glamorous and a little surprising. The staff members are all so gracious and kind. We were offered a small gift of complimentary, fancy fruit juices.We stayed on the 34th floor and the views of the media tower and surrounding city were magnificent! The room was so clean and fresh...very comfortable.We ate breakfast every day at the buffet, which offered so many healthy choices. We could have eaten somewhere cheaper on the street, but not nearly as good, so we ate heartily at the hotel and then had an early dinner out in town.There was also an art exhibition going on while we were there, but we only had time to see part of it.  We are planning to return to this hotel near the end of our tour of Japan. I'm looking forward to the encore stay!

The service was impeccable and the hotel had an impressive lobby filled with amazing art work.We were very impressed as we were upgraded to the corner Artist Room King (Dragon) which had a stunning view of the city including Tokyo tower!The complimentary breakfast with free evening drinks was a treat. It was tricky to locate the hotel and with heavy suitcases it was frustrating in trying to navigate our way to the entrance of the hotel due to the walkways and overpasses.This was our last stop in Japan so we thought we would treat ourselves. It was worth the expensive and it was a wonderful way to wind down.

Before I even talk about the stunning artist rooms or the delicious breakfast, I need to highlight just how stellar Park Hotel Tokyo's location is. You're so close to everything that you're almost spoiled for choice!Shimbashi Station has a dizzying array of food and bar options within walking distance, and the station is also your connection to Akihabara, Shinjuku, and much more.But the artist rooms! Just a fantastic experience. We stayed in both the Zodiac and Geisha Goldfish rooms are loved both. Rooms are spacious and comfortable with high speed WiFi.The artist rooms also include a delicious daily buffet breakfast and nightly wine in the lounge - both huge perks if you're on a budget and don't want to eat out.

Good to be around a number of main train stations and a quick walk to Ginza (ie. near Hamamatshucho and monorail to Haneda.) View hotel is modern and prices are attractive. The staff was friendly/helpful. I'd say that the room wasn't as clean as I expected in Japan. Lots of hairs over the bathroom and didn't look like it had been vacuumed before I checked in.

The Park Hotel has been so good to my boyfriend and I. We stayed here and rang in the New Year in this hotel and couldn't be happier. It is about 10 minutes from the Metro station. By staying here, you'll not only receive excellent service, great panoramic views of all of Tokyo and it's in a perfect location; nearby transportation, restaurants and shops.It was our anniversary and after we took an amazing but tiring ride from the Metro then taxi to this hotel. To our surprise, the staff welcomed us with champagne to our room. On the days that followed, we received great food and service at their restaurant, Hanasanshou and were treated to more bubbly during the New Year celebration. This hotel is full of surprises!Definitely recommend if you love the skyscraper type views of the city and looking to be centrally located Shimbashi-Minato area. Definitely recommend for couples!

Great location close to the train station with easy access to everywhere in Tokyo. The rooms are cool and with the upgrade to artist room you get complimentary continental breakfast, pastries toast tea coffee and a selection of juices. They also offer complimentary wine, gin and vodka selection in a cosy room with a great view of the city. The food in the restaurant was also good although a little pricey.

Stayed for 2 nights in early February - not to be confused with the nearby Royal Park Hotel. Great friendly service, and conveniently located next to the Shiodome subway line and Shimbashi railway station. About 15 minutes walk to the Tsukiji fish markets. Rooms not huge but enough space for 2 people to be comfortable, cool artwork. Great views from reception out to Mt Fuji and the cityscape from the rooms. Fabulous bakery (Tateru) on the lower floor. Highly recommended.

I have stayed in Tokyo numerous times and this by far was the best hotel yet. The view from the 34th floor was amazing with Tokyo Tower and Fuji in the background. Subway is at the bottom of the hotel which makes traveling easy. Tsukiji market is one stop away from hotel for tasty sushi breakfast or a 10 minute walk. Staff is super friendly and willing to help with any of your needs. I would absolutely stay here again and highly suggest this hotel.

This was our second stay at the Park Hotel. With all the hotels in Tokyo, why come back?The location alone could not be better. The underground passage was so welcome after walking the streets in the cold of late January, early February. The views are spectacular! We saw snow covered Mt Fuji every day we were staying. And the people who work at The Park Hotel are so friendly and helpful. We love it here and would certainly recommend this hotel to everyone, Thanks to the staff who helped us celebrate our wedding anniversary, it made our stay extra special.

Wanted to stay here for a long time to experience the amazing art inside the artist rooms but to my surprise this floor is actually a club floor with complimentary breakfast of pastries and coffee and evening drinks. It is well located to a train station but not many local eateries near by. The staff were incredible. All guest rooms are non smoking which is a bonus for Japan but they do have a very funky smoking room if it's needed.

My wife and I stayed 4 nights and I will go back if I am ever fortunate enough to visit Tokyo again! Everyone was very helpful to us English speaking travel’s. The view, location, service and room were all great and comparable rooms I researched were double the cost so the value for dollar is what puts this location over the top. If you want a nice place with an amazing view over Tokyo stay hear!

We stayed at the end of our honeymoon and were really happy with the hotel. It’s a very convenient location, the staff are superb meaning excellent service/hospitality, good breakfast, amazing views. Would highly recommend.

We stayed in the Park Hotel for 9 nights with our family of four (two small children). We really enjoyed it and I would definitely come back.At the top of a tower on floors 25-34 the views over the city are great. In particular Mount Fuji can be seen (on less hazy days) which looked beautiful with the sunset. Most days were too hazy but for a few days it just appeared looming so large in the background we were amazed we hadn't seen it before.The hotel is in easy walking distance of the Ginza district with upmarket shops, the imperial palace and a few gardens and temples. It is a few minutes by train from Tokyo station where many of the Shinkansen run from. The hotel is part of a large complex and initially finding it amongst the maze of walk ways and underground tunnels is quite hard - make sure you have the directions from the website if you arrive by train. You quickly get used to finding your way round. The complex is very well connected with both various underground lines and also the Japan Railway lines (our three year old loved that you could see Shinkansen every few minutes down below). There are numerous small places to get in the connected towers (there must be 20-30 different small restaurants). We went to a few of them and they were quite good and relatively inexpensive.The room we had was quite small which we understand is normal for Tokyo but it was clean and well maintained. The breakfast buffet was included in our rate, there was a good range of mainly western style food with some of the items rotating on a daily basis to give some variety. Unusually for an upmarket hotel there is a room with a couple of coin operated washing machines - very helpful for us as we could clean some of our baby clothes. I would stay here again if I was in Tokyo again.

The Park is a wonderfully located hotel with iconic views of the city. Like many hotels in Japan, the rooms are fairly small and basic, but perfectly comfortable. Being so close to the rail station and an elevator away from the metro is a huge plus. The Artist rooms are great fun, though it is luck of the draw which one you will get. The bar is very expensive, but you're paying for a view of the Tokyo skyline and it was an event to drink there. I would definitely stay again.

Park hotel allowed us to check in early, not just once but twice. They were very helpful with booking restaurants, concierge is prompt to give us updates and also was very helpful when we had a lot of changes made.Last but not least, I left my sneakers behind when I checked out. I emailed them about it, and they sent it out very promptly after I made payment for the courier services!Not to mentioned the great view, you can actually see Mount Fuji on a clear day!

Started off very well when kind staff made a room available early (I had come off an overnight flight) and let me work in the business centre until it was ready., It wasn't one of their "artist" rooms but it was painted in soft grey/blue hibiscus and clouds and very comfortable. The Atrium with its light show at night and pleasant place for sitting and lunching during the day was very attractive. The restaurants and whisky bar were great. Also the convenience store down in the basement and the easy access to subway and a short walk to Ginza shops were other pluses.

Beautiful hotel with great service, this is the second time I visit this hotel, this time we choose to stay at a designer room and it was just breathtaking. The breakfast buffet is super delicious and the hotel is located perfectly since you are just a few steps away from subway stations.Thank you Park Hotel!

This hotel is near the Shiodome Media Tower and a great location, if a bit corporate. The check in was easy and this hotel is definitely full service as my fellow travelers had lots of baggage to get up to the room. The staff immediately saw to it.Get the breakfast option if you want a luscious buffet of both Japanese and Western breakfast favorites in an unhurried, attentive atmosphere.The rooms are very spacious for Tokyo standards and have views out across the city. The rooms are well appointed and feel modern and comfortable with a luxurious bath experience. I spent 3 nights here and got plenty of sleep in a beautiful room which fortified me to take on Tokyo. It will do the same for you too. Great stay, great staff at a reasonable price.

I enjoyed this hotel because it was entirely located on the upper floors of the building and had great views of the Tokyo Tower. The room was very clean if a bit small, but the size is probably in line with other hotels in Tokyo. The staff was very efficient in checking me in and out, and they helped me retrieve things from my bags in storage. The price for breakfast was a bit steep at 2800 yen, but there are numerous outside breakfast options nearby and the food at the buffet was high quality. I would return to this hotel next time I am in Tokyo.

A lovely hotel with a great view of Tokyo. We stayed 3 adults in a room, and the pull-out sofa was not too comfortable. Rooms are clean and well stocked with bathroom supplies. Easy access to Shimbashi or Shiodome station and easy to walk to and explore the Ginza area. Would definitely stay again, however, not with 3 in a room.

Stayed here recently on recommendation from friends and it’s great. Central location, easy transport links being above a metro station and only a short walk to awesome Ginza shopping; and great service and helpful staff. Will definitely stay again.

My husband and I stayed here for 12 nights while exploring Tokyo. We had a queen city view room and it was perfect for two adults. The hotel's lobby and hallways are all decorated with curated, mixed medium art and there are projections each night on a huge wall in the lobby each evening. The view of the city from our room was great, looking south towards Odiaba. The furnishings in the room feel fairly modern and streamline. My only real complaint was that the mini fridge was the minibar so that limited our ability to store things in the fridge. Bathroom was spacious and we loved the heated mirror (doesn't fog up). The hotel sits directly above subway access (via Shimbashi or Shiodome station) as well as many restaurants and convenience stores. This made coming and going each day extraordinarily easy. The staff was very helpful at every point of contact. I loved coming back to such a beautiful place each evening after exploring the city all day. Would happily stay again.

This is a lovely place to stay and we would highly recommend. Staff are very helpful, rooms are lovely and clean, beautiful city view from room, breakfast is very nice with every choice you would want. The Park Hotel is within easy access to stations that take you anywhere you need to go. This hotel has a lovely atmosphere and it is a nice place to spend time in the lounge areas also.

We loved this hotel, which had a great view of Tokyo and even Mount Fuji early in the morning. The room was small but clean and the bed was comfortable. The staff were incredibly polite, friendly and nice. Breakfast was pretty good. We enjoyed the potato salad!

My boyfriend and I stayed here for 2 nights at the end of our trip and I’m so happy we booked this hotel. The view of the Tokyo tower with Mt Fuji in the back ground was absolutely incredible. It’s a little away from Shibuya, about 20 minutes on the train but it’s not too bad.

We loved our stay at the Park Hotel Tokyo. Had a beautiful room with a lovely view of Tokyo Tower -- especially pretty lit up at night!The hotel was extremely reasonable for Tokyo and it is more a five-star than a four-star hotel in our opinion. The rooms and service could not have been more top-notch. The breakfast buffet was lovely in the magnificent lobby area. Artwork everywhere.Convenient location: near Hama Rikyu Garden and Sumida River boat trip, Tsukiji Fish Market, and the Ginza (three places likely to be visited in Tokyo). Also, the hotel is in a complex with the metro; it was sometimes a bit complicated to find the right subway line and the way back to the hotel, but the hotel staff was very helpful in explaining how to accomplish this. Also, gave us information on a shuttle bus to the airport which saved the four of us who were traveling together about half of the cost of a taxi.

The Good: If you are flying in or out Haneda the Tokyo monorail is nearby. If you are a business person and have to work in the neighbourhood then this hotel may be ok. In my opinion for a tourist it is not a good option. My first room had a view of a rail yard, my second room had a good view.The Not So Good: The hotel is in the middle of a massive office complex with a ring of highway, rail, subway and monorail. To get around by foot you have to use a complex network of overpasses. It is impossible to easily walk around the area or figure out where you are. The signage to the hotel is poor. My first room was noisy from the trains, and I was on the 32nd floor. I asked to be moved which the front desk did without question. The second room was much quieter. The hall carpet was stained in many areas. The room was basic, furnished much like a generic Hilton or Hampton Inn. A small 21' TV rounded out the room (the remote did not work). The bathroom was clean and the shower consisted of a very basic hand held facet in an old fashion bathtub, The shower head was tiny, similar to what you would find in the clearance bin at Home Depot.Location: As I said for connections to HND it is good but you are a very limited, there are no restaurants or other retail, other than a Family Mart. The restaurants in the office complex were closed in the evening. There are restaurants in the hotel and nearby hotels but they tend to be costly. If you are using the subway use Exit 7.Summary: In my opinion there are much better options unless you need to be near the office complex.

This is an average hotel. It sells itself on having artwork in the rooms but you have to pay extra for these. The room we stayed in had a nice view and was in a reasonably good location, near the subway station. The room was small and a bit worn. It looked like it could do with a renovation. Nothing special about this hotel but the staff were nice. Good location for the business district but not for tourists.

This hotel is conveniently located near a JR station with an underground pedestrian walkway that leads to the basement entrance (it took several attempts to find it the first time). We stayed in the Bamboo room on the 31st (artist) floor and it was beautifully painted and cozy. The 31F displays artist exhibits as well. You have the option to request a specific room in advance (the Cherry Blossom room is an apparent favorite). The 31F lounge (only for people staying on 31F) offers a complimentary cocktail hour 8p-10p with wine/gin/vodka and also pastry/coffee/juice in the morning. We opted to eat at the buffet since we are early risers and the 31F lounge was not open. The buffet was a mediocre mix of western and Japanese foods, but with excellent and attentive service staff. For those who exercise, there is a small fitness room that can be reserved for 45 minutes by requesting at the front desk. Overall, we thoroughly enjoyed our stay and would absolutely recommend it to others.
user_name:
jennyu266
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: I’ve been staying at this hotel for about 15 years and it’s still the best. Once you get into the guest facilities it’s unique. The hotel offers the two ultimate luxuries in such a dense urban environment: space and serenity. Combine that with a wonderful swimming pool, and it’s a winner. The only negative is the location. Unless you’re doing business in Shinjuku, it’s pretty inconvenient. My solution is simply to spend a couple of days simply chilling within the hotel. Also, the Japanese restaurant was less than impressive, particularly for the $250+ my meal for one (drinking only beer) cost. Those things aside, I will look forward to returning.

Excellent jumping off point for virtually anywhere in Tokyo via Shinbashi station and other transport hubs within a couple of hundred metres. Hotel is super quiet, even sedate, which is nice after busy days and nights out in Tokyo. Staff are exceptionally kind and helpful. The price is unbelievably good for central Tokyo. Rooms are in good condition. Second stay (first was in 2011), will happily return.

As was the case with our visit last year, again the Park lived up to and exceeded our expectations. Again we stayed at the start of our trip and again at the end for one final night. Firstly, as we were going on the Sydney after and we wanted to travel around as lightly as possible, the hotel stored our luggage for the 2 weeks we were travelling- fantastic. On our last day in Japan, as a result of Qantas just cancelling our onward flight, we were given help and assistance by the concierge. All of this to me reflects on the quality of the operation here. Breakfasts are comprehensive and delicious, hotel location right by the metro and the glitzy Ginza and for Japan, very decent sized rooms. 5*****

We picked this place because of the great ratings, the great value (cheapest 4-star hotel we could find that's centrally located), and most of all, the great view. It did not disappoint.Location - it's a bit of a walk to the more well-connected Shimbashi station which takes you to Tokyo Station (Ginza line, Asakusa line) but it's not a boring one since you're walking through an underground mall. But it's also right on top of the Shiodome station, which sits on the Oedo line that and provides very quick access to the many attractions in Roppongi, Shibuya, etc. Family Mart in the same building, and just adjacent to a McDonalds and Taco Bell if you need fast food.View/rooms - To die for. I'll never forget falling asleep to a gorgeous, night lit Tokyo, and waking up to a sea of buildings bathed in golden sunrise and a great view of Mount Fuji. I only wished I spent more time in the room. Room was scrupulously clean, and I'm a clean freak.Service - Faultless. Despite the sheer volume of guests, you feel like you're getting one-to-one service. Able to help with last minute dinner reservations, booking of airport limousines, even bringing up a weighing scale to our room when we asked for one. Coin laundry always a plus, though you need to be quick to snatch one of the two machines available!Definitely returning on my next Tokyo trip.

We stayed in a Corner King view and arrived to see Tokyo Tower lit up and woke the next morning to see Mt Fuji. A good start to our first time in Tokyo. This view is also seen from reception. From the hotel you can get to Shiodome and Shimbashi train stations - both using underground walkways. Nearby there are plenty of restaurants and shops. The Fish Market is about a 15 minute walk and Ginza about the same. Breakfast had a good range of hot and cold items. Service at breakfast and at reception was of a high standard. This hotel was great value. Only reason I've given it only 5 stars is that the room was ready for new carpet etc.

The views from the lobby and our room were amazing and on a clear day you can see Mt. Fuji. The staff was extremely friendly (as is everyone in Japan!) and we enjoyed speaking with everyone that we met during our stay. The hotel is right next to a train station which makes it very simple to get around the city. We'd definitely stay here again on a future trip to Tokyo.

Had a great time at this hotel. They upgraded me to an artist room just because I asked and they had one available, and I had an amazing view of the city.It’s right next to (4 minute walk) to the Shimbashi station. So getting around Tokyo and all its neighborhoods is really really easy. And it’s walking distance to the fish market and Ginza.For first timers to Tokyo, I HIGHLY recommend it.

Location was great for rail access, worked well for Tokyo Big Sight convention centre as well as walking distance (just!) to Ginza, the fish market and an exciting (but a little seedy) part of town I'm not sure of the name of. Room was spacious enough, comfortable bed and nice window seating area. The hotel reception/atrium is very classy and the various artworks gave it real atmosphere. A word of warning about the Tokyo Tower view rooms- there is a large building under construction directly in front of the tower which seriously obscures the view from at least some of the 'tower view' rooms. From rm3006 you could only see about the top 1/3 of the tower. You may wish to consider this when paying extra for the view. Having said that, we had one clear day which we could (just) see Mt Fuji beyond the tower, which was great!The bakery on the ground floor has some wonderful sweet and savoury snacks for an affordable light breakfast on the run.

15 mins walk to Tsukiji and Ginza which was one of the reason why we decided to book this hotel. Another reason was that shuttle buses to/from Haneda Airport stopped over at the building. We took the last shuttle bus to Haneda for the last day that we enjoyed shopping at Ginza. They kept our big luggage in the back and brought down to the bus stop at the 1st floor for us 10 mins before the bus coming. He also passed them to the bus driver so we didn't need to worry about carrying the heavy bags around. I like the atmosphere that the hotel stuff created too. Their soft voice made us feel confortable.

We went here for our honey moon the city views are amazing you can see Mt. Fuji and the whole city. They even gave us some champagne to celebrate our marriage! The rooms are moderately sized, but comfortable enough for a couple.

Very accessible hotel from Shimbashi or Shiodome station. Used hotel as base from front and back end of trip so experienced both the Queen view and Corner King rooms. King has more spacious windows but otherwise Queen was certainly fine. Both were comfortable, good HVAC system, refrigerator/mini-bar. Bathroom fine not not at the same level of sophistication as the rest of the hotel property. Vending machine (soda and beer) along with ice on each floor, reasonably priced. A variety of convenience stores available in the basement shopping area. Note that only the elevator on the right goes directly to the Subway/basement floor. Great access via either the 3rd floor Pedway system or via the basement with direct connections to subway, rail, restaurants, and shops. If you are arriving by train, it's easiest to not go outside but follow the signs to Shiodome and look for a small entrance on the right before the end of the station for the Shiodome Media Tower.

The hotel is located in a central spot at Tokyo which makes it very practical if you are going for few days you can go everywhere in not so long distance, in walking distance you can get in the Metro Station. Breakfast has western and local food. Very good service and clean rooms.
user_name:
cordext
San Pedro Garza Garcia, Mexico

review_body: We stayed at this hotel for two nights recently and it was nice, but the rooms lack a wow factor. The hotel itself is outstanding, very unique design, sophisticated, wonderful staff, and great breakfast, but that level of elegance does not translate to the rooms. Our room, a Corner King Room with Tokyo Tower View, was very blah – a place to sleep and that’s about it. The view was nice, however, there is a large building being constructed that, upon completion, looks like it will eliminate the view of the Tokyo Tower. What really bothered us was the flooring in the room. It was heavily stained and looked like it should have been replaced years ago. All in all, if I find myself back in Tokyo I would certainly consider staying here again, I just hope the carpet situation is addressed. Also, be careful when checking in. When we first arrived, jet lagged, up for well over 24 hours, and lost in the bustle of Tokyo rush hour, we mistakenly tried to check into the Royal Park Hotel Tokyo which is in the same vicinity as the Park Hotel Tokyo….

Upon booking I requested the highest floor available, we had a corner king room on the 33rd floor and the views were spectacular. The sun sets behind the Tokyo tower and we had glorious views of Mt Fuji for 2 days.The bed was spacious, comfortable and the room was a reasonable size for Tokyo. The staff were outstanding and the entire check in process was very pleasant, our room wasn’t ready when we arrived but after going out for an explore, when we came back our bags were already waiting in our room. I will definitely return when I come back to Tokyo.

Nice rooms. Recommended artist rooms. Each room has a different theme. Has a lounge & photo gallery on same floor. Good location. Delicious food. Courteous staff. Enjoyed stay. Recommended booking in advance.

What a great stay. Fantastic service and super friendly. The hotel is really in a great location, within walking distance of Simbashi station. From Simbashi you can take the Yamanote line, which connects to many of the highlights in Tokyo.

We were very happy with this hotel. The location is excellent, within walking distance of the Ginza, Tsukiji Fish Market, and Hamarikyu Gardens and near a couple stations so that we could easily get everywhere else we wanted to go by train. Best of all are the fabulous views. We booked a corner king room which had floor to ceiling windows through which we had a panoramic view of the city including Tokyo Tower. The room was comfortable and plenty large for the two of us.
user_name:
PaminatorJ
New York City, New York

review_body: We stayed in Park Hotel Tokyo on 1-3 Dec'17, and had a room that overlooks to the Tokyo Tower. Very nice view, especially at night when the tower was lit-up. The room was spacious enough to accommodate 2 persons with a lot of amenities (Thann brand) in the washroom. The hotel also helped me in sending a document back home. Very good service. The hotel has a number of nice art works. Location is also good as it is just a walking distance from Shimbashi station (take Shiodome exit from station). Cannot comment on the food as we did not take meal plan.

We stayed at Park Hotel for our first visit to Tokyo. The view from our room was amazing - we chose a Tokyo Tower view room. Rooms were spacious enough & location very helpful. The basement is connected to train stations... just a short walk to sub-way and JR stations.The staff here was very helpful with anything we needed. They received our delayed check-in from the airlines.. guided us with sightseeing directions.. helped us get a medicine from the pharmacy nearby and printed a card that spelled out our vegetarian diet preferences in Japanese... to show at other restaurants etc.

The park hotel is in a smart buiness area of tokyo and very easy to get to. When we arrived the staff at the front desk were very friendly and welcoming. We had chose a queen room with tokyo tower view which was 100 percent worth it. We arrived late at night and as soon as wd opened the bedroom door we were amazed by the view. The room was clean , smart and cosy. Comfortable bed and all the amenities you would expect from a japanese hotel. We tried a cocktail in the whisky bar and can also recomend this , the bar tender was able to make any cocktail even if it wasnt on the menu. A bit of tokyo luxury to end our trip around Japan.
user_name:
CatherineF260
Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom

review_body: Of course, the views are great from the rooms so high in the tower. Our room was clean, comfortable. I especially enjoyed the art work not only on our room wall, but especially in the lobby, common area, and there was an exhibit going on. Lovely atmosphere with plants, lights, display. Service was excellent, helpful. Excellent location convenient to restaurants and attractions. On-site restaurant is a little pricey, but good.

This was probably one of the best hotels I have stayed at. I traveled with family and we stayed here for 2 nights. It is a bit on the pricier side, however, I feel it is justified with the location, rooms, sights of the city, and overall quality of the hotel. I would be pressed to find anything to complain about with this hotel. The top draw to the hotel I feel is the sight of the city it offers in the lobby and the convenience of its location. Everything you want is certainly in a walkable distance and the train station is a small walk away.

Slightly dated rooms but fantastic skyline views and very helpful staff. Could use a late night cocktail rooftop or similar and more room service options but strong location right in the thick of Tokyo and next to the high-end shopping districts of Ginza.

Stayed here over a business trip and it was conveniently located with many restaurant and shops around. Also well connected to major transport stations via the overhead and underground walkways. The hotel itself was located on a high floor and hence all rooms had great city views although some with views better than others. Staff were very friendly and polite with an ever willing to serve attitude. All had a good understanding of English which was great. Had an issue with the room pillow being too thin for me and the housekeeping staff were kind enough to provide me with a thicker Western style pillow. Also complained of the room feeling a little stuffy on the first night and they quickly sorted out an air filter to clear the air. Let down was the gym which was very small. Literally only a hotel room with 3 machines in it. They also imposed a 30 minute limit on each user and sessions had to be by prior arrangement. No hotel pool was available. Overall a good experience during a business trip and would recommend this hotel.

This hotel is very well situated. It is close/walkable to many attractions ( such as Ginza, Tsukiji Fish Market, Hamarikyu Gardens) and the rail system. The rooms are a bit on the small side but very well appointed and clean. Most of the staff have a good working knowledge of English and are very accommodating and helpful. There are several restaurants on site along with a fitness center. The Breakfast that is included is well done with offerings of Japanese or Western style.

The hotel is modern and new and staff are professional and friendly. I think it is one of the most special and artsy hotels I've stayed in Japan. The walls feature different local artists which I think is a fabulous idea. If you're having got a room with a view, go to the lobby ad you'll see a beautiful view of the Tokyo Tower. All the staff are helpful, unlike in some hotels where you always find one or two very nice staff only, even in Japan. Some may find it a bit far away from downtown but the hotel entrance is connected to a train station, so is still convenient.

This hotel is really nice. It's on the 25th floor with great views of the city and the staff is super helpful. The hotel made dinner reservations for us in addition to taking care of our airport limo bus transportation so we really had nothing to worry about. There is even a family mart at the basement for some quick things.

We loved our stay at the Park Hotel. Staff was very welcoming and hospitable. We enjoyed our room on the Art Floor each one has a different theme. You also get access to a lounge that offers a light breakfast in the morning and drinks in the evening when you stay on this floor. One draw back is the small bathroom and the hand held shower is a little awkward. Other than that this hotel connects to the Shimbashi Station and you can easily get to different places by subway.

From the moment we arrived and the manager pointed out that you could see Mt. Fuji through the windows behind reception to the time of checkout 4-days later this was one wonderful experience. We were given a room on the "art floor" which has it's own concierge and Edo-period art painted on the walls, each room different, each room original. Service was of the highest standard, room was well appointed, clean and had a nice view of Tokyo harbor. A real plus is that the hotel is situated over the Shiodome - Shimbashi subway station so easy to use Tokyo's fantastic rail system without hiking down the street. You are however taking a hike to get to Shimbashi, but it's all indoors. While I usually like to try new places, I plan on staying at Park Hotel Tokyo my next visit to Japan.

Park Hotel is a great place to stay in Tokyo. It is situated in the business district but do not let this put you off. It helps not being in a tourist area! The hotel is situated right next to Shiodome and Shimbashi stations which take you to most places in the city. We travelled by train to every destination in the day and night. The hotel itself is very modern and clean with extremely friendly staff. I would stay here again if I go back to Tokyo!

The hotel exhibits art in the reception lobby and in the rooms and gives you an extraordinary atmosphere. They have one floor with mural paints in the room walls for various famous contemporary painters. You can enjoy different themes and learn on the painter and the inspiration process to paint the wall rooms.

Nice room, good location. Plus point to have the limousine bus stop at the hotel, for easy access to Narita Airport. The reservation team are very helpful and it was easy communication via email & in person.

We kicked off our Japan trip with three nights at the Park Hotel. Conveniently located and on the top floors of a tower building, this hotel provided the perfect way to ease ourselves into the local culture. Our room had a great view of the city. It was clean and comfortable and included everything required for the holiday or business traveler including international power sockets and very good WiFi. The room service meal we had was pretty standard and the breakfast buffet was good. The staff were very helpful and most spoke enough English to communicate well. Overall, the Park Hotel provided great value accommodation that I can’t really fault. I would be happy to stay again on future trips.

We have been going to Japan for the past ten years and this was our fifth trip. We always stay in Park Hotel Tokyo. This hotel is clean, the beds are comfortable and the location is great. It is a little difficult to find if you have never been here but once you get it, its great. I love the area and I love this hotel. It will always be a part of our Japan trip.

We were made very welcome by the staff here, despite arriving hours before check-in time they were happy to allow us in to the room after our long flight. All the staff were friendly and helpful throughout our stay. The hotel location is great for visiting Tokyo. Enjoyed breakfast, but didn't try the hotel restaurants - there is plenty of choice nearby.

This hotel is not the easiest to find. But once you found it, it's worth it. The view from the room is fantastic. During breakfast, you may even be able to see Mt. Fuji if the weather is good. Limited facilities, but if you are sightseeing, you won't be in the hotel much.

This hotel has a good location with easy walks to train stations and the Ginza shopping district. The staff was great here, all very helpful and polite. The breakfast buffet was quite decent, with a variety of options for most international travelers. We were in two rooms during our stay: 3233 and 3333. Westerners should be aware that rooms are pretty small, with either two twin beds or one double bed. Room amenities were plentiful and always replenished. Overall, a clean, comfortable hotel.

The hotel is superb. The staff are kind and very efficient. The rooms are comfortable and the location is very convenient. Tokyo room view is breath taking. The service we had received was top notch. I recommend the hotel.

Stayed for one night on 29th March. Easy check in. Small room even from Japanese standards. All basic facilities available. View of multiples trains running from room window was great. One departmental store located beneath hotel which prove very helpful for foreign guest.Overall a comfortable stay,

It was very good , clean, quiet, with a great view!The staff were helpful and efficient.The breakfast was first class! The rooms weren’t very big but very comfortable. I would recommend it for a good place for transport or walking to parks - fish markets and Ginza of course!

As many have said it isn’t easy to find this place once you arrive from the nearby train station. Further complicated that there is also a Royal Park Hotel across the street. My advice from the train is don’t go down to street level. Stay on the overpass. Anyway we really enjoyed our two night stay. Quite an easy walk to the fish market (20 mins) and a lovely park where you can catch the river cruise. 10 minute walk to the start of the high end shopping street in Gion. Breakfast was truly excellent and on our last morning we had a view of Mount Fuji from our room. Fabulous!

Stayed for four nights to begin a 15-day Japan trip. The entrance to the hotel is somewhat convoluted if you are arriving by subway. Once you figure out that there is a nondescript door, a hallway and an elevator to reach reception. The check in process is flawless. Dinner and breakfast were very good as was the service in the restaurant on the main floor. The concierges were not at all helpful providing information on Tokyo compared to the rest of the five hotels I stayed in during my travels in Japan. The room was small but efficient with a good view albeit tired looking. For a hotel of this category, I was particularly surprised at the large stains on the carpet in the hallway. Did not find the stay memorable as compared to some of the other hotels on the route.

PLUS:- Very, very good location. It's beside Shiodome and Yurikamome stations and has underground connections to Shimbashi Station. Direct access to different subway lines. Walking distance to Tsukiji, Ginza and the eateries around Shimbashi Station. Hayao Miyazaki's Giant Clock is just across. - Easy access from any airport (Haneda and Narita). Can be reached by direct subway to and from both airports. Haneda Airport Limousine Bus stops at the G/F.- Comfortable room, good WiFi that's easy to connect to.- Accommodating and friendly staff- Very good choice for business travelersMINUS- Same breakfast choices everyday- Room size is a little small, given the price. But OK given the location.Lobby is on the 25th Floor. Not an issue, but actually gives the hotel more privacy.

Stayed here 3 nights, it was fine. Location was convenient in the sense that it is near the subway station, easy to go to other parts of Tokyo. However, we did not find ourselves doing much or eating in the neighborhood around the hotel. Took the Skyliner train from the airport that dropped us off directly at the station downstairs, without a need for a transfer.Room was small but nice. Views were pretty. However, our room had a musty body odor like smell, and if you are facing the Shimbashi station you may hear the rattling of the Yamanote and Shinkansen trains on the tracks below all night, as we did, even from the 30th floor. Nothing earplugs or jetlag can't overcome, but sensitive sleepers take heed.Staff was always helpful and spoke English.

We planned a 3 night stay, but from the necessity of arriving early to escape a hurricane back home we ended up staying 6 nights. The hotel was relatively full, and that necessitated us moving to three different rooms over those nights. While that sounds an unpleasant situation, the staff made it super easy. We simply zipped up our suitcases and left for the day. When we returned, we'd been moved to a new room. It also gave us the chance to experience different views from the hotel and the special 31st floor with its "artist rooms." We stayed in the Zodiac room. A playful design and it was fun to examine how the artist painted the theme. The rooms we stayed in were small (bed, desk, small table and chair, and a padded window sill for sitting) as expected for a downtown area, but clean and sufficient for two people. The views were so spectacular, we found ourselves turning off the lights at night just to look out at the city. Three of the days we ate downstairs at the breakfast buffet and it was more than adequate with both European and Japanese choices. We also had the hotel forward a piece of our luggage to another hotel later in our itinerary. Cost between $15-20 and arrived the next day. Not a bad option to save lugging it on the trains.The best part about the hotel was the location. We got up early and walked to the fish market. It was close to a great restaurant district, and near shopping and tourist sights. A major train station was a walk away along with the metro.

This hotel can be reached from the Shimbashi and Shiodome stations via tunnel. Hint: Look for Shiodome. If you have a JR pass you can go to Shimbashi and ride the Yamanote line which loops around the entire city. This will allow you to see most of the major sites using your JR pass. The hotel occupies the 25-34 floors of the Shiodome building. It has nice views of the city. Service is nice. Breakfast has a decent, if not spectacular buffet. The Japanese selection is rather modest. We also ate in the Languedoc French restaurant which was quite good. Languedoc has two other locations, in Ginza and Osaka, both of which are Michelin starred. Service was excellent. Apparently the hotel was remodeled 12 years ago. I think the rooms are due for a refresh. There are two laundry machines which are combination washer/dryer. It takes almost 2 hours for a load. They should have a couple more. Overall a nice mid level hotel.

Stayed recently with my wife for three nights before we started a cruise and found the hotel to be a fantastic choice. Located in the Shiodome area, it is walking distance to the Hamarikyu Gardens and the famous fish market, and a gentle stroll to Ginza. Perfect for everyone. Close to all the major subway lines so it is super easy to get wherever you want. I recommend it to anyone looking for that something special close to all the good spots in Tokyo.

I made my 5 nights reservations through agoda and it is likely the hotel does not sound accommodating at all. I am bringing my wife and my toddler to see the autumn foliage in Tokyo this November end. Due to my flight itinerary constraint, I have requested for the early check in to be able to get my little girl to rest after the 6 hours flight. I have been traveling frequently for business and leisure in Asia and the US which sometimes I did make the early check in request because of my morning arrival, fortunately all the times my requests were accommodated even in the US which Marriott I usually stay with. Since I asked for this special arrangement from Park Hotel Tokyo, I have told them I have a little girl on this trip with the early arrival at 7:45, so that I asked for their kind hospitality to accommodate my request. Unfortunately it is likely the hotel guest services are set up with a "robotic" response which I assume their new Japanese "hospitality technology" as I kept receiving the same response from different names despite what I have tried to explain my needs. Even worse than ever I have seen in my traveling life, I requested the hotel a baby cot for my 23 months old, the first response they told the cot sizes that the hotel can accommodate and asked for my baby age, the second email another robot came in and said the cot is not able to accommodate my 23 months old, so that I should share the bed with her because they won't hold any responsibility for any problem could happen??? I am writing this here in the hope that their manager will step in to take care of the customer requests instead of letting this " robotic technology" come along to ruin their hospitality.
user_name:
ClarkTran
Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam

review_body: I find much in common between my experience and the recent review by Linzerbairn. The location is fine - very close to Shimbashi railway station, and an easy underground connection to the Shiodome subway (no need to go outdoors). A short subway ride from Haneda, as well as a longer (but no changes required) subway ride to Narita. The rooms are on the small size (but that's to be expected in Japan). The furnishings were in good shape, the bed comfortable, the bathroom entirely adequate. $300 per night seemed excessive given that they then charged another 2800 yen for breakfast, and the buffet selection was modest (I have had better, for less, at several other Japanese hotels). I had wanted to get a breakfast-included rate, but none was available. Some guests seem to have been provided with breakfast vouchers but I don't know where they came from. The front desk staff is very nice and helpful, and their English is very good. Dining area staff at breakfast are OK (again, I've experienced better elsewhere).The odor problem that I experienced (same as reviewer Linzerbain) as far as I could tell came from the bathroom amenities provided. The brand name on all of them is "Aromatherapy", and they all have a scent similar to the sort of essential oils used in the practice of aroma therapy. In particular the scent seemed similar to ylang-ylang. Given that all the bath amenities are scented with this, it's not hard to imagine that over time the whole room has gotten permeated with the scent. I don't mind the scent when used occasionally, but having to breathe it continuously meant that after a while I felt somewhat queasy. Thereafter, as long as I was in the room, I felt unwell to queasy. By the third night, it was very unpleasant. Personally, I would book elsewhere. Last time I was in Tokyo I stayed at the Celestine, which was unfortunately full this time around, but I would rate that much higher than this hotel, despite Celestine's somewhat out-of-the-way location.

Pleasant stay at this hotel. Well located since it’s just above 2 metro stations direct connected to all the city! Rooms are comfortable clean and quiet ! Breakfast is amazing ! The Japanese restaurant is a little bit disappointing

We stayed here twice during our trip to japan for a total of five days. I would highly recommend it. We had excellent rooms both times on the side facing the tv tower which give really spectacular nighttime (especially) views. We were on 32nd and 33rd floors - the hotel is from 25-34 floors of the Shiodome media tower (reception and restaurants on 25). Staff were friendly and helpful, breakfast is good. The bar is a bit soulless and we didn’t try the restaurants (there’s a French and a Japanese). However the location is really good being on top of shiodome subway station (directly accessible from the hotel via elevator to basement level 2). It’s also about five minutes from the Shimbashi station with its access to the Yannanote line which you can use free with a JR pass. That is accessible from level 3 via a walkway above the traffic as is the Yurikamome transit to Odaiba. Taxis are available from level 1 and it’s 10 minutes or so to Roppongi. Easily walkable to Ginza, Yakitori alley and Shimbashi areas where there are innumerable eating and drinking opportunities. I would definitely stay there again.

The hotel was a short subway ride from Haneda airport. It was easy getting to the hotel from the subway as it was all connected from underground. Also, getting to the subway station was very convenient.Going to Asakusa/Ginza/Tsukiji fish market was easy with no transfers but definitely will recommend another hotel if you want to explore more of Harajuku/Shinjuku area. Also, we visited Hakone and it would have been more convenient and cheaper if we stayed in the Shinjuku area. (Paying extra 1000yen with free pass gets you a round trip from and to Hakone/Shinjuku.) We went to Hakone from Tokyo station and the price was around 4000yen round trip per person. Going to Shinjuku and then to Hakone took up too much time.Overall, the hotel itself was nice. Although the rooms were smaller than I expected, the view of the Tokyo Tower and the city was spectacular. Service was good. But I thought the breakfast lacked variety. It's always convenient to eat at the hotel for breakfast but I personally wouldn't really recommend it. I didn't think it was worth the price.

I really wanted this hotel to be perfect, having booked many months in advance to stay a few days in Tokyo prior to a cruising holiday around Japan. The location and the price level was perfect for me and I did look forward to staying here....but....Ill start with the good points. Firstly, the location was really good. Right beside the Shiodome metro station, close by to Shimbashi railway station, with other metro lines. It was only an easy 5 minute walk to the Ginza area. From the hotel, by using the comprehensive metro system you could easily visit any part of Tokyo. Getting to the hotel from the airport could not have been more simpler, with the airport / hotel (Airport Limousine Bus Co.) bus system dropping us off right at the door. Check in was easy and welcoming. Our room was on the 32nd floor and as soon as you got in you could immediatley smell a musty odour, almost a slightly sour body odour. I put this down to dampness as the weather was particularly humid. A de-oderizing spray left in the room helped and we thought that it would go away (more later).The room size itself was slightly smaller than expected though OK for the 3 days we were here. We had a Tokyo Tower view room and it was simply amazing at night. All amenities were available and the room itself, although slightly tired was clean and comfortable. As we were jet lagged and went straight to bed after dinner we woke to find the room still had the musty smell. After breakfast we complained and told that it would be sorted out by the time we came back. A full day in Tokyo beckoned.Breakfast itself was not cheap but was well prepared and plenty of it. The selection was a bit on the small side with both Japanese and Western styles catered for.Coming back to our room late at night we still noticed the body odour smell (night No2 of our stay. Another spray of the room helped alleviate the problem, but left a sour taste in our mouths (if you pardon the pun).Another plus point.... we asked the concierge to book us a table for a restaurant we wanted to visit and they sent us an e mail to confirm our reservation while we were out at the Sumo Wrestling. Great service Park Hotel !! Day 3 and the problem with the smell in our room still had not been resolved. Although not a "show stopper", this put a real negative aspect to our stay here.Wi-fi was good and the staff very helpful in making sure we got the right bus to our next destination. If it wasn't for the smell in our room I would have given this hotel 5 stars.Travel tip - buy a Suica card and use it for contactless payments on the transportation system. Just top it up as you need. It will save you buying a ticket for every trip.

Hotel is nice, looks good, friendly stuff.Rather small room.Everything is a bit too expensive for what it is, and the neighborhood, all large streets and skyscrapers, isn't too friendly either.Water in the room is way too expensive.Great view! Close to fish market.Overall a good experience, if you don't mind it being overpriced.

Room was nice and spacious with a great view over the city. Breakfast nice and western style. Location is ok: not in a hotspot of Ginza, more business type of area, but just a short walk from the nearest station and the lively area around Shimbashi Station. Staff is very professional and friendly and most speak English well.

So close to Shimbashi station and Shiodone. We used to just follow all signs to exits 7 and then take an elevator straight up to the hotel. When you first arrive/are looking for the hotel, make sure you know exact name as we had someone directing us to a different hotel with very similar name.The service at the hotel is impeccable. Great recommendations for restaurant and they even came out to tell our taxi driver where to go etc and provided umbrellas as it was drizzling. We did not dine in the hotel restaurants at all though as we were never up in time for breakfast and preferred to have local cuisine in town.We stayed in a queen room and the art on the wall was fantastic, as was the city view from our room. Great hotel and can't recommend highly enough.

We started our Japan trip with three nights in this hotel. It's ideally situated for metro and Japan Rail lines and it's also within walking distance of Ginza. The hotel itself is spotlessly clean, even if the rooms aren't huge. I'd definitely consider staying there again.

I returned to Tokyo and stayed at the Park Hotel again. I was in an artist room on the 31st floor, absolutely beautiful. The staff really know how to look after their guests, I can not fault my visit and can't wait to stay again.

We stayed for four nights and really enjoyed our stay. The staff were exceptionally helpful and we found the position close to the metro and train stations really convenient. The bar staff make excellent dry Martini's.

From the moment I arrived on the 25th floor for check in, I felt like a VIP. The checkin process was swift and accurate despite my inability to speak any Japanese and that I had made my reservation through TripAdvisor third-party site!Room is clean, modern and very functional. Bathroom is Spotless with fancy toilet with "all the features." Amenities are over the top with shave gear, toothbrush & paste , comb, brush and various other widgets. Nice!TV has several English channels that allow keeping up with world events for non-Japanese speaking folks.Fitness room is small and must be reserved in advance for a 45 minute workout window. Very functional.Elevators swift and on demand.Staff is excellent and very hospitable.Outstanding stay! I wish I could rate the property 4.5, because 4 is not high enough and 5 would be Ritz category...

The hotel staff was superb. From the time we arrived (my husband and I) throughout the days we were in Tokyo, our stay was always very comfortable. I can definitely say that Park Hotel Tokyo exceeded all our expectations. This place is truly memorable; with a fantastic location (train station within walking distance as well as great places to eat and shop). Overall we'll label PHT a TOP PLACE TO STAY we absolutely recommend it.

This hotel is very near Ginza in Shimbasi where various trains can be connected to. Its got great 360 views as it starts at the 30th floor and goes up for 10 floors - with a good view of the nearby Tokyo Tower.I stayed for a week delivering a work course and found the staff very friendly, comfy beds, room service, maid service etc. It also has a direct coach service to Narita and Haneda airports - very handy and there is always a taxi awaiting outside to jump in.What stops this hotel getting better from me is that my bathroom floor hadn't been swept and the room service food was of variable quality. Breakfast is not extortionate - and it can be in Tokyo - this is 2800 yen, about 18 gbp, not bad and it has good choices. My gripe is that its often lukewarm at best on the buffet and left me feeling queasy one day. Which is a shame as I really like this place. Looks great but the experience just doesn't get the excellent rating I think it should warrant .

I love this hotel. The Artist Rooms are very beautiful and are worth the extra money. If you're staying on the Artist Room floor, 31 i think, you have access to a kitchen area that is fully stocked with juice, coffee, wine, and a full martini set (alcohol included). The hotel staff is very friendly and welcoming. They spoke perfect English and arranged for the hotel shuttle to take us to the airport. I will stay at Park Hotel Tokyo each time I visit for at least 2 nights so i can experience a different Artist room.

The main reason we booked this hotel, like many others, was for the views of Tokyo tower. It did not disappoint. Coming back to that view after a day of navigating the busy streets of Tokyo, was a welcome relief. However, the main reason I rate the staff so highly is the staff. They were so helpful and friendly, making our stay in Tokyo stress free.

Stayed 2 separate occasions in Japan holiday trip. Staff very helpful and their service cannot be faulted. Room on first one night stay was standard and small but as only one night OK. Second stay was 3 night at end of trip - asked for larger room and offered a corner room for extra 2000Yen which was worth it. Guests a mixture of leisure and business.Walking distance to Ginza. Lots of places to eat close by. Close to shimbashi station for all rail and subway needs so perfectly situated to explore

This hotel starts on the 25th floor and is very beautiful! I loved the lobby, but when we got to our room, I found it smaller than what the pictures showed. Also, the room service was bad, so I had to either use their lobby restaurant or just wonder around and find a good place to eat.Other than that, the staff is kind and helpful. The hotel is close to Shinbashi Station, which makes getting around via train easy. The room was always clean. To summarize, our stay was really good, just a few flaws, but my girlfriend and I would probably stay here again.

The hotel is SO easy to get to from the train station, just a few minutes walk - look for the triangular building! The reception on the 25th floor has some amazing city views, and is actually several stories tall up the center of the building, and the staff are very helpful. We were able to leave our luggage at checkout in the morning and spend six hours exploring the city luggage free, then return to the hotel to pick up our bags and take the subway to Haneda terminals right out of the basement of the hotel. Rooms are smaller than American hotels, but are clean and tidy, Ann's all of them are exterior rooms with a wall to wall window looking over the city. Outlets are 2 prong (no grounding plug), but you can charge phones and such just fine. The bath is stocked with everything, including toothbrush, toothpaste, a shaving kit, shower cap, and the more usual shampoo/conditioner, soap, lotion.

I had stayed at The Park Hotel Tokyo for conferences years ago. I recalled it was a good hotel, convenient for the Yurikome Line to Tokyo Big Sight Conference Centre, comfortable, stylish and with excellent staff.Many years later I returned to find the same positive reviewsThe breakfasts are expensive but very good, one of the best caipirinhas in a bar outside of Brazil, friendly, efficient and responsive staffWe asked for a high level floor and ended up on the top 34th floor with superb city viewsNo noise, comfortable room fully equippedIt's Japan, the rooms are small but comfortable and lacking no amenitiesCheck in on 25th floor hotel extends up to 34th floorExcellent restaurants and breakfast lounge all on 25th floor. To my disappointment it seems there was also a hidden Whisky lounge tucked away that I did not see until the day we were departing Transport system interchange Shimbashi nearby It's a perfect review for Park Hotel Tokyo and such a satisfaction to come back 8-10 years after I was last here to find everything still top notchCongratulations to management and staff of Park Hotel Tokyo

Stayed at this hotel for 4 nights and were extremely happy with the hotel, room and especially the staff who couldn't have been more helpful. This hotel is ideally placed above the Shiodome Metro station although this can be hard to find. The first two days we ended up walking through the subterranean labyrinth that connects all the adjacent office towers to the Shimbasa metro station. It was only when we returned to the hotel on day two and got off at Shiodome that we realized where the entrance was. Restaurants of all kinds surround the hotel and can be easily reached by foot. The Excelsior Coffee Shop, adjacent to the hotel is great for a reasonably priced coffee and muffin/croissant in the morning.
user_name:
Michael L
Saint Sauveur des Monts, Canada

review_body: Stayed at the Park Hotel Tokyo for 6 days. The staff was friendly and went out of their way to be helpful and accommodating. Check-in was quick. The room was nice, functional, comfortable with a nice city view. The location was good - close to the subway connected by an underground passageway to the Metro and JR line. It is close to Ginza and Fish market. I travelled with my mom and we took a cab most times to the Tokyo station to catch the bullet trains ~Y1500 due to her being very tired. But for travelers that are able to handle the train and a 6 min walk - its a convenient location.

Stayed at The Park Hotel Tokyo for 4 nights. The staff were warm & welcoming & very helpful with directions & suggestions of what to see. The hotel has a superb location right beside 3 Metro Stations. Will definitely stay here again when traveling to Tokyo.

Location is fantastic (walking distance to Ginza, Hamarikyu gardens and Tsukiji Fish market) and breakfast is good, the rooms are just too small and the bathroom qualities could be definitely better. Make sure you request a Tokyo Tower view on your reservation because otherwise you will be missing a top view of the city. Worst part is that most rooms are smelly because of poor ventilation (we had ours changed and it didn't get much better)

We stayed for a couple of days in this lovely hotel nearby Shimbashi station, really well connected to all areas in Tokyo. Facilities are great and the staff is very helpful and kind, willing to give you advice and spend any time needed on it. Breakfast is nice although a bit pricy but the area is nice with quite a few places nearby for breakfast/dinner.The rooms are quite big even in basic rooms and comfort is top.We would come back again.

Stayed here on our first trip to Japan. Visited Tokyo, Kyoto, and Osaka, and thought this was by far our best hotel experience. Great location, convenient walking distance to subway and bus pickups for area tours. No difficulty getting here from Narita airport via train. Clean and friendly hotel.Very much enjoyed the cocktails downstairs. Skipped the breakfast to save a few dollars and instead picked up amazing hot pork buns every morning from the Family Mart on the lowest level of the business center next door.Walking distance to Tsukiji Fish Market and Hamarikyu Gardens/the Sumida Riverboats as well as many good neighborhoods for food.I did not think the room was small at all compared to many European hotels. We paid a tiny bit extra for a room with a view, and seeing glimpses of Mt Fuji with Tokyo Tower in the foreground morning and evening was beyond compare.I loved the tea offered in room and was disappointed to not be able to locate it in the other Japanese cities we visited.I wouldn't stay again, not because of the hotel quality, but because I would prefer to stay in a different part of the city next time I visit Tokyo, just to get a feel for the different neighborhoods. This is definitely a business area.

We stayed here during our last trip to Japan a few days ago. The hotel's location is great as you can arrive through Shimbashi station or if you come by metro or Yurikamome line you can get even easier there through Shiodome station. The hotel is very nice with a concept of art since the lounge where you find the Art Lounge which is the place where breakfast is served as well. The rooms are to the right size for Japan and if you are willing to pay some extra bucks you can get an amazing view of the Tokyo Tower. Breakfast was included with our reservation and it was limited but very good. It had both Western and Japanese options and very nice bakery options including e new matcha bread. I love the area of Shiodome because it is very lively and close to some of the main attractions in Tokyo which includes the Tsukiji Fish Market and the Hamarykyu Gardens as well. You can go down the elevator to the basement and in 5-7 minutes walking you are in Shimbashi station (through and underground walkway in case it is raining) where you can go to literally anywhere in Tokyo.
user_name:
juanjofloa
San Pedro Garza Garcia, Mexico

review_body: Wife and I stayed in 2 bursts 5 nights and 2 nights on this same holiday with Kyoto inbetween. Clean, neat, comfortable with small yet well equipped rooms...we did not have meals there however - the hotel could well do with enticing guests to stay and eat breakfast perhaps with a special discount as you register at the front desk.Hotel is in the Shiodome Tower (from the 25th floor upwards of a business building) and unfortunately is poorly sign posted for the first time visitor. There is no hotel name on the building at all!!We got off the train at Shimbashi station and then essentially were lost as the hotel access instructions were not clear at all (they should make sure that a map they hand out to guests on enquiry is on line so clients can ptint out before they arrive)..we were annoyed to lug our 4 bags (2 big and 2 small) through various corridors and stopped to ask at least 10 people along the way (most tried to help but poor english was a barrier - we then asked some Canadian at the Station and they gave us some idea of how to get there as they too stayed at the same hotel)

Just had a 2 week holiday in Japan, and this was our first hotel. We booked a city queen, the bed was harder than I'd have liked but later discovered this is std in Japan :). The room was nice and like all the hotels had a bath and we think the nicest soaps for the trip. Also drip coffee bags. The location is great your right next to the metro and not to far from a JR line. With lots of local food options as well. Would happily stay here again.

My hubski and I stayed just one night here while transiting through Tokyo. It was very easy to access from the Subway/Metro (we flew into Haneda), which meant great access to everything in the city. The rooms were equipped with five-star amenities, complete with bath products from the spa that smelled great! The service was impeccable, the linens were comfy, and the minibar was even reasonably priced. We would definitely stay here again. :))

Stayed here for 5 days in an artist room. Room was perfectly clean, nice wooden floor, must say a bit tiny for Europeans. Shower equipment and mini bar were well stuffed.Very friendly staff, English was understandable, service was excellent. The view is stunning when it's not cloudy. The smoking room is a bit tiny and was crowded sometimes. The restaurants food was very good, but has nothing to do with Japanese food. Hope this helps!Would definitely stanz again!

A few days in Tokyo was made really nice by this stay in Park Hotel. The reason why I chose this hotel is because of the location and the artistic come-on. First, location is just 20 mins from Haneda Airport. You can take the train from Haneda airport to Shimbashi via the Keikyo Airport Line. It costs around 570 JPY. Then you can walk to the hotel within 10 mins. You can also take the monorail from Haneda and alight at Hamamatsucho Station then take a taxi to the hotel. It will cost around 1400 JPY in total. On a daily basis, the train station is just 7 mins away by foot. Its very easy access to Yamamoto line. Around the hotel premises are shops and restaurants, family mart and plenty of spaces to lounge around i open air. The hotel is not easily visible so if you take a cab, you have to look well on the street as the hotel is actually in a building up on the 25th floor inside an office building. 2nd, for the rooms, I loved the fact that the rooms are design with wall art, Not all rooms but the art rooms are really a feast. Although we didn't get the room that we really like, the paintings on the wall offer a difference in the usual hotel stays. Staying in these privileged rooms allow one to have breakfast and refreshments in the lounge for free. IN the lobby, there are several art pieces on exhibit and for sale as well. Its truly a feast for the eyes. The Tokyo tower is just out there when you look through the window. On a lucky clear day, you ma even be able to spot the Mt Fuji just through the panes behind the reception. Overall, its a nice place to stay.

My fiancée and I thoroughly enjoyed our five-night stay at the Park Hotel in Tokyo. We booked a Corner King Room with a view of Tokyo Tower and we weren't disappointed.The views were spectacular, but most importantly everything else within the hotel was well worth checking out. We dined at Hanasanshou, had a drink in the whisky bar, bought some of the art on display and booked our airport shuttle back to Narita Airport. Everything was a pleasure at a mid-range price.We couldn't have asked for more from a restaurant in this price bracket and, having stayed in plenty of Tokyo hotels over the years, the Park Hotel is definitely worth checking out.

My husband and I have just spent 4 nights at the Park Hotel in Tokyo. The location was great for us - right next to Shiodome station and within a 5 min walk of Shimbashi (both JR line and subway), so extremely easy to take the subway everywhere we needed to. Do check out the hotel access page for information on how to walk to the hotel from Shimbashi station - you need to walk past exit 1C and onto the pedestrian walk way.Our room was on the 34th floor. It was small but perfectly functional. We had lovely views over Hamarijku gardens and the bay. You can see the Tokyo Tower from reception. There's loads of bakerys and restaurants nearby if you want to pick up a pastry and coffee in the morning. Walk to Tsukjuki fish market is about 15 mins. We were really happy with the hotel and it's location. It's probably not the place to stay if you want nightlife on your doorstep without having to get the subway anywhere but it's very easy to get back if you need to.

Staying at this artist room Mount Fuji is a very satisfying feeling, not only emotionally, intellectually and inspired me to be more creative. I love how the artist create and designed this room. My stay is worth it and I will comeback!

Stayed here in August for 5 nights. Booked a room on a higher floor, 34th i believe.The hotel in located halfway up a tower so you need to go to the 20th floor. staff are very helpful and friendly. Rooms are good, a touch small, but i believe this is normal for tokyo.The views of the city are absolutely fantastic and worth it just to wake up to the view. The rooms are a little outdated however, and could do with a new touch of paint, some dark patches on the ceilings and the bathrooms.Pros: nice hotel, good staff, few mins walk from shimbashi station which will get you to where u want to go, and a few mins walk from GinzaCons: a little outdated on the rooms, could do with a bit of sprucing up, breakfast is expensive for what it is, although convenient

A friendly hotel with clean, spacious (by Japanese standards) rooms. The staff are helpful and it's central location is ideal for visiting the local sites and restaurants. The Tsukiji fish market is nearby and well worth a visit.

I often do my best to find good views from my hotel rooms as I do a lot of city skyline photography. The Park Hotel was one of my best finds so far. As soon as you arrive in the lobby (25th floor of the building) you can already have a taste of what awaits in your rooms, a great view of Tokyo, featuring the Tokyo Tower.
