review_body: The hotel is excellent, perfectly placed in Ginza and very close to two metro stations, one of them the very big Shimbashi station.The rooms a lovely and perfectly clean, and the staff is helpfull, both during your stay, but also before arrival if you want to book tables at restaurants etc.All in all I highly recommend this hotel.

Park Hotel Tokyo is a hotel with a sense of style. First, you go up, up, up to the 25th floor to the lobby. Beautifully designed, it offers plants, artwork and comfortable seating areas, a splendid bar and restaurant and plenty to enjoy as you savor being in this magnificent, exciting city, We stayed on the art floor, a unique concept in the hotel business. Painters from throughout Japan have been commissioned to create a tableau in each room. It's a wonderful, creative idea. We wrote about it at whereiscookie, and can't say enough about the hotel's unique encouragement of local and regional artists. You can sleep with the fishes, dream with the stars, go back in Japanese history to shogun days, or take a fairy tale ride into Japanese myth. We stayed five nights, and wish it had been ten. Video images of the artwork are projected on the beautiful walls. The hotel hosts receptions and revolving art shows! Rooms look out over Tokyo's bustling streets and soothing parks. And you are staying a few days in a "painting" -- breathtaking. The breakfast, included in the room, is splendid, too, a wonderful blend of east-meets-west. You can have beautiful miso soup, pickles and veggies, smoked salmon or bacon and eggs with gorgeous fruit and healthy cereals, juices and breads. An elegant restaurant offers beautifully presented meals. The bar is welcoming and our bartender was Italian, perfect for an international gathering place. The Park also retains that commendable sense of style for which the Japanese culture is known. Bravo, Park Hotel. We eagerly anticipate our return, and hope other hotels follow suit with the art floor.

The hotel was very clean,staff very helpful and happy ,plenty of maps to help you around Tokyo ,service was of a very high standard,price for accommodation I thought very fair when you compare with other cities,rooms were a good size ,and cleaned every day ,we arrived early and they showed us to room so we could freshen up this is a big plus.

This was our final stay on a two week trip around Japan.Our previous stay in the city had not been in such a central location, so this was exciting. The lobby is on the 25th floor, with the room on floors above that. We were given an "art room" on the 31st floor, making it an even more special stay. The art took some getting used to, but it contrasted with the views over the modern city outside the room window.The taxi driver who brought us from Tokyo Station could not find it, and dropped us at the nearby Royal Park Hotel. But it was just a short walk here, and once checked in and inside our room, we loved the views over the modern city. It was incredible during the day, but at night was stunning.Breakfast at the hotel was good and plentiful, with Japanese and Western food.There is a well stocked bar on the 25th floor, and I enjoyed several whiskies late at night, sitting by the window looking out.A real "Lost in Translation" moment.Wonderful service, wonderful hotel, world class views.

This hotel located in central Tokyo had a lobby entrance on the 25th floor with stunning city views and stylish central gathering area.The service was impeccable, just as in the rest of Japan...ask and you shall receive almost instantly..a concierge that was highly informed and helpful.This may have been the smallest room of our 2 week stay but it sufficed and everything was comfortable. The location was perfect with shops, dining and a STARBUCKS just a short walk away via a pedestrian skywalk.We had 2 meals and drinks several times at the hotel and always good but really expensive so plan accordingly.

I had a few problems with this hotel. First, the rooms desperately needed updating. The furniture was old and the carpeting had stains on it. I felt like it was my grandmother's furniture. The beds were uncomfortable and the pillows were even more uncomfortable. I woke up every morning with a bad back.I got one of the bigger rooms and still I thought it wasn't as roomy as it could have been. I did have a nice view from my room though.The Concierge staff was terrible! They weren't very helpful and numerous times gave me incorrect information. The other problem was they didn't speak very good English. For that type of position, you would think a requirement would be an understanding of the English language since you have Americans, Australians, UK and others that speak English. Trying to get accurate information and suggestions, was so frustrating! There aren't restaurants or shopping really nearby; it's better to take a cab or public transportation.Breakfasts lacked. Limited selections and very, very few options for non Japanese guests. Very disappointing. I got stuck eating cereal every morning.There was free Wi-Fi but many times I couldn't connect or it took a while to connect. They need a better system.Although I used the subway all the time, if you do want a cab, one has to be called for you. On a positive note, the hotel was connected to the subway so that was convenient.Overall, I expected more from this hotel. I would advise finding another option.

Chose this hotel based on other great reviews and was not disappointed. The staff were extremely helpful, and the hotel facilities were very good. The hotel is in a great location, very central to transport, shops, restaurants and major sight seeing spots. We'll definitely use this hotel again.

Second time we stay here. The rooms are big for Japanese standard and very nice view, we got a room with so we could see Tokyo Tower that was great but liked the view last time as well with the park. Great location near Shimbashi and restaurants and shops nearby. The hotel launch restaurant is also were good. Friendly staff and great service.

Our five night stay at Park Hotel Tokyo was very pleasant, only marred slightly by a minor hiccup at checkout when the clerk stated the charges had been applied to my credit card, only to return home to find frantic emails from the hotel wanting credit card details to complete our checkout. A rare slip-up in Japanese efficiency.The hotel reception area is on the 25th floor of the Shiodome Media Tower which is fine and dandy except that the number of lifts is inadequate and they are quite slow. Once on the 25th, another lift needs to be caught to your room floor after a walk from one side of the floor to the other. Just makes for a slightly long winded access.The hotel building is a triangular prism shape, and given the central atrium space and height, rooms on any side have spectacular views.The nearby Shiodome and Shimbashi stations can be reached by a maze of underground walkways. The hotel does provide a walking map to help overcome initial confusion, but we found wandering around and following (sometimes) contradictory signage was the best guide. Luckily this is a new complex and all signs have English as well as Japanese information.Once outside the towers and stations, it was a 10 minute walk to the Tsukiji fish market and nearby gardens. This is a far better option than taking the train for just a stop or two, especially during the commuter rush hours. We opted not to eat in the hotel - there is an abundance of restaurants in the aforementioned areas. Our favourite breakfast of sushi was best enjoyed at the fish market.
user_name:
Peter G K
Cedar Creek, Australia

review_body: We chose a large room so had to pay a higher price, (could have had a cheaper one). Very nice view as this hotel starts on the 25th floor of the building. Also had the experience of an earthquake while we were here. Nice clean room and quiet. We did start off on a lower floor which was very noisy with trains but after moving to another room on the other side of building it was great. I wasn't impressed with the breakfast selection it does not contain much for westerners and I don't eat Japanese food for b/fast. Anyway I enjoyed what I had.

Was in Tokyo for business meetings and picked a hotel closest to our Tokyo office. Hotel was great - loved the rooms and amenities there. It was also great that it was on the Airport Limousine route which made it very convenient to get to and from airport. Being such a short visit, I wish there had been a shopping mall nearby as I limited time to get to the shopping. However I understand hotel is next to the train station which connects easily to shopping.

On a recent two-week tour of Japan, we spent our first 4 nights in this lovely property.Beyond its central location, the rooms were spacious and lovely, and the view of the city from our large window was extraordinary. Tokyo is first truly 21st century city we have seen in our wide travels, in terms of its architecture and design. The film "Lost in Translation" was filmed in large part at this hotel, which offers a choice of lovely restaurants for both casual and more formal dining. After a 14-hour nonstop flight from the eastern U.S., it's hard to imagine a more welcoming place to spend our first nights in Japan.

Third year staying here. The welcome and service has declined somewhat as have the breakfasts, but still a convenient location, and the public space and rooms are modern and comfortable. Compared to other hotels in Japan, however, the service, and helpfulness of the staff was a bit disappointing.

Stayed for 12 days as a base for our holiday and was amazed and delighted with the service. Every member of staff was so attentive and keen to provide the best possible service...the uk could learn a lot from these guys! Hotel room had a fabulous view of Tokyo tower, however be warned they are tight on space. Location is great once you get used to the layout of the high level pathway system around the shiodome area. 2 subway stations in close proximity means that you get around Tokyo quickly and easily. The only downside of the area is that it is a business district so not geared for up tourists, especially on a weekend. Food and restaurants in the hotel were superb. We dined several times in the Ty bis French restaurant and each time the meal was sublime. They managed to cope with my gluten free demands and remembered my allergy choices on each visit without having to remind them which was really appreciated. All staff speak English so there are no worries in that front. A great hotel with great staff, highly recommend

This hotel is 10m walk from Shimbashi station. Get directions from hotel website. Commuting is easy. If this is your 1st stop in Japan and you are taking the Narita Express, be aware that you need to change trains at Tokyo station with luggage. We did not pick the artist room. I'd recommend those rooms. The Tokyo tower view is fabulous. You may be able to see Mt Fuji too depending on weather. I had a good time looking at various arts displayed up in the hotel, smoking room, etc. It seems the hotel will convert all rooms into artist rooms gradually. I found our room had a bit of wear and tear. We had two issues once we checked in: bad smell in the bathroom and safe was not working. The hotel staff quickly fixed those. I was hoping they would offer us something for the small incovenience which they didn't (I did not bother asking). The person checking us out also apologized for those. So the staff was courteous. The convenience stores in basement are not open 11a-7p I think. We gots food from Starbucks and Sunkus convenience store (water, breakfast, etc.) on the way back from Shimbashi station. I could not find Fusen chewing gum anywhere else but I found it at Sunkus store. :)There was a small earthquake for few seconds and we could feel the vibrations. That was far out!Side note: I recommend learning a little Japanese. It goes a long way. I'd recommend learning how to greet, thank, and say time, count (1-10, 100s, 1000s) currency. Follow the "when in Japan" saying: Don't be loud on public transports and silence your phones, don't eat in public places, don't block others while walking, and don't tip as it is considered rude.

Central in Tokyo, the location is a dream. The hotel provides very well for it's customers answering any queries they have about the area and telling then the best way to get to places. The room was small but had the necessities you need and a great view. Park Hotel Tokyo offers it's guest a restaurant which serves delicious food which waiters who are extremely polite and very kind. The hotel is very easy to access being very close to big tram stations and you can get to many places by foot or using the monorail. Perfect location and comfortable stay with terrific view.

I found the Park Hotel Tokyo to be a really convenient and comfortable hotel. The rooms were extremely well kept and were a comparable size to any modern business hotel in any other country. Ive heard stories of very small compact rooms in Tokyo so I was pleasantly surprised by the size and quality of the hotel. The hotel is situated a short walk from the Shimbashi station and has a range of restaurants, bars and shops nearby. The staff are all professional and speak good English and check-in and check-out was seamless. The hotel also has some arrangement with an art exhibition and has some beautiful sculptures and art throughout the corridors and foyer. I didnt have an opportunity to try the food at the hotel; however, I would highly recommend this hotel for anyone staying in Tokyo.

First time in Tokyo and enjoyed my stay here. Took the bus from Narita airport. Staff greeted bus and helped us up to the lobby on the 25th floor. Staff were very attentive to me and my bag, since I was a little out of it after long flight from the US. They had both a Japanese and an "international" restaurant. Breakfast buffet at international restaurant was good. Also ate at both the Japanese and international restaurant for lunch and/or dinner. Both good. Close to subway and not too far from the park (opens at 9 am). Mostly a business district, but I enjoyed the location. About 2 hours by bus from Narita. Closer to Haneda (but the airport bus to Haneda does not run in the early morning. Had to take a cab as I got confused as to the subway line and started running late).

This hotel is hard to find from Shimbashi station, especially as it is easily confused with the Royal Park almost next door. The modern room is probably the smallest we had in Japan but adequate if you don't have large suitcases. The location is hard to beat on the Yamanote line which goes to many of the main tourist locations. There are also many inexpensive cafes and restaurants within a stones throw both within the Shiodome and Caretta complexes.

Located in the Shiodome neighbourhood, which both is far from busy tourist spots and has great public transportation connections. There are a couple of tourist focused restaurants and pubs (Italian/British) nearby but you'll also find two malls across the street with excellent restaurants frequented by the locals - whatever you crave, you'll find it there.Hotel staff were as accommodating and friendly as can be, and most of the receptionists spoke excellent English.Breakfast buffet consisted of both traditional Japanese and continental varieties. There are three restaurants, none of which I tried, and a bar on the lobby floor. Bar is small but cozy, which a nice view.I stayed in a standard twin bedroom with view of Tokyo Tower and Mount Fuji. Quite basic but comfortable. Minus point for stained carpet.

I had 30 hour layover in Tokyo, so I decided to make the most of it. I rented a room for one night. The Rooms:I have to say the rooms are very nicely decorated, with modern aesthetics and many of them have hand-painted art designs on their walls! The hotel commissioned local artists, so each one is unique. The View:Well, the views are just phenomenal! I was lucky enough to get one on the 29th floor overlooking the Tokyo Skytree, and when I entered into my room for the first time at dusk, it afforded one of the most picturesque views i've ever seen from a hotel room. The Location:Situated in the Shiodome Media Tower, within the Shiodome prefecture, the hotel is quite a perfect location for roaming the heart of the city. And the Tokyo Metro has a station almost literally below the building, so hopping on a subway and traveling to all the tourist sites is quick and easy. And if you are traveling on business, you are also in an ideal location for the central business and government centers.

Park Hotel is well situated within easy walking distance of subway and train stations, as well as numerous restaurants and small eating places. Friday night is very busy and quite tricky to find room in one of the many bars and restaurants. A vibrant atmosphere, totally non threatening and felt safe after dark. The only problem we had was communication. Not much evidence of English spoken in the local eateries. Best to go for ones with pictures of their dishes. The hotel staff are very respectful, polite and helpful. The breakfast is varied and more than adequate. Rooms are clean and well appointed...lots of toiletries, toothbrushes, razors, hairbrush etc. Train noise can be heard in some rooms, but, after a full day sightseeing sleep came easily

Well located next to a subway station and a very short walk to another main station. It is located closest to the Ginza area which is a more expensive area. I was happy with the location whilst it wasn't in the thick of things it was still easy to get to the other areas by subway or a good walk. The hotel is very clean, the rooms whilst they aren't huge on an international scale a big I would imagine on a Japanese scale. I have stayed in much smaller 5 star rooms. We had a room with a view and it was lovely. The hotel starts from the 25th floor so my only small gripe would be that you have to go to the 25th floor and then change elevators for your room. The room service is a very limited menu but there are a heap of restaurants connected via a walk way to the complex which are well priced as well as a mini mart down stairs.THe staff are excellent. I would stay again.

This hotel locating in Shiodome buiding which is business area and just 1 stop from Tsukiji-jo station, the nearest station from Tsukiji market. You can find two shops of Familymart that is very convenient. Beside I love THANN skincare in bathroom

hotel very comfortable big room and perfect location and easy underground walk to the subway line.hotel has a wonderful staff. in addition the bar area was lovely . also a really nice view can be seen from various windows in the hotel. lovely atrium as well.

We were staying in this hotel on 19th floor for 2 nights. The view was great! Room was clean and well maintened. It was a bit small for two of us, which was ok for a short stay.The toilet was al piece of technological art, as almost everywhere in Japan.Bath tab was a bit short for us, average size europeans. Location was the most important thing for us. The hotel is very close bot to Tokyo Fish Market and Hamarikyu Gardens.
user_name:
Lara V V
Los Angeles, California

review_body: Park Hotel Tokyo offers a lot of amenities for travelers, staff are courteous and accommodating, goes beyond the regular hotel service, accessible to a lot of Tokyo's tourist attractions. Ideal place to stay for travelersWill be going back and will highly recommend to friends and family

The Park Hotel is in a good business-oriented location. The building and the ones surrounding it are very modern and not as busy as other parts of Tokyo. This worked great for me as I don't like crowds but could still get anywhere I wanted to go because there are multiple Metro/Subway lines nearby, easily taking us anywhere we wanted to go. If you are flying into Haneda, you can get to this hotel without having to make any changes on the train.Check-in was easy and very friendly. As with most places in Japan, the service is quick, efficient, and extremely polite. The staff at the Park Hotel speak English well and communication was not a problem. I noticed a lot of American tour groups going in and out of the hotel so no worries here if you fear a language barrier. I upgraded to a corner twin room for about $20 USD a night and it had a side view of the Tokyo Tower. The rooms are all on high floors and I enjoyed the views and it was a great place to relax and soak in the city. It was so relaxing that we ordered room service one night versus going out. It was pricey but pretty good!The rooms are very simple and have everything you need. The corner twin was big enough for two people and the beds were comfortable enough. The selection of toiletries in the bathroom was impressive and there was doubles of everything. Things were replaced by the attentive housekeeping staff. And when you are in Japan....there's the toilets...the wonderful, amazing toilets! I wish I could have taken it home with me. If you've never been to Japan and experienced a Japanese style toilet, it will be a real treat.You are able to get a late check out for about $15 USD an hour (through 3 or 4pm). This came in handy as our flight didn't leave for LA until after midnight. One tip that the person who brought up my luggage gave us was invaluable. There is a Family Mart 24-hour convenience store on the B2 level of the building. We made several trips there during our stay. They have just about anything you need!The only complaint I have about the hotel is that I'm still dealing with a billing issue. I had pre-paid the entire hotel through American Express Travel. When checking out, instead of charging me the $150 I had spent throughout my stay, I was re-charged the entire room rate of $800 for three night. I'm sure it'll work out but annoying none the less. My only other minor gripe is the lobby. There is a GORGEOUS view of the Tokyo tower from the lobby, but it is obscured by the check-in desk. Why not move the registration desk somewhere and make the area by the windows a lobby bar/lounge so people can hang out and enjoy the view. The sitting areas in the lobby are oddly placed although they have uncomfortable furniture. Move the check-in desks and put some chairs by the window so people can enjoy the view. Add drink/food service and they'll make a lot of money! Overall, a great stay at the Park Hotel. I would stay here again simply for the location and easy transit access to the major Subway/Metro lines.

Tokyo is a big city but we found that there were numerous sites within walking distance from this hotel. In particular, the Tokyo Tower, World Trade Centre and even closer by, the famous fish market and the amazing pedestrian friendly Shiodome Sio-Site. You can actually get to the Shiodome site without going out to the street. The hotel is also accessible to the subway. Whilst Tokyo is extremely safe, as is their subway, it is a little bit isolating walking underground as far as the hotel if you were on your own (it is very well lit and very modern though). The entrance is via an elevator taking you to the 23rd (I think) floor where the very nice lobby is located. We paid for a Tokyo Tower view rooms which I think was worth it - nice to see the skyline, the tower and traffic etc. at night. Don't count on seeing Mt. Fuji as it is often clouded over. Room was a decent size, king bed, with a window seat and had lots of nice amenities. We sent several emails to the hotel prior to our arrival and they were extremely helpful and professional.

My wife and I absolutely loved this hotel. It occupies floors 25-34 of a skyscraper near the Ginza district, so when you arrive by elevator at the lobby you're greeted by an expansive view of Tokyo's city-scape. The view from our hotel room -- one of the fantasticly decorated "Artist Rooms" -- was wonderful, and we enjoyed sitting on the cushioned window ledge at night gazing at the city. The service was great, as to be expected at nice hotels in Japan. We especially liked the hotel's bar ("The Society"), with a wide selection of whiskys, wine, and cocktails. The hotel has a welcoming, modern feel to it. We hope to stay there again on our next visit to Tokyo.

I stayed 3 nights at the Park Hotel Tokyo in April and had a great experience. It is a modern and chic hotel with a very cool lobby and excellent service. It has an excellent location walking distance from the main street in Ginza and connected through a bridge to a shopping mall with restaurants and the Royal Park hotel. It has a metro station just below that connects you directly to Shibuya station and other important places. The rooms are small (almost all in Tokyo are) but with an amazing view! The hotel also has art exhibitions around the lobby and in some special rooms. Very worth it for the price/location. Would definitely stay here again, no second thoughts!

We enjoyed our stay at the hotel. Stayed in basic room overlooking the station. Occasional train noise nothing too drastic. The room was clean, comfy bed. Bathroom was clean and everything worked, however was on the small side with limited counter space. Hotel staff more than helpful and English speaking staff on hand to help you out if you only have basic tourist Japanese skills like us. Location for us was perfect. Take the lift down to the basement and the station is a short walk away. Easy to navigate and get about. There is a 7-11 just outside of the doors as well for supplies. We would stay at this hotel again due to convenience and cleanliness.

Not usually a lover of City,s being from the sticks..But I wished we had another 3 or 4 days here, So easy to get to 2 subways and my wife and I with large cases and backpack on...no hassel along the raised walkways...all under cover... Very impressed.Would have no trouble recommending this hotel.

We stayed in a City Queen Room with Tokyo Tower View - and the view was spectacular. The room was a little small, even by Tokyo standards, but fine for the 2 of us as we were only staying for 2 nights. Otherwise, a very comfortable room with a nice bed, and nice bathroom. Staff were very keen to help, the concierge could not do enough for us. English pretty well spoken throughout. Breakfast was fine, it was a buffet style with a decent choice of either Western or local food, served in the main reception area which is very light and airy, with interesting art and sculptures. Location was excellent, right next to various stations, and so it was very easy to get around the city. Guests at the hotel seemed to be of various nationalities and so there was a nice relaxed atmosphere. Do get a Tokyo Tower View room if you can, it will transform your stay at this hotel.

After a long flight from London and fully expecting to be told at 11AM that the room would not be ready until the check-in time of 3PM, we were delighted that room was available. We started by staying for 3 nights at the beginning and again at the end of the Japan trip for a further 2 nights. Both occasions we were on the 30th floor with confortable and fairly generous sized rooms with all the amenities you'll need. Our stays included complimentary breakfasts in the open plan restaurant area adjacent to front desk and elevators- very comprehensive choices here. Lovely friendly and helpful staff made this choice of hotel a joy to stay at. Brilliant location by Shimbashi and Shiodome stations, Ginza and Fish market a short walk away. Perfect.

Stayed with baby daughter and partner for two nights, they gave us a beautiful wooden cot for her but she slept with us in the huge bed, great view and beautiful reception with projection at night of Japanese arts projects, some of the room are decorated by artists. Lovely place where to go even if just for an aperitif. Definitely worthy a visit if you are in the neighbourhood. The area is very modern and very interesting tall buildings all around Shibuya, great places for food and wondering around.

The location is great, about 8 minute walk to thr JR Shimbassi Station, which is only 2 stops to Central Tokyo. We have been to Japan 8 times & have always stayed at the Park. Have never considered anywhere else.

It is not hard to get to the hotel from the JR/Metro Station Shimbashi. Just follow the signs or find a map. However, there is another Hotel nearby with almost the same name.Lobby of this hotel is located on the 23rd floor. You can take a lift from ground level or some a walking path on the 3rd floor.The lift will take you to the 23rd floor. Lobby is beautiful. Receptionists speak English very well comparing to many other hotels in Japan where I stayed at. Check-in takes 2 minutes and you are ready to be guided by a hotel service to your room. Room was about 20-24 sq. meters. Not too spacious - we had two big suitcases and it was hard to find a place to open them however it has a big window with a nice view which compensates the rest.Clean, well-managed, nice environment.The only problem was with old-fashioned bed covers like the ones that my grandparents used to have. I think without them it would be much better. Comfort of the sleep - unfortunately bed was not too comfortable. Free Wi-Fi was good and fast.

Four nights in "Dragon" themed "art room". Fantastic views over Tokyo Tower and glimpses of Mt Fuji beyond.Lovely service and comfortable room. Nothing too much trouble.Good bed and bathroom was fine.Very easy to travel from, monorail with walkway straight into hotel, and one stop in monorail takes you into great JR station with links from where you can get anywhere through the brilliant metro network.Just an easy walk to beautiful Hama-rikyn gardens.Definitely recommend.

We booked this hotel for its location. It really is brilliant. Easy to get to on the monorail from haneda airport and a ten minute walk.In good location for travelling around Tokyo. Train stations within a couple of minutes walk from hotel.Lovely room overlooking Tokyo tower which we paid extra for. Worth it for the views and of Mount Fuji when it was clear enough.We arrived early after and early morning landing from a flight from the UK. We didn't expect to get out room that early and knew check in was from mid afternoon. That said we were a little disappointed hotel offered nothing but a map and storing our luggage and told to come back later.Wasn't the best first impression after a long overnight flight. No offer of where toilets were where we could freshen up or would we like to pay and have breakfast (people were eating breakfast when we arrived) so we just left ur bags took the map and went and found our own way and somewhere to eat ourselves.During the stay we didn't have any assistance or offers of help from the hotel.The room was lovely, massive bed, nice bathroom with lots of amenities.Would stay here again for great location.

over all good but to expensive hotel increased the prices for individual travelers - due to the fact that more and more tourists are visiting Japan. The efforts in Art in the hotel are great - but do not excuse the high priced rooms decorated by artists

We booked a triple room and the room was lovely and still quite spacious. We had an amazing view that looked over towards Tokyo Skytree. Loved having the coffee machine in room and the bathroom, by Japanese standards, is large. Overall I would stay at this hotel again and again.

This was our first return to The Park Hotel since 2008. It still has the view and the location above Shiodome tube station, close to Shimbashi JR and the monorail to Odaiba. I noticed from the website, some of the rooms are being upgraded. The one we were in was in the process of being transformed but appeared care worn when we arrived. The staff at the desk weren't as welcoming as other places we stayed on this trip. I love the location of this hotel but will check the hotel photos and descriptions carefully before staying here on our next trip.

My wife and I started a short visit to Japan with a 3-night stay at this hotel which has its lobby on the 25th floor of the building.The hotel is conveniently located close to 2 stations - Shiodome and Shimbashi - which are within easy walking distance via either the elevated walkways (from the 3rd floor of the building) or the underground walkways (from the basement of the building). Almost all main visitors attractions in Tokyo can be reached using the JR Yamanote Line (green) from Shimbashi. This was a distinct benefit to us as first time visitors.We found the reception staff to be personable, knowledgeable, efficient, and anticipated our needs. They spoke good English and that was how we asked for directions to use the metro to visitors attractions, arranged to have our luggage forwarded to Kyoto or stored at the hotel, and confirmed transfer to Haneda Airport (incidentally, only 20 minutes by taxi).We consider the room we had on the 32nd floor as average to small but comfortable. It accommodated 2 open suitcases with enough space to sit and move around. Bathroom is small with adequate room for one person as that legendary Japanese institution (the heated toilet seat and accessories!) is centrally located. The room is spotlessly clean and facilities for making the British cuppa is provided. Our room faced the Shimbashi Station and it was fascinating watching the trains (local and Shinkansen) snaking their way through the station.The self-service breakfast is a mix of Japanese and western food and caters for most tastes. If you are early, you get seated in the dining room in the central atrium which goes from the 25th to the 34th floor. Otherwise, a side room with great views of the city is used.There is also a small convenience store (Family Mart), accessed via the basement, for everyday items you might have forgotten to pack.Generally, we found this hotel excellent and will most likely stay there again when we do return in the autumn now that the first trip has given us a very favourable taste of Japan.

My partner and I stayed at the Park Hotel in Tokyo for 5 nights.The location, close to Shimbashi, is fantastic, with a short tramride from Haneda airport, a short walk to and from Shimbashi station, and plenty to see and do close by.Tsukiji markets is a 15min walk, and gardens, imperial palace and the shopping district of Ginza is also a short walk.The best part of the stay was the hotel room view (Queen Tokyo Tower View) with was just incredible!There are vending machines with beer, and drinks for a decent price on each floor, but good and drinks options in the lobby are VERY expensive, $14 for a juice or a coffee, but luckily you can go to a cafe nearby (many options in Conrad building a few mins away).The bar 'The Society' does great cocktails also!The other amazing part was the concierge service, a days notice and they were able to book us into a michelin star restaurant, and went every extra mile, including luggage forwarding to kyoto, and holding luggage for us for 2 weeks (we will be ending our trip with an extra night at the end here (we changed our reservation for another hotel in Le Daiba as we preferred this area).What I will warn, this is the business man area, it is quite local centric, so if you are fancy or upper class, Ginza or Le Daiba may suit better, however for us...this was perfect, local places to eat and drink, close to the markets and a great hotel! We didn't come to Japan to be surrounded by American shops and restaurants!!Hope this helps anyone looking.

We stayed in this hotel for 5 nights at the start of our trip and then again on our final night. We were on the 29th floor first time with a fantastic view, clean room with loads of bathroom toiletries. The rooms aren't big but are big enough as we had 3 cases and we managed OK. On our final night we stayed on the 31st floor in an artist room on a different side where the view was great again, especially Tokyo tower at night. The room decoration extended to every wall and ceiling including the bathroom and was great fun. Breakfast was an extensive buffet covering Asian, American and Continental options. Sometimes we were in the central area with it's full height atrium and sometimes in a side room with a view.The hotel is directly above the Shiodome underground station which also includes a stop on the monorail going out to Odaiba Island which is a fun way to spend an hour or so. It is also within 3 minutes walk of Shimbashi underground and overground station via some attractive walkways. At the moment you can also walk to Tsukiji fish market in about 5 minutes from there (although the market is moving soon).The staff were very attentive and helpful at all times. I would definitely recommend this hotel and would stay there again.

The experience we had was not as pleasant especially with the counter. The personnels we encountered were not service orientated. We also noticed that newspapers are chargeable. We were even asked to pay for stamp for a postcard. The body shampoo provided did not clean at all. Overall it was a let down.

Well located near the Ginza district with easy access to two subway stations. Staff are very friendly and eager to offer advice. The breakfast buffets has a decent variety of both Japanese and western choices. Rooms are small. Views are great.

We stayed for 7 days as the home base of our first trip to Japan. The staff was always friendly and helpful as needed. The cafe food was solid and the in-house bar, The Society, was great for a whiskey/whisky consumer when we were too tired to venture out at night. Their nightly "art shows" projected on the 9-story wall was cool, and they hosted several events in the lobby area throughout the week as well--art exhibit, concerts, etc. It's centrally located, right at the Shimbashi Station/Shiodome Station, making it easy to jump on the monorail/JR line/subway to explore Tokyo. The majority of the staff spoke English well enough to provide great service throughout the week. My only gripe is with the king-size bed that was in our room--it was two twin beds pushed together, so the middle had an uncomfortable "spine" that made it uncomfortable to lay on/across.

We stayed there for 4 nights, the first two nights we had a room facing Tokyo Tower, at the 26th floor, the view was breathtaking.The room size was good, and very clean. Plenty of amenities too.The stuff was great, very welcoming and helpfull. Special mention to the night shift who helped me get a softer pillow as I find pillows in Japan to be extremely uncomfortable and hard. I will come back!

This hotel was very comfortable, the staff were friendly and obliging, and it's got the perfect location for sight seeing. It's writhing walking distance to the subway and on a good day you can see Mt Fuji from the lobby.

I stayed at the Park Hotel for business last week for three nights. They are courteous, clean, and the elevation of the hotel means its above most of the street noise and gives great views. I would stay there again.

We had a wonderful stay, the room was very comfortable, the service was great and the location (near the subway) was very helpful. The only thing I would change is the fitness room that should be a bit more functional.

I was charged 1,500 Yen for one hour late check out after staying for four nights. The hotel should be more flexible with the late check out especially for someone who had stayed for more than one night.

This place has the nicest accommodations. The staff here is friendly, courteous and always willing to lend a hand. We had stayed here a year before, and were so impressed, we absolutely had to return. We were in the queen room with a Tokyo Tower view, and I must say, it's worth it. The hotel staff kept the room clean and orderly. The breakfast is fantastic, with many healthy options.The location is excellent, located near Shimbashi and Shiodome stations, and not far from places like Akihabara, Ginza, Rappongi, and Odaiba. The underground portion that leads to Shimbashi Station has at least 3 Family Marts, a 7-Eleven, and 2 7-Eleven international ATMs, and a ton of great food options, including cozy and delicious restaurants frequented by locals.I highly recommend this hotel for future stays to Tokyo.

We thoroughly enjoyed our stay at the Park Hotel Tokyo. Although the rooms are small, the room was spotless and in excellent condition. There is an excellent selection of amenities and toilet accessories and complimentary tea and coffee. The staff were fabulous and went out of their way to assist you with any query you had. We were on the 34th floor (top floor) and had beautiful views of the harbor. Accommodation is expensive in Tokyo and we found this very good value compared to what was on offer elsewhere. If you don't mind a small room, this place is ideal. It is also very accessible to the metro and JR rail lines, plus loads of local restaurants to explore in the streets nearby. The Airport bus service collects you from the hotel. Would be more than happy to stay there again.

Nice size room and bathroom. We took the city view room and had a great view of Tokyo, especially at night. The lobby is on the 25th floor so you take one elevator to the lobby and then a different one to your floor. Very helpful staff. English is spoken very well at this hotel. Very close to the metro station. This hotel can be reached by both Tokyo airports with the airport limousine bus which is a plus. Also the hotels website is very easy to use and very informative.

Highly recommend to anyone to stay at this hotel. Beautiful interior and friendly and helpful staff. Close to the shops, restaurant and Tsukiji market. Make sure to book a view of Mount Fuji. Would love to give 4.5/5.

It is my another visit of Tokyo and another 5 days in the hotel. There were no doubts where to stay - all i wrote in my previous review is in force. Just one episode: i arrived much ealier than official check-in time and the room wasn't ready, so I went for the morning coffee and pleasant walk around (Ginza is just 5 min walking distance) - when, couple of hours later I came to the hotel to take something from my staff, I was informed the the room is already waiting for me and my staff is inside. All this without any extra charge! So, it is not just a hotel which is perfectly located, clean and quiet , but with the face to the traveler - this is an important point really differentiation this hotel form many others. Recommended !!!

Well lets say for 299 Euros per night I expected more. I got a queen size room on the 29th floor with a view of the Tokyo Tower. The view of the Tower was nice but that is about it. Because I was a ´corporate client' I got one bottle of free water per day. Breakfast was not included in the price. The room is small and you have to shower in the bath which has a plastic curtain. The carpets are ragged at the edges and in my opinion the room are in a state of neglect. The railway tracks are directly beside the hotel and below my window so the room were therefore very noisy. Positives...the staff were friendly and WiFi free in the rooms and lobby which is situated on the 25th floor. Complimentary coffee and tea in the rooms. The hotel is next to a train station and within walking distance from some nice bars and restaurants. The Narita and Haneda airport shuttle bus stops right in front of the hotel and a ticket to Narita costs 3100 Yen.

One of the best stay in Tokyo after all. The hotel room is such a piece of art and the lobby itself is fab!!!! View from 25th floor that can see Tokyo tower was magnificent.The sky walk from the hotel through ginza shopping street is the best! easy walk with traffic worry-free!

One of the best stay I have made to Tokyo recently. The view from lobby is fabulous! the connecting bridge was easy access and get me close to ginza without crossing so many streets. The room is more than just fine :)

Central location with great city and Tokyo tower view. Many areas to eat local or western cuisine. Small clean and spacious rooms better than many other hotels can offer. Local and western breakfast with a coffee shop for confectionery enthusiast. Slightly expensive but Tokyo it's hard to get a cheap place with such ambience and service. Overall recommended for business Travellers.

We were completely in love with our stay here. We purposely picked the queen room with Tokyo tower view and thanks god that we did. It was quite an experience, nice room, well equipped with a spectacular view. Location is quite convenient as it's within walking distance to two subway stations. Breakfast was great with a mix of continental and Japanese style breakfast, a bit expensive but food in Tokyo is quite pricey in general. Hence, for the convenience in the morning before heading out to explore the city, I would definitely pay for it. Highly recommend and I will definitely come back if I have a chance.

With rooms on floors 26-34 this hotel provides spectacular views of this skyscraper city. Service is excellent throughout with knowledgable staff to help you navigate the city. Located in the Shuidome centre there are restaurants and shops in the complex and lots of local flavour outside it.

This was our second stay at the Park Hotel Tokyo. Everything was perfect and the people there really friendly and helpful. Will come back again. We took a Tokyo Tower room view and got the chance to see the Mont FUJI due to excellent weather conditions.

Solid Hotel, Nice location, cant beat the lobby on the 25th Floor! Rooms very clean, small, but lovely views. Bit Pricey for amenities. Staff very friendly and always smiling. Breakfast was very nice each morning with combo Western and Japaneses selections.

We chose this hotel as our base of operations during our six nights in Tokyo.I originally chose this hotel after reading that Shiodome was a convenient and pleasant area of Tokyo to stay in. I had been planning our Japan trip for about a year and I was able to book our room at the hotel six months before our stay via the hotel website. This is quite significant if you are planning a trip so far in advance. Since we were booking in the very busy cherry blossom season, I was unable to find many hotels that would let you book so far out. After booking the hotel and even before arriving in Japan, I had been in contact with the hotel concierge about three months prior to our stay. I tried calling the hotel at first but then was directed to just communicate through email (which made things much easier). The concierge was able to book several dinner reservations for us (including one of Tokyo's 3 Michelin star restaurants). Where I was impressed was that after sending them a list of my restaurant requests they replied back within several hours saying when each restaurant opened their reservation process, as well as the days that the restaurants would be closed. Since I sent my original request about three months out, most of the restaurants wouldn't accept reservations for another month. The concierge kept in contact with me and let me know as soon as they booked the reservations. In addition to the restaurant reservations, they also purchased the hard to acquire Ghibli Museum tickets for me on my desired day (just make sure you ask them to purchase over a month out before your arrival). Needless to say, I was extremely happy with our choice of hotel well in advance of our stay.When we finally arrived in Tokyo we were able to easily find our way to the hotel. They provide excellent directions on their website. One thing to note is that the hotel was a little farther from the station than we had expected. Usually I choose hotels that are within a 5 minute walking radius from a public transportation hub. This hotel was a good 10 minute walk from the JR Shimbashi station. Although the walk was a little further than I was used to, the area is extremely pleasant, with far fewer crowds than other areas of Tokyo, lots of signs and maps everywhere, and is surrounded by beautiful skyscrapers. So at least the 10 minute walk is a pleasant one. I had emailed the hotel several days before hand letting them know that we would be arriving before their check-in time of 2pm and that we would need to store our luggage at the hotel while we went out. When we arrived we were surprised to find that our rooms were ready and that we could do an early check-in. I was also presented with the Ghibli Museum tickets that they had purchased, as well as detailed directions to all of the restaurants they had booked.The room itself was quite spacious for a Japan hotel (still small by western standards). There was ample space for our luggage and we did not feel boxed in or claustrophobic. The bathroom was also a good size, with more than enough counter space for both of our belongings. Although the shampoo / conditioner / body wash were provided in small bottles vs the large pump bottles that we got at every other hotel in Japan, they restocked the bottles daily so supply was never an issue. The great benefit to the room was the incredible view of Tokyo tower and Mount Fuji (on clear days). Waking up to a view of Tokyo Tower + Mt. Fuji was a special treat that I won't soon forget. One thing to note is that you will need to book a room with a Tokyo Tower view in order to enjoy this. There was a small increase in the room price, but it was well worth it. If you don't book a room with a view, then the Tokyo tower is still visible from the hotel lobby on the 25th floor.The breakfast started at 7:00am and was buffet style with Japanese and Western choices. We found the food to be well prepared and of ample variety to never get tired of the hotel breakfast throughout our six night stay. One thing to note is that they have croissants kept warm under a heat lamp. There is no better start to the day than with a warm, flaky, croissant and I always enjoy hotel breakfasts that do this properly.As a base of operations, we found the location to be very convenient. As stated above, the hotel is a 10 minute walk from the JR Shimbashi station which can get you to anywhere in Tokyo within a 30 minute subway ride. Additionally, the hotel is a 10 minute walk from the Tokyo metro Ginza and Asakusa lines. It is also three minute walk to the Tokyo metro Oedo line. If you are planning to go to Odaiba during your stay then the hotel is extremely convenient, being literally right next to one of the Yurikamome train stations. One last thing to note about the location is that the hotel is a one minute walk to the Hayao Miyazaki Steam-punk clock. This is a giant clock that looks a lot like Howl's Moving Castle. The clock puts on a little show every day at 10am/12pm/3pm/6pm/8pm. It is amazing to see and especially magical for Miyazaki/Studio Ghibli fans. Having this so close to our hotel was a special bonus for us.We never had lunch or dinner at the hotel, and never used any of the other services so I cant comment on those. One thing to note is that they do have laundry machines that you can use if you need to. This makes things convenient on long stays. In Kyoto we had to drag a suitcase full of dirty clothes to a laundromat in order to do our laundry. That wouldn't have been a problem here at this hotel.Overally we were extremely happy with the hotel. The service from the concierge, the superb view, and the convenient location will make this our hotel for any future stops in Tokyo.

We really enjoyed staying in this hotel. The room was of a decent size, and the bed was comfortable. The amenities in the bathroom were good as well.We booked the tower view room and were not disappointed - lovely view.The hotel is modern and classy, and everyone was really friendly. The WiFi worked well as well. The location is good, only a short walk from several sights and there is a subway station around the corner. Shibuya station is only a short walk away as well, which takes you pretty much everywhere, including HND.My only complaint really is the cost of extras...we got a couple beers to take up to the room one day and couldn't believe the price given it was just a draft lager, and the breakfast was overpriced too.

Be prepared for a circuitous entry to this hotel property. Entering what seems to be the main lobby will not garner a reception desk; a small sign directs you to a bank of elevators where you learn the hotel starts on the 25th floor!The room is quite small, as are most hotel rooms in Tokyo, even in the 4* category. There is free Wi-Fi which works quite well. The bathroom lighting was excellent with adequate counter space for toiletries. The tub/shower combination has a laundry cord to stretch from one side of the tub to the other for drying items you launder in the sink.Twin beds are about 12" from each other; duvets are quite warm. There is a coffee/tea set-up and a small (stocked) refrigerator. The breakfast buffet was adequate with juices, fresh fruits, cereal, bakery items, hard-cooked eggs and a few hot items (sausage, bacon, scrambled eggs) available. Dinner is a limited menu but nicely prepared.

This hotel may have very small rooms but overall it punches above its weight. We selected a Tokyo Tower view room and were not disappointed. We found that all staff understood our English and worked diligently to please. In turn our questions were answered in English, not faultless but carefully and cautiously in order not to offend.Breakfast was great, as was the one lunch we enjoyed on site.The pillows, what a curious thing! There are ones that feel as if they have small marbles in them, that can be hard when collected and pliable when separated. As I reiterate, a curious thing. However I always ask for feather/down pillows, wherever I go, and They were delivered before I could put my suitcase down in my room.WiFi, another curious thing. I travel with a phone and iPad. So does my husband. When we had all four devices WiFi switched on, we found the WiFi did not work for us. Using one or two devices at a time, we had no problems at all.The location directly adjacent to Shiodome Exit 7 & 8 is ideal. Also very close and via the amazing subterranean network, Shimbashi station is just a short walk away, most, if not all, of which can be accessed via escalator or elevator if carrying/rolling along suitcases. You do have to look for the elevators however. If you do not over think the process and follow the signage one step at a time, it becomes simpler with use.There is a convene stor on level B2, the basement. level 1 is the street level to the road outside. However reception is via lift access to the 25thnfloor. Only certain lifts go all the way from 25th level to B4, the lowest level, which is the carpark. Shiodome exits 7&8 come out to the third level where there is an exit to the elevator bank for access to the hotel. One takes a second lift from the 25th level to rooms above up to level 34.Tokyo accommodation is generally compact and this is no exception, the accommodation does hav a high level of functionality.The bathroom products by Thann are very nice too. The WC is modern Japanese and the heat setting can be quite quite warm.The railway line is below the Southwestern side and trains can be distantly heard when they are running. It is not intrusive.A great place to stay.

We arrived early at the hotel due to our overnight flight. Although our room was not ready the staff did their best to sort it before the official check in time. The staff were very friendly and courteous. The hotel was well situated for shops, restaurants and Shimbashi station. We stayed on the 33 floor and had great views.Our room looked a little bit "tired" but was clean and well equipped.The breakfast was good but the staff seemed to be a long time replacing items on the buffet.

We stayed for 5 nights on the 29th floor. Well connected to the public transport, nice modern architecture and super friendly service. The cocktail at the hotel bar are excellent. The cafe downstairs has amazing croissants!

We stayed here for 3 nights and then for 1 night and found it to be an excellent place to stay for exploring Tokyo. It is located close to both the Shiodome and Shimbashi stations. It is also walking distance from the Ginza, the Tsukiji Market and the Hama-riki Garden. There are numerous walkways at different levels although navigation can be a little tricky until one gets used to them. As well as the French restaurant there is a Japanese restaurant and one can also eat in the central atrium. This atrium most be the most notable feature of the hotel. They project large scale images onto one of the walls in the evening. One can also buy very good craft beers here. The hotel does not start until the 25th floor from which one gets an excellent view of the Tokyo Tower. Our room was on the top floor and from there we had a view of the garden and waterways beyond.We found the staff to be extremely helpful and friendly and nearly everyone seemed to speak good English. Through them we were able to arrange to have most of our luggage forwarded to Hiroshima while we went into the mountains.

I spend here my family vacations and I can say it was a great option, first of all the location, inside of the subway system that is, as well, a great achievement of Japanese organization, the buffet is really good with plenty options, the views from the rooms are spectacular, I have in the same frame a great view of Tokyo tower and Mt. Fuji, also, they have this special floor where each one of the rooms are fully decorated by a contemporary artists,incredible. Last but not least the staff is really kind and very attentive to detail and to the guests. Really a great option, you won't regret it.

The Park Hotel is located within walking distance of many subway stations as well as the JR station. The lobby is located on the 23 floor of the building with an atrium from the ceiling filtering down, with all the rooms facing out over the city. There is a Japanese as well as a French restaurant in the lobby. The rooms (we had both a room with queen size bed as well as two twins) are a good size, and the bathrooms are good, with lots of amenities. The beds are comfortable as are the pillows. There is free wifi that works very well. Our only disappointment was the lack of a place to get a late lunch in the hotel. By 3, the dessert offered in the lobby was down to one option, with no sandwiches or other lunch-type food.

Great hotel. Really nice rooms. Good restaurants. It has a beautiful lobby space that you can work, have meetings or socialize in. Best of all it has an amazing view of Mount Fuji! Its location was further from Shibuya, Harajuku and all of the parts of the city that I was spending most of my time, BUT it was close to Tsukiji fish market which is a must visit for first timers to Tokyo.

We stayed six nights in all at the park Hotel, and loved it. It's so well located. Shimbashi station (on JR Line and also subway) is 5 minutes walk away, and you can walk to Ginza in 10 minutes.Try to get a room with a view of the Tokyo Tower. Reception is on the 25th floor. Floor 31 has special rooms with each decorated by an artist.Staff were super helpful, and breakfast was fine.

We stayed here for three nights at the start of our trip to Japan. This hotel has great views of Tokyo from the reception on the 25th floor and also from our suit (on the corner or the hotel so you get curved windows) on the 30th floor - got some amazing photos at Tokyo at night. The standard rooms are a little small but well equipped. This hotel also has a very good breakfast buffet, offering Japanese and Western style foods. The location is also very good. Overall, a good choice for a stay in Tokyo.

Number one in my book for excellent customer service. For non-Japanese speaking tourists, every staff member was either able to help us immediately or get someone who could help us immediately - whether it was for making reservations, confirming reservations, recommending places to eat, directions. We almost never had to ask, their anticipation was amazing!

The toilet stinks despite it is clean. Helpful and friendly staff but gave us wrong address for the bus terminal. When we called for help they could barely communicate in English on the phone. Luckily we were helped by a passer-by who kindly talked to the hotel people and drove us to the bus terminal. The hotel didn't follow up after we got back to the hotel.

Located at 21 floor with great city view. (I recommend a room with Tokyo Tower view)Only a few footsteps away from Ginza and Train/Subway Stations. Nice and clean Rooms. Great breakfast buffet :-) Best price value !

We had 48 hours to see everything we could in Tokyo - Park Hotel had the right price, right size room (pretty large considering we are in Tokyo) and close to the Tsukiji Fish Market (at the current location anyway, until they move later in 2016). We were in a bit of a rush so we took taxis quite a bit but we took the metro system a few times and it was very close to the hotel. Even though I speak fluent Japanese, my husband only speaks English and they spoke fantastic English and their concierge was fantastic with recommending restaurants and making reservations. There was also a convenience store at the basement for quick snacks and water.

Stayed overnight in this hotel great view of tokyo tower and Mt fuji in the background... Close to many convenience stores and railway.... Entry though is a little confusing with Bell service on the 3rd floor

We got a fabulous room at a great price. Staff could not be better. Only problem was I went to the lobby and decided to have a cup of coffee. The waiter brought the coffee and a glass of water with the bill discretely put in a holder. There were diners having the breakfast buffet. Having just gotten to the country the previous day, I was unsure of the exchange, but was aghast when I realized the charge was 950 yen. Yes, $9:50! I did sign the bill but was quite upset. I larter even asked at the night manager to take off the outrageous charge. I was told by the extremely polite manager, that that was the cost. Buffet breakfast is 2400. High but definitely a better bargain than coffee.

We stayed at the Park hotel for a night at the end of our honeymoon, for a whirlwind tour of Tokyo (we've been before but not during Sakura season). Everything about our stay was exceptional. The staff were lovely and treated us with a gift on arrival (sencha as we preferred that over champagne) for our honeymoon. We chose a room with the view of Tokyo tower, which we would recommend as it's quite breathtaking at night - and went well with some relaxing tea! The room seemed spacious by Tokyo standards and amenities were nice for the level of hotel. We will be back again, given the chance.

Communication with the hotel was outstanding even before our arrival. They helped us with the purchase of tickets for baseball games and were very clear about the type/s of rooms available for three of us. The location of the hotel was perfect for both walking and taking public transportation. Staff made terrific recommendations for restaurants and was helpful answering all of our questions. Highly recommend staying at the Park Hotel Tokyo.

You won't be disappointed with this hotel which is conveniently located very close to Shinbashi station that's very well linked with the airports and rest of Tokyo. Shuttle buses alos run to and from the hotel and two major international airports. The room itself was clean, comfortable and we had a great view of the rest of the city. The staff were very helpful and friendly. Highly recommend if you are looking for a comfortable stay or here for business.

This hotel is close to the Shimbashi rail and subway stations. The Yamanoto JR circle line is ideal to get you everywhere. You can access the hotel on walkway level, which is the 3rd floor in the Media Tower Building. Reception is on the 25th floor. We had a VIP room on the 34th floor. It was comfortable but very small, which is typical for Japan of course. Amazing that hotel staff are so poor in english speaking and understanding. Japan has a great system of luggage forwarding. You can leave your heavy suitcases at the belldesk and they will arrange transport to your next hotel. Trains, even the Shinkansen, are not really built to carry much luggage.

I was so excited to stay at the Park Hotel. It's in a brilliant location, next to Shimbashi and Shiodome Station and easy walking distance to all the shops and restaurants in Ginza. I booked online and discussed room options via email. The hotel staff were very helpful and gave me a better rate than the big online booking services. I loved the look of the artist rooms that they have: rooms entirely hand painted by many contemporary Japanese artists in varying media and styles. The Park Hotel has a great policy of promoting and supporting contemporary Japanese artists.My first preference was for the Geisha Goldfish room, but this had been booked out. I got my second choice "Festival" and we loved that room. The hotel offered us a special rate to change to another artist room rather than to the normal room we had booked for the rest of our stay and it was too good to refuse. The second room was called "Otafuku Face" and had a lovely, big happy Japanese face with beautiful, lush, painted cherry blossoms across the entire room, walls and ceiling. Apparently this room is a favourite, probably because it also has an amazing view of the Tokyo Tower.There was something really special about staying in the artist rooms and I definitely thought it was worth the small extra cost. The rooms themselves are a good size, with very comfortable beds, good air con, quiet and great lighting. Huge picture windows give lots of natural daylight. The bathrooms are very nice with the multi functional Japanese toilets, deep soaker bath and shower. I loved the retractable line for drying small handwashed items. The toiletries were gorgeous, all lovely botanicals by Thann. My favourite was the shower gel. Apart from a very nice toothbrush and folding comb/brush, the hotel also supplied a great washing and scruffing cloth and I'll confess to hoarding a few of these. They last quite a lot of washes and are just textured enough to bring a glow to your skin without rasping. I'm still using the one from the hotel 4 weeks later. Wish I'd bought more of the Thann products in Omotesando to remind me of our trip.Everything about the Park Hotel was above our expectations. Great rooms, fast lifts, beautiful and interesting art displays, delightful staff and service. The staff were wonderful; always saying hello and smiling as we went past. The reception/concierge helped us out with directions, maps, airport shuttles and booking a special restaurant that was notoriously hard to get into. Everything was easily and calmly achieved. In a busy city like Tokyo, the Park Hotel was a blissful quiet haven to come back to each evening. Another bonus of this hotel's location is its proximity to the huge Ghibli clock that animates and the inexpensive restaurants in the Shiodome buildings. It's a 10 minute amble up to the Ginza shopping strip.There's a good local market/supermarket on the way to Ginza (about 5 minutes from the hotel) that has everything you might want: milk, snacks, fruit and drinks. It caters to locals and has an amazing array of fresh and frozen seafood. Everything is in Japanese, not English so learn some key words or use a translation tool like Google Translate to translate images of text from products. Or just try your luck since just about everything in Japan tastes good.I highly recommend this hotel to any type of traveller, but especially to those with a love of modern art. We will definitely be staying here again.

We really enjoyed our stay. The queen room we stayed in had an amazing view and the whole hotel was beautifully presented. Well located in the Ginza area and relatively close to a main train station. Staff were really helpful and welcoming.

This hotel was simply awesome. I paid 270 / night (total, with tax). In Tokyo prices (especially during cherry blossom festival time), this was a good deal. We stayed at more centrally located hotels at first, but paid upwards of 750/night and dealt with sometimes overwhelmed staff/crowds. I have traveled the world extensively and I was extremely pleased with this hotel. Although my room was on the smaller side - I never felt it at all. Why ? Because the design of it was incredible. Everything was placed logically and there was even a desk and a chair to watch tv. The bathroom was superclean and, while not spacious, was not missing anything at all. Shower was perfect temperature and strong. Sink and toilet (although I don't need or want all that TOTO Japan stuff) were good. Staff was awesome, never overwhelmed, and always helpful. The hotel was quiet because it's in the middle of a massive office park. Yes, you can actually walk outside and go to a few nearby shops and restaurants that are fun and not "skanky". But the true gem of this hotel is that it is in the middle of "nowhere". The key is that it is quiet when you sleep. But, when you are ready to embrace Tokyo for all that it offers - the extremely close train (and subway if you need it) service is available immediately. You can get to Tokyo station faster than the regular subway. You can go to Harajuku and other off the grid places. Will definitely return.

From Shinbashi station we followed the directions listed by the hotel and got to the Park Hotel in about 15 mins. We had to find elevators as we had a stroller with two kids in tow.We checked into our hotel room on Level 31 (the lobby is on Level 25). Our room was bright and spacious. We had booked a corner king room. We had a glorious and clear view that spanned across the Tokyo tower, a landscape garden and tall business buildings. We preferred the Shiodome station (Oeda line) as it was easier to navigate and get to with a stroller. In the mornings we walked past salarymen to get to Caretta mall where we had McDonald's and really good coffee at Tully's. The mall itself had a good selection of restaurants but they didn't open until at least 11am. From the Park hotel we made our trips to Disneyland and Sunshine city for the aquarium. The surrounding business district area was quiet and easy to navigate.  I had booked this hotel almost six months before our trip and the communication via email was easy and helpful. Our stay too was extremely comfortable. The cleaning staff maintained our room very well and all amenities were provided. Their complimentary instant drip coffee (Key's Drip On) is excellent by the way. If you are looking for a well maintained and comfortable hotel with courteous staff, in a futuristic part of Tokyo without sacrificing your need for convenience then this is your best bet.

We stayed in the Park the last time we came to Tokyo, and were so impressed that we decided to come back. We stayed in a corner room - a little pricier than the standard room, but hugely worthwhile for the views alone. Everyone was so friendly - especially Lorenzo in the restaurant, who made a real effort to make guests' experience a great one. The food in the lounge bar is fantastic (though quite expensive for what it was). That said, the minibars are the cheapest I've found anywhere, so that makes up for it.Breakfast was the best of any hotel we stayed in during our trip. Plentiful, quick to be seated, lots of variety.Slight snag is the location. It's not the best in the world - it takes 10 minutes to get there from Shimbashi/Shiodome station. Not ideal when you do it a few times a day. But definitely not a big enough factor to stop me coming back.Overall, a great experience - I look forward to coming back one day.

Boring tourist high rise hotel. Showing its age. Couldn't use the gym because we didn't have a gym reservation which was ridiculous. No explanation was given and we were told no times would be available later in the day. Not the kind of thing you'd expect when paying $450 USD per night.

We stayed here for 2 nights at the end of March. We wanted a room with a veiw of the tower but they were all booked. Initially our room was on the 29th floor facing the train station. There was noise from the train but not horrible. However the bathroom had a terrible odor and I read another review mentioning the same thing. We asked for our room to be changed, which seemed like a little bit of a hassle for the hotel staff, but eventually were moved to the 33rd floor facing the bay. This was much better, quiet and no smell. The view from there was also fantastic. Other than the smelly room and staff a bit clumsy on how to handle this, the rest of the stay was great and staff was excellent. They went our of their way to help us.The location was good as you could easily walk to train station underground, though I didn't find any particularly interesting restaurants outside the hotel that I wanted to try. The restaurant we tried in the station was good however. We had stayed in Tokyo in a different location earlier in our vacation that I liked better overall, bigger room, bathroom as well. This seems more like a business hotel.

We stayed in a artist room, which was very nice and the view was astonishing. The staff was very helpful and friendly, as expected from Japan.Our daughter stayed in a single normal room, which had not much view.

My husband and I have just returned from The Park Hotel Shiodome Media Tower and we cannot praise it enough. We were in the Artist room 'Landscape' which had a fantastic view over the city and Tokyo tower. The room was of a good size, clean, comfortable bed, adequate storage for clothes, adequate toiletries, tea/coffee making facilities, shoe horn and clothes brush, room safe and last but not least a TV if you have time to watch it! There are three restaurants we went to The Atrium restaurant, the food was excellent as was the service. The staff at the hotel were all very helpful, pleasant and polite. The location of the hotel is good near to restaurants, train station and metro. A very good hotel and one we would recommend.

We had a wonderful stay here. The room was superb and everything works well. Staff are friendly and way out to help. Everyone here are so much professional and always willing to help. Hotel is in Good location easy access to shops. Shinbachi Station is close to the hotel which is easy access the city.

We spent 6 nights in total at the hotel. Both nights on floor 33. We had great views thought the first room on the train station side was a bit noisier as you could hear the trains all night and the view was slightly obstructed by the building next to the hotel. Room 3303 was quieter and had unobstructed views. Hotel has pretty much direct access to Shindome station and Shimbashi stations so really convenient . The hotel has an atrium area with a lounge bar where you can have light snacks and where you have breakfast. It has a bar with nice views and two restaurants, one Japanese and one French. We ate at the Japanese and also had a light snack and afternoon tea at the lounge bar. All very pleasant. Breakfast had a good selection of Western and Japanese style food, my only complaint would be that there were very view suitably high tables and often we had to sit on very low armchairs designed more for comfort than for eating. The overflow room is not as pleasant so try to have your breakfast in the lounge. Service was a little slow at times but always very charming. The rooms are quite small and we initially thought this was because of being in Tokyo but due to a last minute change of itinerary we stayed one night at Villa Fontaine next to the hotel in a twin room ( but not single beds ) and this was almost double in size ( room 404 ). See also review for this hotel . We used transfer service to Haneda airport which was excellent and good value.

The rooms are more than adequate. The staff is exceptionally courteous and attentive. The concierge desk staff are magicians. The location is easy walking distance to Shinbachi Station which has connections to the entire city

This is a new looking hotel. Lobby starts at 25 F up to 34. Good view of Tokyo, giving you and idea that this is an old town and not much planning Staff good to excellent with varying proficiency in English but always trying hard. Room fine and everything works. Has a Michelin mentioned restaurant. Close to underground.

Great staff, great room, good location although a bit far from everything. If I went back to Tokio I would get a hotel closer to the main station. But in general this one is really good. If I had to say something bad would be basic bathroom (but i found the same in the rest of japanese cities i visited) and pricey breakfast.

Really nice location. The rooms are on the high floors which provides great possibilities for a good view. The rooms were also very clean. Friendly and very helpful staff. The breakfast does not offer that many options but at least you have sone western and asian courses.

If you're traveling to Tokyo, this is the place to stay! Close to train station. Safe. Kind, friendly and nice personal.This was our first time in Tokyo, I missed it already! Great view of Tokyo from the room.

The choice in Tokyo is immense yet somehow we managed to get it just right by landing in a bespoke artist's room with a dragon painted across almost every surface. Moments from Ginza and next to Shimbashi and Shiodome stations this hotel sits above the 25th floor with commanding views of much of Tokyo. No adjacent buildings obscure this view. Our room faced Tokyo tower with the panorama stretching through Marunouchi district to glimpses of the palace grounds. The King room was very large by Tokyo standards. The service was first class. We did not eat here, simply by choice as we dashed off each day but it seemed popular and busy. Wifi was great for my international work. Highly recommended. Book the artist rooms if possible. Ask for Tokyo tower views. They are divine!

My boyfriend and I stayed here for 4 nights in the "Bamboo room." A bit expensive for what it is however... The location makes up for everything.The hotel is in a business district so there's not much to do nearby however it is connected to the Shidome pedi way. There are multiple train lines right there making it easy to explore Tokyo. The welcoming sake was especially wonderful. Overall great for someone who really wants to bop around the city.

We had six nights at The Park, located within walking distance to JR rail and metro, short trip to Ginza, pick up point for tours, well appointed rooms friendly staff. Can on forward your suitcases to next hotel. Restaurants within business towers close by. Quieter district compared to Shinjuku. Not a lot of shopping close by but we were not visiting to shop until you drop.

Stayed here on our final night in Japan. Booked a Tokyo Tower view room, which is highly recommended. Room was a good size, and the bed was comfortable. The staff were friendly and happy to help in any way. We also really liked some of the quirky and cutting edge design features.All in all, great value for money.

This is a beautiful hotel. The service was top notch, as good as Savoy or Waldorf in London. The rooms were exceptionally clean, and the view of Tokyo Tower was a joy. I have no hesitation in recommending highly and would stay again. Do book a view of the Tower and turn off the lights

We stayed at the hotel on two separate occasions during a two-weeks stay in Japan, book-ending our trip beginning and end.
