We can take as many pictures as we want in the room, with the Tower, be it day or night shot!Room comes with full amenities, clean and neat, spent a very comfortable 3 nights here. It looks smaller than I expected but all others is fine, as long as it doesn't have any musky smell which I came across for rest of my hotel stay in Japan. Location wise, its within walking distance to Shimbashi Station, which connects to most of the tourist attractions, eg Asakusa, Shibuya, Odaiba, these places took less than 20 mins traveling time.Excellent service staffs, very friendly and courteous 24/7! I would definitely book the same hotel in Tokyo during my next visit!

Really good location, really easy to get around on public transport from. The view is great as the hotel occupies the top floors of the towers. We had a third bed added to a corner room and still had plenty of space.

Great hotel to explore Tokyo. Everything you need is walking distance: transport links, Ginza, few family-mart shops to pickup small items like water, Tokyo Bay, fish market...Breakfast buffet was generous and well stocked with local and international options. Decent size rooms for Tokyo standards (don't expect large rooms), perfect views across Tokyo tower or Tokyo bay. I loved the shelf-sitting at the window; if you are good with heights; you can spend hours perched at the window watching the city lights.Staff cannot be more polite and most of the spoke good english. Free wi-fi with great speed and coverage. Room service available, mini-bar, kettle for coffee and tea, surprisingly quiet, quiet air-con (windows will not open), all toiletries provided incl toothbrush, comb, cotton buds, shower caps etc.Overall, highly recommended and would stay here again if I visit Tokyo.

Impeccable describes everything about this hotel. The room overlooking Tokyo Tower was amazing and on clear days the view of Mount Fuji was spectacular. The hotel service epitomises the best that Japan has to offer. The room service food although small in choices offered was beautifully presented, high quality and a fairly standard price for a hotel of this quality. The hotel is ideally located to Shiodome train station, about a two minute easy walk, which connects you to the many train lines in Tokyo and beyond. The hotel can organise a limousine bus to take you to the airport, cost is about $30. The lobby is one of sophistication and art with the moving art feature that is projected onto one of the towering internal hotel walls coming on at 7pm every night. We thoroughly enjoyed our stay at the hotel and would highly recommend any travellers wanting a first class experience to stay here.

A very good hotel with decent sized rooms (for Japan standards) and mostly very helpful, cheerful and friendly staff. Could improve on facilities for families with younger children, but other than that, a very good quality hotel.

Almost every time I go Tokyo I choose the Park Hotel for my stay. Near Tokyo station, Ginza and Tsukiji fish market with direct connection to subway and 10 min away from Shimbashi JR line. Quality of rooms as well as service is at the top. Price is within the range for this type of Hotel and location. Highly recommend !

Everyone was extremely friendly and curtious! Some of the staff knew us by name. When we checked in and went to our room a prearranged tea service was given. She also took our pictures with our cameras. Hands down this is the best experience ever! Highly recommend! American hotel hospitality companies should use this hotel as a training ground for this price point.

The check-in and check-out process was easy and smooth for us. The staff gave us a map and showed us to our room. All staff were friendly and acknowledge us every time they saw us. Room was cleaned daily; coffee and teas were also replenished daily. Housekeeping was great; they even gave us new robes and put our slippers next to our beds. I thought this was so sweet of them.Location of the hotel is close to the subway and train station. There is also a Family Mart ( like a 7-11) downstairs for meals and snacks. There is also a Laundry room on the 26th floor. They have directions in English too. Very easy to follow. The machine is a washer and dryer in one, but you can just wash or just dry if you choose that option. We had to put another 100 yen to have it dry for another 30 minutes because some things didn't get dried completely. Other than that it was pretty convenient. I would stay here again and would recommend it to others too!

The hotel is impressive from the outset. Starting from the 25th floor of the Shiodome Media Tower you get outstanding views of the city.From my room I could watch the Shinkansen whizzing through Shimbashi station and at night the lights of Tokyo were spectacular.The hotel is modern, clean and comfortable and the staff are extremely welcoming and friendly.At the base of the hotel are a number of cafes and a bar. Ginza is within walking distance for high end shopping as are the beautiful Hamarikyu gardens.The rest of Tokyo is easily accessibly via Shimbashi station and the excellent JR transit system.

I loved the view we had from our room as well as it being walking distance from the fish markets. I love how it overlooked Tokyo Tower. excellent service and facilities. Beautiful lobby and staff service.

Probably caters to business travelers but we found it great for vacation. Centrally located for transportation, directly on most tour and shuttle stops, front desk concierge and bell staff could not be more helpful. Quiet, so if you are looking for bars etc in hotel, not here. Hotel restaurants good. Breakfast a good mix of western and local. Rooms are small by U.S. standards but spacious by Tokyo standards. 24 hour Family Mart (convenience story) on basement level. Connected to Shindome and Shimbashi stations directly. "Art hitel" with beautiful works from local artists throughout the hotel.

The hotel is very nice. It has small rooms but they are very comfortable and with excellent views. Staff is impeccable, friendly, and very helpful. Concierge is outstanding: very knowledgeable where or how to get there. Suggest more alternatives, and just as all Japanese very polite and friendly.Stuff speaks good English easy to understand. Location is excellent, within 5 -7 min walking distance to few subway stops.Hotel stuff can provide you with local maps and point all places where you want to go. Explain you in details how to get there,etc. Subway map and local maps are available in the lobby. Very convenient.I enjoyed my stay in this and definitely lovely hotel would come back.

Having stayed earlier in our vacation in a different hotel in Tokyo in the Shinjuku area as well as a ryokan in Hakone, coming here was a bit different. The hotel itself is very lovely, our artist room was absolutely beautiful, and the views of Tokyo Tower from our room breathtaking, especially at night. We also were treated to complimentary sake upon arrival, a great touch! As elsewhere in Japan, everything was spotless. All that said, we felt a little less welcome here than in other locations in Japan. The staff were perfectly professional, but just not as warm and friendly as in other places we had visited over the prior week. I don't know if it was just because their usual clientele are business people or what, but it was a distinctly different vibe from other hotels/ryokans in which we had stayed. Breakfast buffet is solid, though small. Was surprised by the very Western dinner menu, including room service, but man, those BLTs were tasty! During our stay we also happened to meet one of the artists who was having an exhibition on our floor - what a fantastic guy, with beautiful work! Having local artists featured throughout the hotel was really nice. I also have to say that because this is a little more of a business/financial district, there wasn't QUITE as much right out the front door to explore as in other locations, and a little harder to find the convenience stores and such. However, it's still a short walk to the Hamrikyu Gardens and only about 15 minutes' walk to the Tsujiki Fish Market. I don't know that I'd stay here again, partly because it was a little further from what felt like the heart of all the city, and partly because of the strange, slightly uncomfortable vibe. But it was a beautiful place and a good stay. Oh and P.S. Free wifi in the rooms seems the norm in Japan - not so in the Western world, but what a great perk.

We stayed here for 3 nights in May 2015 at the end of our trip around Japan. The hotel is conveniently located (once you've managed to find it) with plenty of transport and food options in the immediate vicinity.The rooms are very small and the one we stayed in was very tired having a ragged carpet that was covered in stains and walls that were covered in scrape marks. Furniture was cheap and nasty although the bed was perfectly comfortable. There was little in the way of storage room and the safe was not the biggest we've ever come across. Wi-fi worked well in the room as did the air-conditioning. The bathroom was also tiny and again felt old and tired compared to most of the other places we stayed. This was sold to us as a "First Class" hotel but the room felt in desperate need of some refurbishment.The included breakfast was decent enough with a reasonable amount of choice but is just served in the lobby area which isn't particularly classy. The restaurants looked expensive and un-inspiring (both in terms of menu and ambience) so we gave them a miss and ate in some of the huge array of restaurants around the Ginza area. One evening we used the hotels cosy looking little bar but again it was a bit lifeless and lacking in atmosphere.Service was a bit mixed with some good and some not so good. For example, I went to reception to get some help to change our transfer arrangements back to Haneda but I was told that I should be doing stuff like that using the bedroom telephone. When the staff member finally agreed to help she made it clear that the phone call would be billed to our room. Not the sort of service we had to worry about at other places we stayed and rather poor for a "First Class" hotel.Overall this hotel is in a reasonably good location but with the poor state of the bedroom and the mixed service I'm sure there are better places to stay if you're in the Ginza area.

Fantastic concept: the nine highest floors of a 34 story building makes that every room offers stunning panoramic views, some of Tokyo Tower. So do the bar and restaurants. Only the edge part are rooms, which offers a huge nine sory inner hall with daylight through the glass ceiling. Tastly decorated with modern art. impecable staff, great style. Japonese restaurant, top scale French restaurant with great French wine list. Third lower profile restaurant also offering first class food with same perfect service. Nice trendy bar (smoking permitted!). Great location near Shimbashi station, which is a perfect start for all your Tokyo sightseeing! Alltogether thisnhotel.gives you a warm and homy feeling and a perfect service: once again: could not be better!

We stayed here as the first leg of our honeymoon and we could not have picked a better hotel.The staff were fabulous. So polite and friendly. Happy to advise on where to go, what to do, and how to pronounce some of the Japanese phrases we were trying to learn.The views from the hotel were amazing. I dont think it can really be put into words how impressed we were with the views of Tokyo!We only ate dinner in the hotel once, unfortunately, but the experience we had was lovely. Food was declious and very reasonable. Wait staff were very attentive and keen to please.Japan impressed us so much, we are hoping to return in the near future and I would definately have Park Hotel on my list of hotels to stay in.Great location, close to anything and everything you might need.

The hotel's location is very underrated...approximately 10 minutes' walk to Shimbashi station (on the all-important Yamanote line) and Ginza. Located on the top floors of an office building in a business district, most rooms seem to offer fantastic views, but the Tokyo Tower rooms, with an unblocked view of the tower as well as Mount Fuji, probably offer some of the more compelling city views in Asia and can't be recommended highly enough. Room size is adequate...indeed quite reasonable by Tokyo standards. The bathroom, while simple enough, is extremely clean and offers all of the necessary amenities. Service is very efficient and friendly, and we were offered a free bottle of wine simply for signing up for the hotel's loyalty programme. Special mention to the very pleasant concierge who worked hard to accommodate a last-minute, relatively specific restaurant request and came through with flying colours, even going to the trouble of creating a customised map for us. The lobby sports a Michelin-listed French restaurant which offers very reasonable and high quality set meals for lunch, but be warned that you may feel a bit underdressed in tourist attire in comparison to the business lunch clientele on weekdays. On the whole, a very good value for money option at around sgd250/night in Tokyo that is surprisingly well located for tourists yet is not subjected to the ever-present crowds of some of the more well-known districts. random tip...Ramen counter around the corner on the way to Shimbashi station (ground level...the name is in Japanese but it says 'want garlic?' underneath for some reason) was a nice find, with a massive bowl of high quality ramen running about 700 yen.

I was very happy with my 3 night stay in this hotel. The room and the whole hotel was very clean and well maintained and the staff were very friendly. Room was a reasonable size by Japanese standards and the room I received lived up to what I chose and how it was described on the internet when I booked. The view of Tokyo tower was excellent. The bathroom was a little on the small side, though workable for one or two people. The bed was very comfortable and the room was quiet, even though my room was located close to the lift area.I liked the location, only a couple of minutes walk from Shimbasi station which is on the convenient Yamanote line. There are plenty of restaurants and cafes around the Shimbasi/Shiodome area and the old part of Shimbasi is quite fascinating and only a couple of minutes walk away. From this hotel you can also comfortably walk to Yama Riku Gardens in about 10 minutes and Tsukiji fish markets are about a 20 minute walk.I can't comment on the hotel restaurant because I didn't eat there at all. There are many places to eat around the area and any number of Family Mart's and other convenient shops.I would have no hesitation in staying here again.

My parents, sister and I stayed at this hotel for 6 nights, 15 minutes walk to Ginza, Shiodome, JR line and restaurants near by. The hotel Lobby has an amazing view also our rooms had a great view and wall paintings. Staff very helpful and friendly. Breakfast a little expensive but worth it, I specially enjoy the miso soup, salmon and rice. We took breakfast every other day so the rest of the days we look for other options there are a bunch of coffee shops at Nippon TV Tower (here you can't miss the big clock) just in front of the hotel.
user_name:
KattiaLorena
New York City, New York

review_body: Great hotel in an excellent location, convenient for rail and metro travel. And the Tsukijii fish market! Ask for a room facing Hamarikyu Garden - amazing views - hotel starts on the 25th floor. Very courteous and helpful staff.

The hotel is very confortable. Very beautiful the lobby and workers very kind.A little noisy due to the monorail Yurikamone that it is very close. Having dinner impossible. Breakfast too expensive and not for Europeans.

The Park Hotel is a very special place to stay in Tokyo. Situated in the top 10 floors of the Shiodome Media Tower in the capital’s newest shiny skyscraper district – this cutting edge art hotel brings the beauty of Japanese culture and art to the luxury hotel market.The futuristic Shiodome district opened to the public in 2002 and, as well as the Park Hotel its spectacular skyscrapers house offices, restaurants, theatres, shops and the headquarters of Nippon television, one of Japan’s national private television networks.The Shiodome area was originally a tidal marshland separating the Imperial palace from Tokyo Bay. During the Edo Period (1603-1867) the marshes were dried up and developed into residential land. Shiodome literally means “halt the tides”The Park hotel with its vaulted atrium and achingly cool bars, houses art exhibitions regularly in its public spaces but it also has some very special hotel rooms indeed.One entire floor of the hotel has been given over to the Artist in Hotel project which began in December 2012. Each room on the 31st floor is being decorated with a work of art by a Japanese artist. This project is well underway and we were treated to a view of some of the amazing rooms.Broadly themed on "Japanese aesthetics," artists draw on the walls and decorate the rooms with their original paintings and art objects. A finished Artist Room is a pure art form encapsulating the creator's passion and views.Themes for the rooms include the Dragon room where a great fiery beast curls around the walls, and the Zen room which is very spiritual and peaceful. One artwork is inspired by the might of the Sumo wrestler, one by the beauty of the Cherry Blossom season. Another room becomes a forest of bamboo and one a colorful public bathhouse complete with views of Mount Fuji and comic characters taking a dip in the waters.My personal favourite was the most recently completed artist’s room ‘Geisha goldfish’ which took the artist Aki Narita seven months to complete. It is a beautiful series of murals which cover the walls of the entire room. The colourful Geisha keep watch over the bed in the centre of the room and the bright red goldfish swim all over the walls, the ceiling and even off into the bathroom!Ms Narita said “When I looked out of the window, I felt like I was inside an aquarium.”The fish give the feeling of floating and in ancient times a dream of being in a room surrounded by goldfish that are lucky charms would bring good luck to the customers who stayed there. It is stunning.Another favourite was the Zodiac room where painter Ryosuke Yasumoto decorated a room themed on the 12 signs of the Zodiac, while staying at the hotel for 11 days last year. "I will be happy if the guests can sense the world of the humorous, old folk tale of the 12 signs of the Zodiac," said Yasumoto about the room filled with lively images of the animals.The cat and weasel, which are not included in the 12 signs but appeared in the folk tale about how they missed out on being chosen, are included in the room decoration. Yasumoto makes the most of the three-dimensional canvas and visitors lying on the bed can make eye contact with the tiger painted on the back wall through a mirror or spot a monkey hiding behind the curtain.Every room in the Park Hotel has its own fabulous view out over this unique city. Right outside the hotel is a first class view of the famous Tokyo tower which is modelled on the Eiffel tower in Paris. The tower has its own impressive illuminations at night and it stands out among the stunning space age skyline. At 333m high it is 13m taller than the French tower and is a symbol of the city’s post WWII re birth. It looks rather retro among the other ultra-modern buildings.The hotel is in a great location close to the world renowned shopping district of Ginza with lots of up market stores (including the biggest Uniqlo in japan) and there are also lots of art galleries and theatres nearby including the Kabuki-za Theatre.By contrast, just around the corner under the railway tracks near Shimbasi station is a network of little alleyways with tiny stand up bars and restaurants where crowds of office workers descend to eat drink and talk. Another fascinating snapshot of alternative Japanese culture.The staff at the Park Hotel make you feel very welcome indeed. They are super attentive, have very good English and are actually quite charming. One lady on the desk even apologised for our recent earthquake experience! If you are going to the Far East I cannot recommend this fabulous hotel highly enough for your very own lost in translation experience.Check out my blog at Eccentric England for some gorgeous pics of the rooms
user_name:
Elaine W
Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom

review_body: Very convenient location. Lots of restaurants and the trains are close by. The buffet breakfast was just mediocre and very expensive so wouldn't recommend that to anyone. The room was a little on the smal size but apparently by Tokyo standards not too bad. Great view of Tokyo tower and Mt. Fuji.

This appears to be a new hotel excellently located next to the Shiodome metro and a short walk from Shimbashi JR station from where you can use a JR Rail Pass to get to Tokyo, Shibuya and Shinjuku JR stations. Rooms weren't massive but this is the norm for Tokyo where space is at a premium. It was a little hard to find at first - reception is on the 25th floor of an office block but it means the views of Tokyo are brilliant. Service was friendly and attentive. One quibble is that the bar closed a little early at 10.30pm on Sunday and Monday but in all other respects this is a very good choice for both business or leisure and at the rate I got was great value for money. Recommended.

Found the hotel really good great location had washing machines which was a bonus but pillows not comfortable but would definitely stay again easy to get between train stations once oriented yourself .

Great value for money! I stayed in the standard room, which was plenty enough - clean, quiet, with a great view. Staff is attentive and speaks good English. Best part is the area - you are right on top of the metro station, right by the station of the special train that goes to the Odiba island and very close to the JR train station. Additionally, the area itself is not that turisty, but very entertaining (restaurants, slots, karaoke), but still within a walking distance to eg. Ginza, fish market, Kabuki theater, or even Roppongi, if you are willing to walk about 20 min (metro ride takes only slightly less than a walk). Lovely Hamarikyu Gardens are also right by.

Poor value for money. First two nights i booked the corner King Room - this was good, but expensive. Nice views, good size room (but not a king bed, its just two twins pushed together). Next 4 nights in a standard room. Noisy vent, noise from shower drain every time above bathrooms were used, stank of smoke when ever air con was on. Complained but they wouldn't do anything. With no breakfast included, its too expensive and has poor customer service. Stayed at the Monterey in Kyoto for next part of holiday. Same room quality, with breakfast, half the price of the Park Hotel

Booked the Park Hotel because of the rooms decorated by artists. Ours was the Washi room, we really liked it. The paper (washi) art is very nice and the wall paintings were also to our liking. Nice detail: the artist tells on the TV about the room. So, room was good - great Tokyo view as well. What we wondered about was why the reception is in the best part of the lobby, with a great view. Pity you are only there when you need the staff. The Conrad next door, has the lounge area with the top view. Their designer made the better choice I would say. The sun umbrella's in the lobby, what they are doing there is a mystery. Turning a large, high, interesting space into someting boring. But, we were only there for breakfast, so not an issue. Breakfast was OK, first morning lukewarm, other 2 mornings nice and warm. Staff is helpfull, location is good, room comfortable. I would like to give good and not average, but after average comes very good and that is too much.

Stayed f0r 10 days and loved it. Access to every station in Tokyo. Very clean, good English speaking staff. Lovely decor, housekeeping staff attentive and quick to respond. New Art Cafe has some very nice quick lunch meals, Bakery to die for Tateru Yoshino. Pity it didn't open at 8am and not 9am. Room not large, but that is not an issue for us. Great view of Tokyo tower and Mt Fuji on a clear day from our room. Overall and great choice for a reasonably priced hotel in Tokyo. Non Smoking is the best a hotel could decide to do for its quests. Rail noise is a little annoying, so bring earplugs. Wi fi never missed a beat.

This is gem of a hotel. Not too big and in a perfect location. It occupies the top 10 floor of an iconic Tokyo building and has fantastic views over the Tokyo Tower and Mount Fuji on a good day. The reception area restaurant is casual with a small menu but with very delicious food and a good choice of wines. The staff are super and I would definitely recommend this hotel.

The hotel is very modern and is in a great location. Rooms are small compared to European or American standards, but big for Tokyo, but we requested a room on the tower side as high up as possible and is worth the extra charge (10,000 yen per night) as the views over Tokyo were amazing! The hotel is circa 30 mins train ride from Haneda airport and very near to all the touristy attractions. We loved Tokyo and would certainly stay at this hotel again and recommend to others. Tip for Tokyo though, pre-order a Japanese sim data card and have it delivered to the hotel as we found this essential for getting around!

the location is good and the hotel is ok. rooms are small, but it's ok if you are planning to explore the city and use the room only to take a shower and go to sleep. the receptionists were mostly ok, but there were a few who were completely lacking manners. they seemed annoyed by our questions and were not helpful at all. for example we asked to show us were we could find an ATM and the explanation was so bad, that we could not find the ATM. same thing when we asked to show us how to reach the metro. in general, they did not put any effort in trying to make us feel welcomed and comfortable. i would not pick this hotel again.

If you want a great view of tokyo tower, you should stay at this hotel. When we first arrived, it was a little bit difficult to find the hotel but once you get used to it, you will find it easy especially that it is near the shiodome station. The staff were helpful and the rooms are clean. There is a water vending machine in each floor as well as ice vending machine which was great. There is also tokyo guide booklet in the lobby area. you can find a supermarket just outside the hotel.

This is our 7th visit to Japan, and we always stay at the Park. It ticks all the boxes for us. The location is great. About 5 minutes to the JR Shimbassis Station. The rooms are clean, hotel has got good English & the service is exceelantKev & Anne Rogers Australia

Very nice hotel but over designed. After a 12 hour flight I need directions to find the hotel and then the reception clearly indicated. This hotel fails on both counts. after getting off the elevator at 25 there are absolutely NO signs for reception - you stagger around until you either bump into the area (off to the RHS), someone answers your questions, or you give up and go somewhere else. The room was great except for bedside lights that cannot be turned on or off when in bed!! Smart designing.The restaurant in the lobby is an over designed disaster. The chairs for most of it are between Japanese seating and western type seating - so you sit about 12" off the floor. This makes eating totally uncomfortable. Some interior designer went mad designing this. Have them sit there and eat. They either have to sit on the edge of the seat and eat, sit back in the chair (as meant to happen) and bend double, or stand. All ways are non-human like.

My husband and I stayed here in May 2015. The hotel is near two subway stations, the staff is extremely helpful and gracious, and we had great views of Tokyo from our room. I notice some posters say the hotel is expensive. Maybe we got a good deal, but our rate was extremely reasonable. I would highly recommend the hotel.

A bit difficult to find, but once there there is an ease underground connection to many places. Our City Queen room was spacious (for Tokyo standards) with a nice view and a comfortable bed. Breakfast includes both western and Japanese food of good quality. We really enjoyed our stay.

We had to change our plans and spend an extra 2 nights in Tokyo, and due to a festival the choice was limited. The room had an amazing view from the 33rd floor and was "artist themed". I am sure some of them are really interesting, but ours looked like a five year old had been let loose in a white room with a pot of black paint. The breakfast was very good and the staff were reasonably helpful, but the room rate was nearly twice the price of the hotel we moved onto, which was almost as nice. The other problem was the labyrinth underneath. We spent ages finding the hotel from the station and then getting back to the station - we seemed to finish up going a different way each time - very confusing.

I found my experience here to be an enjoyable one albeit with a few minor complaints. Food is overpriced but so are 99% of other hotels. Room rates a little expensive but with the advent of people renting out rooms in their house or entire apartments which is becoming more and more popular I think hotels will have to reduce their rates in order to attract people back. Getting sidetracked here lol. The quality of room service was very good and the breakfast buffet also was good quality. I spent quite a few hours in the cocktail bar which has an awesome view of Tokyo's business & shopping district. The prices for drinks was cheap when compared to my city of Melbourne ($25AUD for an Appletini??). My room was a Queen with a view of the Tokyo Skytree and it looked amazing at night, so very happy with that and the quality of the bed and fittings in my room. WiFi also in every room with very good speeds.I also think it's great that the hotel is supporting local artists with their work displayed throughout the hotel and in peoples rooms (higher price) and in the smoking room. Lastly, when you arrive there is no hotel lobby on the ground floor which was a little confusing. You need to go to your right to the elevators and go to the 25th floor where you'll be greeted.Overall my experience here was a positive one and would recommend this hotel.

Very comfortable, modern hotel with mostly foreign clientele. Excellent service from staff, English speaking staff were easy to communicate with. Beautiful views from all sides and all floors as the hotel is located on the 25th - 34th floors of the Shiodome Media Tower. Close to everything by rail - a couple of stations are right outside the hotel door. On the edge of Ginza. Great, centrally located hotel. Very clean and comfortable room.

We found a decent fare for this hotel so I decide to book it.We arrived at night and it was a little confusing arriving there but once you know the area is a very nice and easy walk from the subway.The hotel is on the top of a big building so the lobby is on floor 24.Check in was very friendly staff, I asked for a room with a view to Tokyo tower butThat was more expensive, also we were offered a bigger room for more money but we were not going to be in the room all day.The room was ok very basic and clean ( it would be ok if I haven't seen all this pictures with very nice roomsWith paints ) our room was very basic.Nice view from the room but for the price I would rather stay at a basic hotel with a regular view and less expensive.You are paying more for the view. So if you don't mind the view there are many basic hotels.It was ok

The hotel is conveniently located to Tsukiji Market and Shimbashi and Shiodome metro stations. The rooms were clean and included good size bathrooms. Restaurants are a plenty around the area and the Ginza shopping district is within walking distance.

I wrote to the hotel that it was my birthday and got a surprise upgrade to Tokyo Tower view. The hotel is very conveniently located to visit the convention hall at Big Sight as well as touring around the Ginza area. There is a small family mart right at the building where the hotel is located which I find very useful especially when I arrived late at night and was hungry but all the shops have closed. Another note of improvement for the hotel is to offer room service at least till midnight.

Amazing view.Beautiful room, great service. Well located.Breakfast is ok, there is almost what you expect for a continental breakfast. The staff was very nice and did what they could to help us ! I recommend it !

Fresh, clean and modern hotel, with a wide choice of restaurants in the building and nearby. Ideally located and highly convenient as the Shiodome subway station is one of the basement floors. Rooms were spotless, staff were so helpful with ANY questions you might have, and I would definitely stay here again. Highly recommended!!!

We stayed at the Park Hotel for 5 nights at the beginning of May and then for 1 night at the end of our trip and everything was perfect.It was relatively easy to find after following the directions on the website and a 5 minute walk from Shimbashi Station which is on a JR line so great for a JR Pass.We stayed in a queen room with a view of Tokyo Tower. The view was amazing and on a clear day we saw Mt Fuji.The beds are comfortable and the room was spacious for Japan. Staff were friendly and helpful. If you are planning a trip somewhere it's a good idea to ask them first. They will show you the quickest route and give you a map. The Park Hotel is based around a walkway with multiple levels. There were lots of restaurants and cafes nearby and a small food shop at the ground level below the hotel.The buffet breakfast was the best we had in Japan and offered lots of variety.

Great choice for foreigners staying in Tokyo. Staff speak English and close to train statons, Ginza etc. Plenty of resturants and bars nearby. Rooms are clean and decent size for Tokyo. Easy to get to by mono rail and train if coming from Haneda airport.

Beautiful hotel with very nice interior. Great service! Rooms a little bit too small. We stayed in a room with Tokyo Tower View: View was realy wonderful and on two days we could even see Mount Fuji ...

Only stayed for 1 night at this hotel. Check-in was easy and they even gave me a complimentary beverage of either green tea or sake. I had an artist's queen room and it was very clean, brightly lit, and comfortable, albeit a bit small. Even though I was on the 31st floor, I could faintly hear the train station below me. There were two train stations (Shimbashi and Shiodome) in the area so it was very easy to get around. With directions from the concierge to the fish market at 4 am, it was a short walk from the hotel. Other than that, I didn't find much in the area to do.

The views from this hotel are amazing. Our room was on the top floor and it was beautiful looking out the window at Tokyo. The location is good - walkable to the fish market, which is handy if you're trying to go to the tuna auction and close to 2 subways. Not sure if it was just us, but we did find it confusing to work our way back from shimbashi station to the hotel, so handy to have a gps map if possible. The only thing that lets this great hotel down is the shower as it can only point in one direction and compared to the quality of everything else this is a shame.

Stayed for a week while site seeing in Tokyo with a friend.Arrived early and our standard room wasn't ready so for the equivalent of £23 a night we upgraded to a spa suite which was lovely. The fish on the bed were a bizarre but cool touch!The hotel is very clean and all staff were helpful and friendly. Lovely toiletries in the bathroom (I believe we got extra such as body scrub etc because of the type of room).Location wise it was great for seeing the City being located next to two Underground stops.The breakfast was pretty basic and nothing to write home about but it set us up for the day so there are no complaints. There are a number of coffee shops nearby too.A nice place to base yourself when visiting Tokyo. I can't really rave about this hotel as nothing was outstanding but I have nothing to complain about either so it gets a solid 4 out of 5 :-)

...travelling would be less stressful and more enjoyable.Stayed in a small room which was very comfortable and ample for one person. Room had a range of amenities including the standard toiletries in Japan. Staff were friendly and polite. Arrived at 9am and was told I would have to wait for check in at 2pm. Good complimentary wifi.

I recently spent 3 nights at the Park Hotel and found it to be very good indeed. They did make one mistake or rather the Manager did! He gave me the wrong time to send my luggage on to my next destination which could been very inconvenient. However the staff dealt with the situation promptly, efficiently and professionally. The bed was extremely comfortable and the room was very pleasant to relax in. The breakfast wasn't perhaps the best but it was nonetheless good enough. The hotel environment was great with a big emphasis on art. In general the staff were excellent and I would have no hesitation staying there again.
Cozy room, great view, nice service, okay location, and fair price

The staff is unbeatable and the rooms are great. I had a standard queen room and it was perfect for just me. With two people, it might get a bit crowded depending on your personal preferences. Great location for accessing different districts.

The room I checked in smelled. I mean really bad as if I was stuck in an ancient basement storage with tons of unwashed,dirty clothes. Got a new room the next day, and found a piece of hair on the bed and in the bathroom. Unreliable housekeeping but polite and vey helpful staff.

Park Hotel Tokyo is chic, modern and being on the 25th floor and up at the Shidome Media Tower, the rooms have a stunning view of the city and its surroundings. The rooms are of good size, considering the hotel is located in the most expensive city in the world. While the hotel is not in the heart of Ginza District, it is very walkable to Ginza. The Tokyo Tower and the Zojoji Temple are both within walking distance from the hotel as well. Bus and train stations are just a short distance away, should you wish to venture outside of Tokyo.We have stayed in Ginza District for a few nights and have purposely sought to stay here to change the environment, away from all the shopping and crowds. Besides we want to sample more on how the local lives outside of Ginza, and we are happy that we have done this. The staff is very helpful and courteous. We actually have the good fortune of unknowingly ran into Yoshiaki Hayashi San, Director and General Manager of the hotel, when we asked him for directions to the Zojoji Temple. As it happened, he was going to the sister hotel (Shiba Park Hotel) for a meeting and he offered us a ride as the temple is near Shiba Park Hotel. We are thankful of this random act of kindness and it speaks volume of the leadership for this chain of hotels.
user_name:
Goavidtraveler
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: This hotel has amazing views, the rooms are small but great and are super super clean! The area was under construction when we were there so it was a little less accessible from ground level but there are so many ways to get to the street and metro that it was still amazing. Would go back in a heartbeat! :)Also it had free wifi!
user_name:
Anna S
New York City, New York

review_body: Park Hotel Tokyo was an oasis in the middle of amazing Tokyo. The value, location, friendliness and cleanliness of the hotel was impeccable. If we ever return to Tokyo, this will be our home away from home again.

overall good place to stay. some English speaking staff. and also great care and customer pre follow up. what i mean is: i needed the hotel to help me with booking Japanese restaurants a month in advance, follow up and delivered on their promises. and even had direction, pictures and re confirmation ready when we arrived. while in stay the room was great, one thing might be the hotel itself is abit hard to find since the shiodome is all highways and hard to cross unless you go on the top walk ways.

It is a third time I'm staing in the hotel for business. I like the hotel very much as located in perfect location - 2-5 min work from Shimbashi and Ginza area.The staff is very professional and friendly, the rooms are clean and the total atmoshpere in the hotel permits to relax after long bisuness day.The hotel is very quiet with no disturbing noises from any source. The breakfast is rich and can satisfy any taste.The hotel welcomes local atrists, what is coloring the atmphere of the lobby and the floors.Bottom line - very good value for reasonable money. Defenitely will select it next time visiting Tokyo.

Wow! Just wow! There is no other word to describe the view once you enter the room - at least if you are lucky enough to have a room facing Tokyo Tower. However, the hotel lobby is on the 25th floor and all the rooms are above it, so you're pretty much guaranteed to have a great view whichever room you get. The hotel is a little difficult to find, and confusingly there is a Royal Park Hotel in a nearby tower which is also called Shiodome, but once you find the right place you will probably not want to leave, even though you are close to Ginza with its world-class shopping. We found ourselves just sitting by the windows admiring the night lights of the tremendous city of Tokyo.

This hotel made our entire experience wonderful! First off, the staff is so amazing! As soon as we walked in, they welcomed us and took our bags. They even held our bags for 2 days while we went to kyoto even though we were not checking in until we got back. They were focused on their guests and providing them with the best service. The only downfall for us is that the dinner was over priced for the amount of food we received. But there are SO MANY restaurants nearby to compensate for that one little downfall. We walked to Imperial Palace, The Fish Market, Ginza District (which has tons of food), Hibaya Park, and the Himaruku Gardens. The subway is very close by. But why this made our stay incredible is because of the VIEW from the rooms. Pay a little extra and that the view of the tokyo tower. TRUST ME!!! this isn't an average view. ITs an amazing view because the rooms start from the 26th floor so you are high up and also there is a windowsill in the room and you can read or just relax near the window with an amazing view of the tokyo tower. Even though the room is smaller than we are used to, it just didnt matter. The rooms are so cozy and the hotel itself is very modern and very conveniently located. Keep in mind that to go to the fish market, you have to be there by 4 am or earlier and there are no subways running at that time. So you pretty much have to stay at a hotel that is walking distance (like this one) or take a taxi. Also, this hotel is near a ton of malls, and highrise buildings which have plenty of food options if you don't want to take a 15 minute walk to Ginza. Really Really recommend this hotel and for the price, the view is just unbeatable. Free Wifi too!

*Amazing view of the Tokyo Tower (make sure you double check while booking)*Convenient location for public transport ("Walking distance" to Shimbashi station but can be tricky as you will have to navigate the underground shopping complex; for the yurikamome line it cannot be easier because there is a connecting bridge; you also have the Oedo line which is relatively easy to get to)*Walking distance to many tourists spots (short walk to Ginza, Tsukiji Fish Market, Hama Rikyu etc)*Room luxuriously comfortable and very good size (plenty of space to put your luggages and shopping)*Staff very attentive (from front desk reception to room service; reach out to them if you need to book a restaurant or need direction to anywhere)A perfect hotel for a perfect trip!(The only negative would unsurprisingly be the cost. For a hotel this nice and central it certainly comes with a price tag. However, I do believe they offer very competitive prices; I would suggest do you research and shop around if cost is a concern. Also keep an eye on special offers and packages from the hotel itself or other vendors.)

I was part of a group of 7 who stayed there. For most it was a first visit to Japan. We arrived at Tokyo Haneda airport after flying from the UK via Paris, and where met by a member of the hotel staff for the transfer. Sorry but I can't remember his name. He was friendly and spoke good English.The transfer took around 30 minutes. Narrita is further. We pulled up and hotel staff promptly offloaded our bags while our guide took us to check-in which was done quickly and by friendly staff. We ate breakfast there each day. It is served buffet style with a range of Japanese and western food on offer. A good chance to try something new.The hotel is located around a 10 minute walk from the Tokyo version of Bond Street. So lots of shopping and dining options within easy reach. Public transport to explore the city and further are easy to get to.Our room was small by UK standards but I gather Tokyo land prices are very high. Our room was spotlessly clean with a good view of the city.I was expecting high drinks prices at the hotel but was pleasantly surprised. A beer worked out at around £4.50 in English. Which is cheaper than a lot of UK high end bars and hotels.

Our stay at Park Hotel was lovely. The view is hands down worth paying a little more for. At night I would sit on the windowsill and just watch Tokyo do it's thing. It's marvellous. The room was small, but that goes with the territory so there is nothing we can do about that. The amenities were everything I would expect from a hotel of this calibre and the location is prime. 5-7 minute walk to the subway/JR trains via the means of a covered walkway which helps when its snowing/raining out. The reception staff were welcoming and happy to help with directions if we needed them. The bed was just amazing... not sure if it's because we had been staying traditional prior to our stay at this hotel, so any mattress would have been splendid, but this one was pretty perfect. It is a business hotel so there is plenty of foot traffic at different times of the day, but for location, view and price you can't go wrong.

Liked the hotel overall,very close to Ginza and the Fish Market. The corner room with Tokyo tower view is great!. Food was good quality though a bit pricey. The walk to the subway and trains in Shimbashi station was a little far from the hotel though its a underground and covered walkway. We had some trouble buying train tickets from the JR ticket station since they don't take US credit cards so the concierge at the hotel did buy it for us and charged to the hotel. But you are better off buying a Japan Rail Pass because its a bit of nightmare when JR will not take your credit card to buy train tickets. Good service from the hotel to help us out with the train tickets. Thank you Miss Shimose! Some US ATM cards also don't work in Japan so bring cash!

We stayed here for 7 nights. Pros.Rooms are located on the top floor of an office building. In room amenities were useful. Great Breakfast options for international visitors. Thank you for the cappuccino with hot milk!Staff is very helpful and always smiling.Connected via subway to 2 transport lines. Tokyo Station is only a few minutes via the subwayTwo Cat or Yamato Service in lobby itself was very helpful and we did not have to lug luggage around cities and hotels.Good wifi connection.Water/Ice Dispenser and Laundry in Floor.Charging Dock by the bed!ConsNot many tourist spots in the area itself, which means you have to trek via taxi or train stations. We stayed in a premier room with a view of the tokyo tower. But it was still tight for two tall people with more than 2 bags.While, this is a fine hotel, there was no additional advantage to staying here for 7 nights other than the price. Would have been nice if the hotel have provided additional perks for longer stay guests like free access to happy hour or laundry or higher floor room or dessert.We would stay here again for the price and service.

The Park Hotel is a to quality hotel in which westerners will find themselves very comfortable. The hotel is conveniently located near a JR line station and several metros. It can seem a bit of a hike when first finding the place in the maze of underground pedestrian tunnels but we discovered the quickest route via the third floor entrance. Decent sized rooms by Tokyo standards. Excellent staff. Wonderful "art" motif throughout provides some interest in what could otherwise be a bland and functional hotel.

I had a room facing to the TV tower, the view was just so spectacular and the room was clean and tidy.We loved Japanese food a lot and the breakfast was outstanding with traditional food. Staffs were great and helpful. Having drinks in the bar, it was a breathtaking evening. Enjoyable stay.

Great location; buzzling by day and quiet by night and close to great transport links. The hotel starts from the 25th floor of the Shidome Media Tower, soaring over the Tokyo skyline with big windows and stylish decor. The rooms we're impeccably clean with all the anemities you could possibly ask for. The staff is fantastic; very friendly and charming and the level of service granted is amazing. The perfect hotel for our Tokyo visit, we could not ask for more and would book it again in a heartbeat!

Absolutely my favorite hotel during my Japan tour. Beautiful view, central position, near metro lines, Ginza and Tsukiji (the famous Fish market) in walking distance, helpfull staff, good breakfast (extra charge) Just loved the stay, thank you!

We stayed here for two nights before heading off to other parts of Japan. The rooms are a good size, with table, chair and window seat where you can sit and admire the view, plus plenty of space for two big suitcases. The room was spotless and well equipped. We had a room overlooking the Tokyo tower, and it was nice to overlook the city (when it wasn't raining!). We appreciated the fast WiFi too!It's a really handy location if you're coming in from Haneda - tip, get the monorail to Shiodome rather than Shinjuku as the hotel entrance is right next to the station. It's also a good location to get to Tokyo station for onwards travel.

My last stop in Tokyo tis time round we decided to pay a bit more for the convenience of leaving for airport. This hotel has the Limousine pick up. Location was great n was pleasantly surprised to be upgraded to a room that my window faces directly at the Tokyo Tower. Staffs were very professional n friendly. Tried the hotel lounge n was surprised by the quality of food they served. Definitely had a great ending trip in this hotel. Will certainly return with kids.

We enjoyed the stay at Park Hotel very much. This is a first class hotel, very much service oriented with staff that gives you the feeling, day and night, that it is doing everything possible to give you a pleasant and agreeable time. The staff at all positions are very friendly, most of them speak English. Very well located.This is certainly a hotel I will recommend to all our friends.I have the pleasure to mention in this TripAdviser report, Concierge Ms. Nozomi Shimose.Her fantastic performance, patience and her kind and sympathetic personality are the basis of her professional approach, tools which lead to solve all our difficulties. Thanks to her devotion we could enjoy to a maximum the limited time we spent in Tokyo.

Very convenient location, very sleek and artsy hotel with great staff. Rooms are well-thought and planned, and very comfortable. we had a dinner at Atrium restaurant which was fantastic. We'll definitely stay again.

Could it be that I was in one of the artist rooms when I was last here a few months ago? Or was there a change in management? In any case, the experience was different. During my first visit, the staff sought solutions like the best hotels (and businesses in general) of the world do. They went the extra mile to do so. This time, they just recited policy. There were 3 of us in our troop, arriving in Tokyo at different times. Many days in advance I asked the hotel to arrange an early check-in for my colleague. All I received in return was an explanation of policy and the recommendation of a non-option... to change the reservation to check in a day earlier earlier, thus buying an additional room-night. The morning of his arrival, I inquired about the status of the early check-in. They had no record of it and proceeded to recite policy again. The room I had was extremely small. Not worth the price I paid. But the really BIG turn-off was this... Our meeting schedule changed and we had to overnight in Nagoya. We had to change our reservation from 5 days straight to 4 days with a 1-day gap in the middle. They took advantage of this and charged a higher rate for the rooms after the re-checkin. One of the keys to maintaining a long-term business relationship is this:In any and every negotiation, never go for the last coin on the table. Leave it. They went for the last coin and thereby lost our trust. They chose greed over partnership. Nobody even asked if we would often be in Tokyo in the future. On a positive note, The views are great. The location is great. Quick walk to Shimbashi station. The lobby / atrium is impressive.

Great location with easy access to the subway system and the rest of the city. The staff was extremely friendly and helpful. Room was clean and a good place to call home for a week. Would highly recommend this hotel.

We stayed here one night - lovely room, beautiful view - ask for view of Tokyo Tower - excellent food. Drawbacks - darn windows don't open even a crack - and located on the 25th floor, which means you're far from the action and every time we had to go into the city we got lost in the maze of high rises. So overall a fine hotel but next time we would choose differently. Also pricey.
user_name:
Kenneth P
New York City, New York

review_body: Park Hotel is located from the 25th floor up of the Shiodome Tower, above Shiodome Station. It's a seven minute walk to Shimbashi Station to get on the JR Yamonote line or subway, which is confusing the first time but you soon get your bearings. JR line is about 29 minutes to Shinjuku, a little less to Shibuya and only about 5 mins to Tokyo Station. Locally you can walk to Tsujiki Fish Market in 15 minutes and the Kabuki Theatre in even less.Hotel service is excellent, room was very comfortable, well-sized with superb views across Tokyo including the Tokyo Tower. Fast Wifi. We had no complaints at all.

We recently spent one night at this hotel and I wished we could stay longer. We had an amazing view of the Tokyo Tower and the hotel staff really go out of their way to provide excellent service. The concierge helped with dinner reservations, Karaoke recommendations, arranged special transport for us to the airport, and provided directions in Japanese that we could show our taxi drivers to make our travel even easier. The hotel is beautiful and the neighborhood is great. Didn't even have to leave the building to get to the train station. I thought the room rates were very reasonable too. Free wifi and multiple options to dine inside the hotel. The rooms are comfortable and they even offered something called a pillow fitting which I happily tried. Basically, three different pillows were brought to my room to help me find just the right one for my own personal comfort - that was first class service!

My husband and I stayed here for 3 night when on our honeymoon. The location is good. There is a metro station in the building and train station 5 minutes walk away. Breakfast was reasonable. Far from the worst we had on our 3 week trip but nothing special. Room was lovely with plenty of space in a double by Japanese standards. There were all the ammenities you would expect and the staff were all very helpful.

We stayed at the Park Hotel twice on our trip to Japan, we left one suitcase at the hotel and it was delivered to our room on our return a week later. The hotel is located close to the Shiodome and Shimbashi stations which we used to get around the city. It was a bit tricky locating the hotel at first due to the number of overhead walkways and the fact the lobby is actually on the 25th floor!The staff were very friendly and helpful, on our booking we had noted we were on our honeymoon and the hotel provided a free bottle of champagne which was a nice touch. The rooms were clean and there was a full range of toiletries provided in the bathroom. The bath was a little small for my 6'1" husband but no smaller than any of the other hotels we stayed in, in Japan. The views were lovely from the room and from the lobby and even in the lift!On our second stay there was a slight spicy smell on our floor but you couldn't smell it in the room and we could here people moving about on the floor above us.Overall I would recommend this hotel for a short stay in Tokyo.

Stayed here for 5 nights. Great location for Tsujiki Fish Market and Hama Rikyu Gardens. Shiodome station can be accessed by the walkway that is accessible on the 3rd floor and Shimbashi station is a short walk away. One thing to be aware of is that the hotel is on the 25th floor of the ?Media Tower and if you are dropped off by taxi/shuttle is that you will have to carry your cases up in the lift on your own so might be worthwhile if you have a stack of cases for one of you to go up in the lift and get one of the porters to come down with a Hotel Trolley.We arrived early but the Hotel asked us to come back at 12:00pm (and to leave our luggage there whilst room was being finalised) and we simply took a short walk to Hama Rikyu Gardens which was no hardship!Room was too small for us - we were on the end of a four week tour of New Zealand and had two cases and three bags. Room we had would be ideal for someone with modest luggage or using the luggage forwarding service NAME and just taking a small bag to this Hotel. There were art installations taking place whilst we were there - not sure if this is a regular feature but it was interesting. Breakfast was good and a choice of table heights if your first seating it's not too your liking. Concierge facilities were very good.Would be happy to stay again.

Stayed four nights in a queen Tokyo Tower facing room. View was lovely (especially at night) and the room was cozy but had a comfortable bed. The bathroom was small with top notch amenities and fixtures. I couldn't help but love the fancy commode with its warming seat! We used both the laundry and pressing services during our stay, everything came back perfect and beautifully packaged. Hotel staff was very friendly and helpful in providing directions or arranging cabs. The location was excellent and the main reason for choosing the hotel. It is situated right above Shiodome Station (Oedo Line) with direct access from the elevators and Shinbashi (Ginza & Asakusa Lines) is easily accessible through the pedestrian underpass (just beyond Shiodome). Tsukiji Market was just one stop on the Oedo line from Shiodome and we found it very easy to get everywhere else mainly using Shinbashi. The above ground Yurikamome private line was also located just outside the hotel as well. We would stay here again on a future trip.

Close by Shinbashi station this hotel is well organised, comfortable and well equipped. It is a modern western style hotel with a soaring central atrium. The bar does very good food- the steak and chips are particularly well done. There are also several restaurants. Breakfast is an OK buffet style. Not a super luxury hotel but definitely worth 4 stars.

Location and view are pretty hard to beat and it was easy to get to the places we wanted from here. Also lots of food and shopping in the area as well as the famous fish market. The rooms were clean but wish we had of gotten one of the painted rooms. I think this would of freshened up the room a bit. Our bathroom was nice and we slept well. I would recommend asking for a high floor though they all are pretty high as it is. Breakfast was good as well and felt a little more like a restaurant compared to a buffet than other places we staed. Overall I would recommend staying here if visiting as for the price it is a very nice hotel.

We stayed here for a few nights at the end of a two week trip to Japan. Very helpfully they let us store our luggage while we visited some other areas of the country so we didn't have to carry everything with us. The staff were very helpful, they also helped us arrange airport transfer on the last day. The rooms are pretty spacious for Tokyo, and the view is incredible - even if you are not on the side of the Tokyo tower.

A short walk from the rail station we nevertheless got mixed up and went to the Royal Park Hotel close by. All smooth when we eventually arrived at the correct hotel. We were located in a corner room with great views of the Sky Tree. Comfortably furnished and room enough for three. My husband visited the spa and was very impressed with the area and the skill of the therapist. We ate in the lounge area as the restaurants were fully booked and the food and drink were of good quality although the selection was limited. Didn't stay long enough to do anything else but on the basis of our experience would recommend.

Tourists may like this hotel given its relatively reasonable prices, but businessmen BEWARE! The rooms are very small, carpets dirty and very few amenties (like soap bars in bathroom). Worse....WiFi at this hotel is AWFUL. They say its slow because too many people use it. No different that any other hotel. There WiFi is simply not updated and not compatible with newest tablets and computer devices. If you want to work out, they have what they call a "personal gym" by reservation only! It is tiny on the 26th floor and contains a weight machine that is very sqeaky and barely works as well as a bike and elypitical machine. If you want a night cap in the lobby, arrive before 10 pm...they stop serving then. The manager on duty, Mr Abe, is your classic "Hai, Hai, Hai" guy that does nothing!

I wish we'd had more time to enjoy this hotel. My wife and I stayed two nights in March. We were pretty jetlegged, so slept most of the time. The room is certainly dark, quiet and gave us the sound sleep we needed. The toiletries in the bathroom were unusually good. We wanted to take some with us!If you arrive at Shinbashi station it is really worth - in fact it's essential to do so - having a map ready when you exit the station. The road, overhead walkway and rail system is complicated. You can enter the hotel's building on various floors, but reception for the hotel is on the first floor. We found it interesting and unusual that all the porters and luggage movers were young ladies!We enjoyed the nearby 'Victorian pub' for beer and food, although don't like to admit it.The hotel organised us a well-priced and timely bus to the airport.

We have just returned from a tour of Japan and stayed at the Park Hotel in Tokyo for three nights. It is centrally situated, close to the Ginza district and within walking distance of the Imperial Palace. We had a City twin room which wasn't huge although that seems to be the case throughout Japan with some exceptions. The bed was comfortable (although the pillows were a bit hard for our tastes). We didn't sleep terribly well but I think that was due to jet lag rather than the room or bed. It seemed quiet enough although you could hear the trains passing through the station which is adjacent to the hotel but this wasn't enough to prevent us getting off to sleep. The hotel is labelled as an "art hotel" and there were various installations/exhibitions in the lobby while we were there.Restaurants included a French restaurant (which we tried and found that to be very good although purists might nitpick about whether the menu was entirely French. We had a decent bottle of red wine which, thankfully, was not served chilled as everywhere else we ate served red wine VERY chilled unless you specifically ask for it not to be. We found prices reasonable for a large hotel. There is also a Japanese restaurant which we had planned to eat in but this was full on the evening we tried to get a table, so it may be better to book if you are keen to try this restaurant. There is also a cafe area in the lobby where light meals and drinks are available. It took us a while to find the bar which is through an entrance at the back of the lobby area. However, the bar staff made excellent cocktails and there are floor to ceiling windows offering great views over the Tokyo skyline. The only real negative aspect was the service in the cafe area. There seemed to be quite a few waiting staff standing around but without any direction and it seemed a little chaotic. All the staff were pleasant and helpful but communication can be difficult as few people speak much English (I put my hand up - my Japanese is virtually non-existent) even in the hospitality business.Breakfast is served buffet-style in the lobby area with a good choice of different dishes available.All in all we had a very good experience at this hotel.

Hotel is connected to a walkway from the JR station Shinbashi. They have a floor full of artistic rooms, we stayed in the bamboo room. It's a good choice of hotel if you want something different but still good quality. The rooms are quite spacious and the bed is super comfy.

We stayed here twice in March 2015 and will not stay anywhere else next time. The rooms were comfortable and an adequate size especially for Tokyo. Note there is another hotel called Royal Park Hotel in Tokyo. This one is in the Shiodome tower, a block of offices with the hotel starting on the 25th floor. It is also right on top of the metro station so is very conveniently located and makes moving around the city a breeze. What so impressed me is the service - even after we had checked out. You see after checking out of the hotel, I left my wallet on the back seat of a taxi at Tokyo Central Station when were headed for Narita airport. Due to the amazing attention and caring nature of the staff at The Park Hotel my wallet arrived in Sydney 5 days later and was fully intact. Cards, cash everything! I was blown away and will only stay in this hotel next time I visit Tokyo.

I had the most wonderful experience in this hotel. Its amazing staff made all the difference. Breakfast was delicious and the waiters and waitresses were very attentive. Rooms were simple and clean.A special thanks to Mana Yoshihara, Chief Concierge; without her dedication, expertise, and help, we would have had a miserable stay in Japan. She was able to secure a rental wheelchair and have it delivered to our hotel to be used for days around the country. Thanks again... if she reads this.

we stayed here with 2 kids and it was awesome. the train station was right beneath the hotel. The buffet was great and we had this almost everyday. my kids loved the mini mart at the basement . the hotel was located in a central part of tokyo so i took the kids to many destinations including tokyo disney, mt fiji and the Ginza upscale shopping district which could be equated to time square in newyork or champs elyses in paris..The room was very nice and had amazing views of tokyo.

This hotel was in a great location near multiple train stations and easy walking distance to Ginza and the fish market! It was obviously use primarily as a business hotel so I did feel a little awkward walking round the lobby in my shorts when most others were in suits! The staff spoke perfect English and were very helpful, even helping us get to a last minute baseball game which was awesome! Would definitely recommend although if I went again I would ask for a city view like the amazing one you get in the lobby!

Got the hotel recommended by friends and it most definitely lived up to the expectations- our stay at Park Hotel was perfect!We stayed in one of the panorama rooms, which has an amazing views over Tokyo (both Tokyo tower and the harbour area). The service was excellent and we had two excellent dinners at the Hotel restaurants (when we arrived and after a loong day sightseeing Tokyo). Definitely a Hotel i would recommend!

I was there on business for 6 days. 3 days at a large global chain and I requested my local office colleagues to put me in a non-chain and what they would recommend. The hotel begins on the 25th floor of a high rise. Spectacular views, free internet all over the hotel, ample room space, and friendly staff. Great breakfast buffet with lots of choices. I really enjoyed my stay there and would go back. While I was taking the taxi most days, the subway station is right outside for easy hop to Ginza, and the JR Rail station (that connects with Tokyo Station) was helpful in taking the bullet train for my day trip out of Tokyo. My only two areas that I felt that the hotel needs improvement:a) I had to check-out in the morning from my other hotel and come here to drop my bags before heading to the office. No door man downstairs to take luggage. There is a phone, and a sign, but when I called the number, I was told 10 minutes. I waited 10 and no show so forced to go up. Hotel should have the valet available immediatelyb) Fitness room is a 1-person facility. It helps to work out after a long trip from US and keep with the schedule at the start of the day, especially since no place to run outside. You have to reserve it the night before for use. They could use a better machine in there. The bike and stair climber are both fine but the fitness machine is beat up and rusted compared to the polished shine everything else in the hotel.

Great location, staff can speak english, good breakfast, great tokyo views from the rooms.Only drawback room was small for two persons with big lugagge. Breakfast area was not big enough according to hotel size.I would repeat it without any doubt.

This was the first hotel we arrived at when visiting Tokyo. It was easy to find once we started to figure out the sky walk ways. Those were the most confusing part about finding the hotel from the train station. Once you figure out the location it's easy to find.  The lobby is located on the 25th floor. While checking you have a beautiful view of Tokyo. When we checked in we asked about upgrading our room. They said they had room and we were able to upgrade. Since it was our honeymoon they also sent champagne to our room. The room was nice. Had a nice view, the bed was a good size, the bathroom was a good size, and they had room for our luggage. The mirror in the bathroom has a fog resistant area in it. It's pretty cool! The hotel isn't located far from the JR. It just takes a little figuring out, but once you get it you get it. We got everywhere we needed to go by train. Park hotel us also really close to the fish market. They're also near alleys full of yakitori places. We loved the location of this hotel. It wasn't in a super busy part which is a nice breather from visiting the busiest spots in Tokyo. We could definitely stay here again.

Services; front desk was pleasant, all worked out. But, when we arrived our room was not ready (30 min before check-in time) and first estimate was that it takes 2 hours to be ready. After receptionist checking situation we got informed that it will be ready about 15 min. Other thing that I was surprised was that we had to ask assistance for getting our luggage to room and from lobby to down stairs; this should wok other way around. Best service experience was at breakfast. Room; spacious and light feeling; there were comfortable twin beds and one extra bed (made from sofa). Our luggage and baby strollers fitted in well. In bathroom there is a bathtub, nice to have when travelling with kids. Desk in bathroom is quite small, feeling is light and bright. Interior is modern and it suits well in this hotel in quite new skyscraper. Sound isolation was great; no noise was heard from surrounding rooms or outside.Maintenance; well, can be done better. At first dusts could be vacuum out from room footlights and bathroom floor. Bathroom could be cleaned well, there should not be hair or splash / water marks at bathtub, desk or at door. Breakfast; is served at lobby floor restaurant. Every time there was free when we arrived. Breakfast is buffet style and selection is not very wide, but good enough, hot and cold choices available. Service was good and pleasant. Baby high chairs were available. Breakfast was not included in our room price, but price was reasonable. Views; this hotel got best views of surrounding areas that I have ever seen. We could see Sky Tree and city skyline from our room. From lobby and breakfast table you can see old TV tower, Mt Fuji and city skyline. Pre request information; I have sent e-mail to hotel and asked if twin bed can be pushed together (side by side), answer was no. Reality, yes you can under bed there is wheels. In addition I asked if we can get baby bed in room, answer was no, there is no space. Reality, my opinion it would fit in room. Over all, ok but nothing more than that. Travelled with family 2 adults and 2 small children (1 and 3 years), stayed in Premium triple room.

We enjoyed our stay in this hotel. Once you understand where it is. It is fantastically located not just for when you get out of narata airport as you can take the train straight from the terminal to shimbashi station. The hotel is actually right next to shidome station but if you turns the other way you can walk to shimbashi. The view from reception is beautiful the beds are comfy and there was even one or two English speaking channels on the TV. I would stay here again on a return trip to Tokyo.Things to consider, probably better for you if you coming in from Narita airport as the journey should be closer.If you are using the subway and metro then you can buy a day pass for 1000 yen that lasts till midnight(unlimited stops)It's very close to Ginza Main Street so we ate there rather than the hotel but the menu did look nice and again for one of the restaurants would come with a great view.The staff are helpful and its a peaceful gem in a great location.

The hotel has reasonably large rooms, an excellent breakfast and the staff is very helpful. We needed help organising transfers and flowers for business partners and everything was done in the most professional way. It is not the Ritz. However, it is probably the best value for money in Tokyo.

The hotel lobby is on the 25th Floor of an office tower. Near Ginza District. Close to the fish market. We stayed on the 32nd Floor. Room small but adequate. Great city views, close to Shimbasa subway line. The breakfasts (included) were good with a nice variety of Japanese and Western offerings. Efficient porter who transferred our luggage to next destination with ease. Pretty decor with modern art displays. Some construction in area made access slightly more challenging. Would stay again.

We stayed here for 5 nights in Dec 2014 and found the Park Hotel to be a great base for exploring Tokyo. The hotel facilities are very nice, and the city view from the 25th floor lobby is spectacular. Breakfast is also very good. Navigating the streets around the hotel can be unpleasant and takes a bit of effort. But trains and subway stations are close by.

V nice room on 25th floor with tokyo tower view. Room adequate size. Decent shower although it's in the bath fixed on the wall rather than standalone. Breakfast in the coffee area at the lobby was nice - and offered a good mix of western/japanese food options. A really good location around 5min walk (through underground mall) to get to the ginza subway line (the hotel is on a different line that isn't v useful for getting to town and main sights). Hotel is about 10min walk from the train station where the monorail from haneda arrives. Free wifi in lobby but reception in room was variable.

Trendy hotel with a great location and has incredible views. They seem to host lots of art events; the night I checked in I was worried because they had real loud music in the lobby. Well music is an exaggeration, they had a bunch of young people making weird uncoordinated sounds with a variety of instruments. If you ever watched Friends and recall Ross making his “sounds” you get an accurate picture. But I digress. The point is that once I got into the elevator, I couldn’t hear any of that garbage.The room was of a decent size considering it was Tokyo. Of course very clean. Like all hotels in Japan, the toilet sprays water on your rear but this one had an added touch of having a dryer too!The place is pretty trendy and the lobby is on the 25th floor. There’s a gym but it only accommodates one person at a time and you have to make reservations; I was unable to score a time slot.If you get the munchies in between meals there is a 24 hour convenience store connected to the hotel in B2. The metro is connected to the hotel and you can catch it without stepping outside. Ginza is walking distance.

The view from our tower view bedroom was incredible, we could see Mt Fuji on clear days and the city at night was just as picturesque. The location of the hotel was a perfect base for exploring the city, in one of the quieter areas with great transport links. The concierge staff were extremely helpful with our tourist needs and very informative when it came to sightseeing and transport advice. The breakfast was one of the better ones we sampled in Japan, however not so great for vegetarians (a pattern throughout Japan). The staff were very friendly and accommodating, even when ordering room service (pizzas) at 4am to satisfy our jet lag! Room facilities were great, tea/coffee, minibar, TV (only 2 English channels), good bathroom supplies, Wi-fi, very quiet. We left our mobile phone behind and they were very helpful in arranging it's return to us.Would definitely stay again when visiting Tokyo! Great way to start your Japan adventure.

This hotel is in a great location for exploring Tokyo. Unusually, the reception is not on the ground floor but rather on the 25th floor. As a result the views from the reception are stunning. There is a perfect view over the entire city with the majestic Mount Fuji in the background. It looks great at all times of the day. Unfortunately there was a disgusting smell of cigarette smoke throughout the entire hotel. There are many people smoking in the lobby and the smoke rises through the atrium and pollutes the rest of the hotel. Disgusting. Smoking should be banned in this hotel.

We loved our stay at the Park Hotel in Tokyo. The Hotel, like many in Tokyo, starts on the 25th floor of a high-rise. The view from our room of the Tokyo tower was stunning. On a clear day we could even see Mt. Fuji in the distance. The breakfast buffet was delicious, if a bit expensive. We also enjoyed their coin-operated laundry service. The gym is a joke, a tiny room with one bike, one elliptical and one weight machine - but no free weights. Also, you have to reserve the gym the day before.
