Even going to Shisui premium outlet, just drop to Daimon metro station and take the express bus (bus lane 1), about 60-80mins. Walking distance to Tsukiji market. Hotel service was excellent initially, during just check in. The service counter notice that we are couple, so change room from 2 single bed to double bed (well done). 3 nights later while check out, notice that we are going to Hakone, provided us with all necessary information and recommended to take the 2 days pass(well done). But 1 day later, after our trip at Hokane, we re-check in the hotel (which we did informed them during the first check out that we will be back) , but during the re-check in we were given 2 single bed. A bit disappointed, but we did not pursue as this is a small issue. Overall, I very impressive hotel and I will return again.

The Park Hotel Tokyo is located in Shiodome, which is a newer area of Tokyo adjacent to Ginza and Tokyo Station. The area itself is very clean and modern, albeit a little sterile – it doesn’t have any traditional Japanese elements at all. However, the location is very good, with access to the subway, monorail and train. Personally, I’m willing to give up being in the middle of a traditional Japanese neighborhood for the convenience, etc.The hotel is near the Royal Park Hotel – do not confuse the two! As is the case with most large hotels in Tokyo, the Park Hotel is on the upper floors of an office building. The lobby is reasonably big and contains a restaurant/lounge. Check-in was smooth.My room was small, as is the case in many hotels in Japan. Furnishings were modern, and bathroom amenities were generous and varied. The room showed a few signs of wear and tear but nothing substantial. The room was quiet and the bed was very comfortable. I was very happy to spend time in the room and get work done.One of the best parts of this hotel is the Thann Spa. I didn’t get a chance to get a massage or facial, but they stock Thann products, which I was happy to purchase! (I didn’t have time to go to the Thann stores in Roppongi and Omotesando.)I was able to book this hotel at a discount (I can’t remember why/where). Provided that I can find that discount again, I’ll definitely stay there again!

This hotel is located in a large office building near the Shimbashi Train Station. You take the elevator up to the 24 th floor where you check in. The hotel staff spoke very good English and were very helpful. I found the rooms well furnished and comfortable. The service in the bar was outstanding. I liked that there were several restaurants in the hotel that served decent food. I would stay here ago. I liked the close proximity to the train station. I was unable to use the train to go to my destination without any trouble.

The hotel is located above the Shimbashi Train Station that is a short 5 minute walk through an underground passageway. The staff is very professional and most of them speak respectable English. The rooms are clean and quiet. Thank you for chopsticks Ms. Simose. We will definitely stay here again.

We thoroughly enjoyed our stay in this beautiful hotel, the room was very comfortable, with a great view of the city and nearby park. The breakfast buffet was delicious, with a wide variety of hot and cold foods.Best of all were the very courteous, helpful hotel staff, they made our stay a very happy experience, thank you!

I wasn't sure what to expect from the Park Hotel since it was a lot less expensive than some of the other hotels my travel agent recommended. I was very pleased!First, note that it's in a high rise office building. You enter on the first floor and take the elevator to the 25th floor to reception. The staff are very, very friendly and accommodating (as you might expect in Japan), and offer complimentary sake or green tea upon arrival.The rooms are very clean, a good size, and well appointed, with free, fast wifi, coffee, tea, and a small mini-bar.(Respectable) massage is available in the evenings in your room for reasonable rates. (No idea if unrespectable massage is available anywhere, but wanted to be clear here...)There is some sort of train depot down below and you DO hear the trains, though just as a rushing sound, nothing more, so if you're very sensitive to noise, I suppose that could be an issue but I barely noticed it. I would definitely recommend the Park Hotel.
user_name:
Sara S
McKinney, Texas, United States

review_body: Been staying at the Park Hotel whenever I visit Tokyo for the past ten years. It can be a little tricky finding it if you take the Yamanote line for example. The rooms have all the amenities you need. Be sure to ask for the side of the hotel that faces Tokyo Tower as it provides a great view of the city! Beds are very comfortable. The fish market is very close by and provides a wonderful opportunity to have sushi for breakfast! And speaking of breakfast, the hotel's buffet is pretty darn good. I've traveled and stayed in this hotel for both business and for personal vacation. Many businesses have employees staying at hotels in Shinagawa. I've found the price for this hotel and the quality much better and worth a couple train station rides away.

We stayed for two nights at Park hotel Tokyo. The location is excellent, very close to the train stations. Staff is very good, friendly and welcoming. Hotel rooms are not too big, getting a bit dated, but still very clean. The views from the lobby are spectacular. Less great from our hotel room, but still it was nice. Beds were comfy, not the pillows. In general it was a good experience.

Just home after 5 nights at the Park Hotel, we were there 7 years ago and it really hasn't changed at all which is great. It was lovely then and still is. The staff are all 10/10, they really are so charming and cannot do enough for you. The hotel is an oasis of calm in a very busy city, also the location is good and perfect for the metro and JR line.Right by the hotel are loads of restaurants ranging fro typical cheap Japanese up to top end sky restaurants. For breakfast, near the hotel there are Excelsior coffe bars where you can get a breakfast set for about 420 yen, I.e. cappuccino and Croque Monsieur.If we return to Tokyo this is where we'll stay.

This hotel is located in a modern business business centre between two stations. It is very modern, comfortable and fully deserves its four stars. The room is none too large, the bathroom is luxurious... And front staff Excellent!

We had a room with a fantastic view over towards Tokyo Tower with mountains in the distance. Huge windows that stretched across the whole side of the room! I imagine all the rooms have excellent views as the hotel starts on something like the 20th floor of a building!! The beds were so comfortable and the bathroom clean and of high quality. The location for tourists is ok but felt a little bit out of the way of many attractions, although with the fantastic infrastructure in this city, it wasn't a problem at all... It's just that you can't really walk to any attractions. There is a parade of convenient restaurants literally underneath the hotel which is handy. The bar and restaurant were very nice, brilliant cocktails! If I go back to Tokyo I will return to this hotel.

What a joy to stay here! It is one nice surprise after another. The Park Hotel Tokyo is now officially my official hotel in Tokyo.The positive first impressions start at the entrance to the building. The lobby of the hotel is not on the ground floor. It is on the 25th floor. The way to the lifts is through the bright, airy lobby of the Shiodome Media Tower in which there were 2 interesting exhibits: 1 on political cartoons, the other on the history-making events of the post war world as recorded by the cameras of the news agency housed in the tower. Both are fascinating. Several sensory surprises await you 25 floors up. I will not spoil them by describing them here. I'll just put it this way... It's a lobby one looks forward to spending time in. The staff is lovely and helpful. Most speak English well enough to be helpful. But, the main thing is the sincerity. During my 5 days there, I never encountered that politeness-as-a-duty behavior that I experienced in every other hotel in Japan. They must have some special recruiting technique to hire those who are helpful and polite just because they want to be. My room was one of the "artist rooms". Again, I will not ruin the surprise for you. I will just say that I smiled every time I entered the room. It was a joy just to sit there admiring the walls as well as the view of Tokyo from 31 floors above the action. Breakfast is quite good. The restaurants are rather pricey, but the food and service is good. The bartender in the whiskey bar makes some excellent cocktails. My compliments go to the designers and entire staff.

Nice view on Tokyo tower from 26th to 34th floor, Looby at 25th floor, several train lines in front of the room window make a little noise at night. Small and clean room. The Bathroom is not five star like (material and size). Wifi free.No swimming pool, Fitness room such small that you have to book in advance to use it !

A friend and I had the pleasure of staying in Park Hotel Tokyo for 5 nights. Our initial response was 'Wow - MOUNT FUJI!' - the view from the hotel lobby has a stunning view of the city with the famous mountain ever present as the backdrop.The lobby itself is a piece of art - there was a design installment when we were visiting which was gorgeous!Our room had a spectacular view of the bullet rains whizzing by in the crazy city! Our rooms were clean, equipped with every commodity a traveller could hope for. Really comfortable beds, fantastic WIFI and great customer service.The room service, restaurant and bar are expensive, but it is what you would expect for a hotel of this standard. The area is a business district with contemporary sky rises dotted around, but the area is exquisitely designed and remarkably safe. There is also a Tokyo TV studio based right by the hotel and we saw a lot of filming while we were out and about! But if you fancy something more traditional, you are a stones throw away from the world famous fish market, Japanese dance theatres and numerous bars and restaurants!We would highly recommend this hotel to anyone visiting Tokyo!

The Park is a fine hotel and probably a good all round standard for downtown Tokyo. The biggest negative is the small rooms. We were there on part of a long trip for which we had quite a lot of baggage. Finding a place for everything and the cases was a challenge. Small niggles include a shower curtain in the bathroom (I thought that these went out years ago) and no bedside table or reading light on one side of the large bed.The staff was all very helpful and friendly with good english spoken.

I have stayed at Tokyo tower side room for two nights and i have to say the view is wonderful! although the room space is small and the facilities is kindda old in this price, still worth it for this wonderful view.The service is excellent, i truly love it.

This is a good hotel. it's in the top part of a modern high rise building. The reception is on the 23rd floor, our room was on the 32nd floor, it was spacious looking towards the Telecom Tower and on one morning we were able to see Mt Fuji from our room! The lobby lounge is used for breakfast - just make sure you get a sit up table and chairs , otherwise the arm chairs are somewhat awkward, if you're tall. The breakfast and meals are good.There are plenty of eating places near the hotel. The staff are helpful.There are many new tower blocks around the hotel, but they did not restrict our view. The hotel is essentially central , close to the bottom end of the Ginza, with a metro station close by, and within walking distance of the famous fish markets.The hotel has exits from the first three floors and two basements into various walkways - which messed with our minds a little - we had some difficulty orienteering ourselves outside. There are metro stations nearby, and the metro system is ok, once you've mastered the system of where you want to go and buying tickets.We arranged for a car to transport us from the airport.We recommend this as value for money in central Tokyo

Stayed for 6 nights in two comfortable, modern 29th floor rooms with spectacular views over Tokyo Tower and, after a typhoon cleared out the skies, Mt. Fuji (which is usually an elusive presence). Rooms are medium-sized and have the usual 4-5 star hotel amenities: slippers, in-room coffee and tea, safe, mini-bar, sleeping kimono, free Wi-Fi. The bathroom is small but includes an all-service toilet that turns out to be standard in many Japanese facilities. Fortunately the buttons for flushing and more intimate cleansing activities are easily de-codable. There's a small but functional business center that meets basic needs (Macs, not PCs). Ground floor and basement of the building have a daytime café and a 24-hour mini-mart; the metro/train station complexes have many little shops selling food, clothing and other items. Compared to the coldly impersonal Conrad, Royal Park, Intercontinental (Roppongi) and Imperial Hotel lobbies we visited, the Park Hotel is warmly welcoming, almost cozy by Tokyo standards. Staff are very helpful, polite and gracious. Breakfast and light dinners in the lounge are very good, with a sufficient selection of western and Asian food. In fact, the croissants and Danish pastries are so yummy that I saw guests every morning standing by the bread baskets wolfing down the ones with chocolate chips without bothering to go to their tables. The two on-site restaurants - Tatero Yoshino (TY) Bis (fairly cutting edge French cuisine) and Hanasanshou (kaiseki-style Japanese) - are excellent. Food quality and presentation at both are worth the prices and if you're a Casablanca fan you'll be able to lipsync "Play it Sam," with Ingrid Bergman and "Here's looking at you kid," with Humphrey Bogart while the film plays silently on one of the walls in TY Bis.For touring, the hotel is well located right above the Shiodome Japan Rail station which goes directly to the Oeno circular city line that stops at Tokyo Station; an easy walk through the sky-scraper complex of Shiodome takes you to Shimbashi station where multiple metro and private train lines connect. You could walk to the Tsukiji Fish market for the early morning tuna auction (hotel recommends leaving at 4:00 am to get one of the 120 spots available to tourist viewing) or skip the auction, wait until the metro starts running and ride up to the market's entrance, one stop away. Worthwhile visit, by the way, to see what it takes to put that piece of sashimi or sushi on your plate.For visitors who take Sunrise Tours of Mt. Fuji and other places, the good news is that the company picks you up at the hotel. The airport bus does too. Driving may be a bit of a challenge because we did have one or two cab drivers who needed to resort to their GPS to find the hotel entrance. It's in the Media Tower on floors 29-34.We were delighted with our stay and glad we chose this hotel over some of the better known similarly priced places.

We went to Japan last September and we sleept 6 nigths in this great hotel. Is very special because is situated in large office tower, but the hotel is situated from the 25th floor to the 32th floor. The views are espectaculars, because all the rooms are externals. The breakfast is so good. And all the staff is so pleasant and want to help you is you have some questions.At least, this hotel is a good option in Tokyo. It,s near Shimbashi train staton and Shiodome underground.

We had the pleasure of staying at both the Conrad and the Park Hyatt Tokyo in October 2014. The Park Hyatt starts with a lobby on the 41st floor. To get there you pass through a lounge with a magnificent 270 Degree views of Tokyo, including Mount Fuji. Check in is personal, no counter. The room we got on the 47th floor was spacious, luxurious, very modern, partly electric shades to the outside. The fitness center was outstanding with the equipment on both sides of the pool on the 47th floor. We ate at the Japanese restaurant which was very good. In retrospect we should have gone tot the NY Grill on the 52nd floor which is breathtaking. Not only that, the Jazz performance on the 52nd floor is professional jazz club level - no need to go out, people actually come here. I will post a separate review of the Conrad, but the bottom line is that both are outstanding and the choice of where to stay hinges on what Tokyo neighborhood you want to be in.

The hotel is in a very high rise, modern tower. We gently asked for a room with a nice view and, to our surprise, we were assigned a room with a fantastic view over Shiodome Tower! Staff were really helpful and professional. The room was minimalist but comfortable and extemely quiet - the bathroom was relatively small but had lovely toiletries. The station is just below the hotel, plus there are a number of shops and restaurants just a few minute walk if you don't feel like travelling.We tried one of the bars on the same floor as the reception, great cocktails and atmosphere. Would definitely stay again.

Situated in a central Tokyo location, this hotel has over 250 small,, but well appointed rooms.. The hotel recepetion is located on the 25th floor of Shiodome Media Tower with the rooms situated in the floors above affording grest views from this triangular shaped building.The hotel can be reached easily from either of the two local airports by train, limo bus or a more expensive taxi ride.It is also only a short distance to a main train station for any local or more distant travel. Within the building complex are a number of restaurants and a mini market.A good choice for either a long or short stay.

Stayed as a couple for 5 nights in June in one of the standard rooms, it was a perfect introduction to Japan and Tokyo in particular- small but practical and very clean, funky toilets with good bath accessories. We didn't have such a great view from our floor (I think it was 30something) as there was an office block opposite. Staff were courteous and had a good command of English. The location is a plus if you want to head to the Tsukiji fish market as it's a pleasant <10 min walk (we went twice!) but if you want to get to the JR line it's a 10+ min walk. The surrounding area (Shimbashi) is also not as "happening" at night, but the Ginza district isn't too far away (15-20 min walk).

fabulous, we arrived after an all night flight from Sydney Australia, and expecting to wait until 2pm to check in and for a small extra fee, we were in our room resting by 9am staff helpful, view spectacular, close to station very easy to get around, lots of covered walkways, station is just outside 3rd floor exit, I would recommend to anyone

Tokyo Park Hotel in Shiodome's Mediatower is a very good location for sightseeing trips around the metropolitan area of Tokyo. Shimbashi station (JR Line and Metro) is only a short walk away and connected underground so that even during the typhoons and rain periods you are very flexible. It is no problem to find excellent dining options around. Tokyo's variety of soups can be tested directly in the transfer passage to the metro station! Excellent food for little money! The Hotel itself is perfectly comfortable and the view is just fantastic (especially at night) The breakfast can be rated as good so that you are perfectly prepared for a day within Tokyo!

Friendly .Clean and Wonderful service!Stayed at Park Hotel for 4 nights in July, 2014. It's a wonderful design hotel. Friendly,clean, modern, and well situated. I tried to ask a room that can facing the Tokyo tower. And they made me the dream come true! It's a wonderful experience and nice trip in Tokyo and Park hotel!

This was my first visit to Tokyo and I cannot therefore compare this hotel with others in the city. My wife and I enjoyed our stay in this well appointed hotel in a very good location, a short walk from the Ginza and main line stations.First impressions are not good. At ground floor level you are greeted by an empty open space and need to take the lift to the reception on the 25th floor. From then on, it's a normal hotel although there is no pool.Our room was on the 28th floor with fantastic views, although it was a bit smaller than we expected. It was nevertheless very clean and tidy. Breakfast was on the 25th floor and was comprehensive and tasty. We did eat in the restaurant one night out of three and it was perfectly OK. We only ate out the other two nights so that we would get more of a feel for the area.When we had queries, the staff were very helpful. From the reception there's a great view of the Tokyo Tower, especially when it's light up at night.The hotel has underground and above ground walking access to the local stations, shops and the Ginza district which is an experience in itself.We enjoyed our staff but had the overall feeling that the hotel was more suited for businessmen rather than foreign tourists.

Tokyo seems to have a dearth of hotels in the upper middle (or lower luxury) category. The choice often reduces to the extremely expensive global brands like Hyatt, Ritz-Carlton, etc., or smaller and much more basic "business" hotels. The Park is an excellent alternative between these two poles. It is modern, well-designed, clean and well-located. The staff is, as usual in Japan, very friendly and responsive. We arrived late on a Sunday night and decided to eat in the hotel's lobby bistro instead of wandering out. The food was tasty and well-presented and, compared to most hotel restaurants, good value. All-in-all a pleasant stay with no complaints. Also, after a number of intermediate stops, the limosine bus from the airport will drop you directly at the hotel door.

Stayed at Park Hotel for 4 nights in October, 2014. Clean, modern, and well situated. I got the standard room which was small, with a functional but tiny bathroom - which tends to be the standard for Japan. The staff was extremely helpful and courteous. I told them I was there for a honeymoon, and they upgraded us on our last 2 nights to a room with the Tokyo Tower view. The concierge was invaluable in booking us into a 3 star michelin restaurant after several emails back and forth trying to accommodate us. It was great having the shiodome metro at the basement of the hotel however, the hotel is not in the middle of the action. The closest thing worth going to is the Caretta Shiodome which is about an 8-10 minute walk, Ginza which is about a 10-15 minute walk, and the Hamarikyu gardens which were about a 10 minute walk. However being on top of the shiodome station, and close to the shimbashi station made it easy to go anywhere in Tokyo with public transportation. Overall I felt like it was a good value for the quality that was offered, though next time in Tokyo I would probably stay in another area.

Its excellent location and pleasant staff, makes a wonderful hotel to stay in at Tokyo. A modern hotel located at shiodome station and a few minutes walking from Shimbasi station,close to Ginza and 10 minutes walking from Tsukiji Fishmarket. Rooms are well equiped, cleanliness and well equiped with wonderful views of Tokyo (recommended rooms with Tokyo tower view). Pleasant staff. Buffet breakfast excellent,good quality and variety. The only negative point is its very small gym.

Everything about this hotel oozes quality, even down to the amenities shower cap which included a hairband. We had lovely views from the room which was very quiet. We didn't eat at the hotel as it was only a short walk the Ginza with all its restaurants and shops. The subway is right outside and train station only a short walk. We purchased a pasmo card which can be used on both these. It was quite easy to get the express train from the airport. Their website gives good directions.

I stayed here in 2011 and liked it so much that I stayed again when visiting Tokyo this past September. The lobby is located on the 25th floor and gives the hotel a boutique feel, discouraging people from walking in off the street to gawk. I found the staff to be particularly accommodating at every level (even as someone who for many years lived and worked in Tokyo and so knows well the high levels of customer service that are common in Japan)My room was clean, the view outstanding. The hotel now has a very small gym that guests can reserve by the hour. It would be good if they could expand this.The laundry facilities are useful for those staying more than a few days.All in all, excellent value.One criticism....as a non-smoker, I dislike the designated smoking spot in the lobby. To be sure, it is a small area, but the second-hand smoke spoils the ambiance ever so slightly.

A very clean and modern hotel within a walkable distance from Ginza, very quiet area at night. Stayed for several nights but spent most of my time out and around Tokyo. I think this hotel is more suited for the business traveller rather than the tourist/shopper. Location wise not much of a problem due to Tokyo's extensive train system. Overall had a nice stay at very reasonable prices.

We stayed here for just one night on a last minute booking after our other hotel fell through. The hotel is in a great location and was easy to find. The service was very good but it seemed more suited to business people than travellers.Our room itself was on the 33rd floor and had a great view out onto the city. The location is good and we had a rail pass for the duration of our trip so it worked well for us but it is slightly out of the main part of Tokyo, nearer the business district. Overall a very nice hotel with lovely rooms and a great view, perfect for visiting the area.

The service and facilities at the Park Hotel are very good, but if you are a tourist the location is, maybe, 6/10 or even 7. Yes, the hotel is close to two rail stations - Shimbashi and Shiadome, but there is nothing better than stepping foot outside a hotel and absorbing the atmosphere of the location. This is sadly missing at the Park Hotel. The hotel has virtually no "presence" on the ground floor (there is a desk, but more often than not while we stayed at the hotel it was unmanned).For the business person the Park a Hotel is ideal, but for the tourist, it is so, so.

We chose this Hotel for our 3 night pre cruise tour, It is well located above the Shiodome Subway, easy access to Shimbashi Station (about 7 Minute walk in Tunnel / shopping area and also close to stations on the new above ground Line. Once you work out the Metro system it makes for safe and easy transport. We also walked to Tokyo Tower in under 30 Minutes, Ginza Shopping area about 10 minutes walk. There are many ways to walk around and you can walk above the streets on Pedestrian Bridge walks or under the streets in Tunnel areas. Hotel Staff extremley helpful in giving directions and information. Reception is on the 25th Level via dedicated Elevators. We found 3 seperate Entrances to the Hotel depending on what direction you were coming from .... Main Entrance is on Street Level, this is where the AirPort Bus, Taxis etc drop and pick up. Then there is the Basement Entrance which takes you too and from the Metro and underground shopping area. Lastly an entrance on the 3rd level which goes straight out onto the overhead Pedestrian walkways.Rooms are smallish by Western standards but quite adequate, views are excellent. Quality of the rooms and furnishings is good. We had breakfast included in our booking to make this meal simple, the Buffet is more than adequate with Western and Japanese Selections, we did not eat Lunch or dinner at the Hotel but there are many eating places close by, mainly small Japanese restuarants but we also found a Subway and a MacDonalds within 5 minutes of the Hotel for those who are less Adventurous with their eating.Hotel is also close enough to the Fish Market to walk there and explore. and Local Botanic Garden as well.Getting to or from Narita Airport is simple as the Airport Limo Bus includes the Hotel in its stops.DO NOT CONFUSE THIS HOTEL, PARK HOTEL with the ROYAL PARK HOTEL which is just around the corner they are 2 different Hotels.

This hotel is fantastic- The views are amazing. The rest of the hotel is fantastic too. The rooms are large, clean and comfortable. The best bit about this hotel is the staff; they are so accommodating and help for any small request. They really are there to help you out which is great. The hotel breakfast is not that cheap but it good value for the money. There is both Japanese and Western food so you can choose what you fancy. The hotel reception have breakfast vouchers which save 400 yen per breakfast which is a good incentive. The hotel is easy to get to from Shimbashi station or Shiodome station. It's a good base to explore Tokyo.

We only got to stay three nights on our Japanese tour with Tokyo the first stop. It's super location for transportation, whether JR lines or subway, make this a great hotel for a first timer to Tokyo (like us) to stay. We used it as a base and explored the city like crazy. The room was small but well appointed. The staff were very good indeed, always happy to help and spoke pretty good English. There was really nothing too much for them to do or arrange. The breakfast buffet was okay, nothing outstanding but offering both Japanese and Western fare. The bed was comfortable and a welcome break from the very hard beds experienced in mainland China. The lobby was decorated nicely. We didn't visit the bar or in house restaurant. As I said, we had a really good experience here and would recommend it.

Location very close to subway/railway. Hotel lobby at 25th floor, makes every room have a spectacular view out of Tokyo, including nearby Tokyo Tower.Many many restaurants nearbyWalking distance to Ginza makes it convenient for shopping.Fish market nearby, with several very good sushi restaurants.

it is good hotel with reasonable size of room. And night view of the city is great. The only catch is the hotel front desk is located at level 25 of the building with all rooms above level 25. It is lucky for us to catch taxi to the hotel at first time when we landed Tokyo. At first a few attempt to go out, it is very hard to walk to station even it is only 7 minutes away from Shimbashi stations and 12 minutes to Ginza. The traffic routine even walking path is very complex. My advise that you don't walk on the street level since you may see the hotel building and you can't reach it very easliy. Only underground pathway or above ground walking path way is much easiler to go.

Ideally located to visit the different areas of Tokyo. Easy access to both Shimbashi and Shiodome Stations. We had a Tokyo Tower View room which offers a breathtaking view of Tokyo. Rooms are modern and of adequate size for Japanese Hotels.

We were on our way home from a seven week trip to Europe and, wishing to have a stop-over, decided to do so in Tokyo. Our travel agent booked us in for two nights at this hotel that is on the edge of the Ginza shopping precinct.Finding our way there from Haneda Airport was very easy, as it was simply a matter of catching the monorail from the airport to Shinbashi Station - about 50 minutes. The Hotel is right by the station exit. When you enter the building in which the hotel is located, the Shinbashi Media Tower, you will see that the hotel starts from the 25th floor and there are 4 lifts to take you there. The hotel itself is reasonably new and comprises the top 11 floors of the building, so has great views of sections of the city. Rooms, while not overly large, are very comfortable and of a high standard. Good quality sheets, towels and other soft furnishings made our room very comfortable. We were on the 32 floor and the views were excellent! En-suite facilities are excellent and feature a combined toilet/bidet which is easy to use. The bathroom also has a retractable washing line and a heat-patch behind the mirror to allow a fog-free patch on the mirror..Lighting was very good and included a dimmer on the lights in the bathroom.Air conditioning was quiet and effective.There were also little extras like a clothes brush and show horn in our room. The room also had a kettle, tea and coffee bags, cups and a mini bar. Internet connections are very easy and there is no necessity to reconnect after either leaving the hotel or switching off your Ipad or phone. We found this to be a real boon after difficulties re-connecting in some of the hotels we visited. In our case, breakfast was not included, but if you ask them nicely, they may gave you vouchers to all you to have a discounted breakfast on the first morning. Breakfast included a good range of 'Western' and Asian foods.Staff at the hotel were friendly and efficient and helped make our stay there a delightful experience.Nearby, there is 'label' shopping and also a lovely park. Really good signage, in English, is a great aid in finding your way around, as too is the very friendly and helpful nature of the Japanese people we met. Sometimes, seeing us rearing at a map, they came and offered to help us without us even asking for help.We enjoyed it so much, we are thinking about a return visit some time.

I wanted to LOVE this hotel, I did, it has so much potential and had great reviews, but unfortunately the bad outweighed the good and unless they do a major reno, I probably won't ever return here. We stayed in room 2901 - Corner King with Tokyo Tower and Skyline view. Honestly, I think this was the least exciting corner king room they had available and was not as glamourous looking as the photos on the website. If you're going to stay here and get a corner king, get one on the other side of the hotel. I think the skyline on that side is "better" and more "glamourous".Let's start with the PROs:Breathtaking views of the Tokyo skyline, including Tokyo TowerConveniently located right by three (3!!!) train stations - Shimbashi, Shiodome, and YurikamomeSurprisingly delish candy dish in the lobbyGorgeous lobbySpacious room (well, by Japanese standards)For the most part, the staff were super friendly - exactly what you'd expect from a property that bills itself as a "luxury hotel"Free Wifi that worked GREAT!!CONs:The guy who checked us in did not represent the hotel well or display typical Japanese hospitality. He seemed genuinely disengaged. I know this probably seems trivial and had we been at an American hotel, I would have been like "whatever" about it, but that's cause service in America sucks compared to Japan...so basically, I expected more.We had a room with million dollar views, but unfortunately, the room itself did not reflect that. It's outdated and the carpet along the wall with the windows were torn up and the caulking around the bathtub (top) was not done properly. Again, little details, but when you're paying a premium, you notice those things.The hallways smell of an "old" hotel...basically, all I kept thinking was "this is an outdated hotel with an updated facade and lobby". I'm sure their suites are much nicer than the room I stayed in, but given that we were in an upgraded room, I can't imagine the hotel has THAT many "fancy, schmancy" rooms...does that make sense?So, in conclusion -- while the over all stay wasn't horrible, it is not worth the $300+ price tag to have a "room with a view" when the rooms are outdated and you can get equally delicious views and a more updated room in an EVEN MORE conveniently located area (like Shibuya or Shinjuku) for about $50 more (average)...like at the Cerulean Tokyu Tower.
user_location: Washington, District of Columbia, United States
user_name:
Haley G
Washington, District of Columbia, United States

review_body: Very well located in Ginza, with easy access to Shimbashi and Shiodome Stations. The hotel is located over the 25th floor in a modern and beautiful,and offers wonderful views to Tokyo Tower and even to Mount Fuji, in clear days. Breakfast is expensive. Wifi is free. Rooms are not to big, but very confortable. It worths the price and I strongly reccomemd this hotel.
user_name:
Marco L
Belo Horizonte, Minas Gerais, Brazil

review_body: We got this hotel off Expedia for a very good price. It is located on the top floors of the Shiodome media tower. It is about a 5-10 minute walk from the Shimbashi subway/JR train station. It is very easily reachable if you have a JR pass and take the monorail from Haneda airport and then take the green Yamanote line to Shimbashi. If you fly into Narita it is about the same travel using the train and then on to the Yamanote line. From the hotel it is 15 minute by foot to the Tsukiji Fish Market and about a 15 minute walk to the Ginza area. The hotel is clean and the beds are comfortable. The hotel is easily confused with the Royal Park Hotel which is located in the Shiodome Centre and about 100 metres down the road.

Upside:1) Location - easy to find2) Train line in basement 13) Taxis know where this is4) Big, clean rooms (ours was in the higher floors)5) Great view of Tokyo Tower6) Affordable7) Money changer (machine) in reception area8) situated in the business area, no noise9) Staff helpful 10) Smoking outside the buildingDownside1) Lobby is located several floors above. Sometimes there's nobody at the entrance door to meet-greet you

Amazing hotel - great service, location. The views are stunning! We took the best pictures of Tokyo from the hotel. The rooms are very clean and the staff super helpful. Very close the train station, so you can get around easy. Walking distance to the best shopping area and other great areas in Tokyo. Definitely recommend the hotel to anyone and would love to stay there again!
user_name:
Tatianapc2014
Los Angeles, California, United States

review_body: We stayed at the Park Hotel for 4 nights and really enjoyed it.The location is handy, staff are very polite and helpful and the views are superb.The rooms are well equipped and cleaning is good. We had breakfast one of the mornings at the hotel and enjoyed that too.It was good value, so definitely recommended.

I stayed at the Park Hotel on my first trip to Japan and was a little surprised at the size (small - and I live in central London) and furnishings (relatively outdated by western standards) of the room. But the concierge was really really helpful, staff lovely and the western breakfast was gratefully received. The view from reception is amazing, and the location is great for exploring Tokyo, with Ginza a short walk away and Tokyo Bay easily accessible by train. I would definitely stay here again.

Park Hotel staff are very polite, and service orientated, nothing was too much trouble for them.The hotel lobby is located on the 25th floor, which opens up into a light airy atrium.You can see Mount Fuji and the Tokyo tower on a clear day. Travelling in Tokyo is easy and inexpensive. They operate a card (similar to the Oyster card in the UK) that you purchase and charge from machines located in the station below the hotel (you can also pay for food and drinks from the local convenience stores using this card).Signs are also in English and most people can speak it. You can access the station directly from the hotel elevator, links to Japan Rail (JR) and Metro lines (JR Shimbashi) also in walking distance (~10 mins) to Ginza if you want to do some shopping. The rooms are spacious and comfortable (we stayed in 3312/3313 and offered a clear view of Mount Fuji, Tokyo tower and a breathtaking view of Tokyo city. Fresh robes and towels are provided on a daily basis, there is a shower and bath (as well as a warm lavatory seat with bidet facilities built in!). There is a coin operated laundrette on the 26 floor (no need for soap powder) and a drinks machine on the 33rd floor.There is an ample breakfast available (the hotel offered us discounted breakfast vouchers) and there are lots of little cafes on the ground floor and surrounding areas. The buildings around the hotel have fantastic food courts and there are a good selection of restaurants.Take the metro and explore, it is very safe and convenient, Tokyo has a lot to offer, the Park Hotel is an excellent choice to make, we will definitely be returning.

My partner and I stayed here for the second time in December 2013/January 2014 - this time with another couple. The standard of the rooms is very high - much larger rooms than many other hotels in Tokyo. The views from the rooms are spectacular! And on a very clear day Mount Fuji can be seen from the huge windows in the reception area. Staff are very helpful and attentive, we were staying over New Years and they were very helpful in offering suggestions for what to do, as many attractions were closed. The hotel is a 5 min walk from Shiodome Station and a further 10 -15 mins (undercover) to Shinbashi Station. From here we regularly caught trains - both Metro and JR lines - around the city. There is an abundance of small restaurants and karaoke bars a short walk away and there are several 24hour convenience stores located close to the building. We would recommend this hotel to any first time Tokyo visitors, it is well located and well priced. Bonus for us was that it was about 10 mins by train to the nearest Pokemon Centre! :)

the rooms were very nice and fairly large. the view from the 32nd floor was spectacular. Breakfast was good. It was better to eat in the hotel than outside where the temperature was 33C (feels like 44C). Dinner menu was good. Staff were very helpful. Airport bus picked up at the hotel. Shiodome station is right beneath the hotel, Shimbashi station is relatively easy walk via the underground concourse (not so easy with suitcases when you are 75). WiFi was free and fast. For people who have a problem with heights. the two windows outside the lifts (left and right), are full length plain glass going down to the floor and should have some furniture (table, chair etc) across the window. I'm fairly OK with heights but I walked up to the window and felt I was going to fall into the empty space of the Atrium, 7 floors below - very scary!. We enjoyed a 4 day stay at the hotel and would recommend it.

We chose this hotel with some trepidation - we are from the UK and never been to Tokyo. So we thought that location was everything. When we looked at prices and reviews, we thought this hotel looked good value. Then we realised that the rooms start on the 25th floor with some amazing views.We paid extra for a Tokyo Tower facing corner room (about £40/$60 a night more?) and it was worth it. We were on the 33rd floor and every time we went back to the room, we just went "wow". The room was spacious with an enormous (king+) bed plus four wall to ceiling windows. Smart bathroom, safe and mini-bar (why?). All very good.We had the buffet breakfast once - it was pretty good, lots of variety and a relaxed atmosphere.The only downside is actually the location. Despite it being on top of one subway line and only 5 minutes from about three others, it really means that you have to work out the complicated subway system to get anywhere. Once we'd worked out the Suica card system (touch-in / out, e-card) cost between £1-2 ($2-3) and location was ok. The biggest problem we had was our last evening in the Ginza area (just on the edge of the hotel) which is clearly a business district. We found it hard to find a restaurant - lots there but full of business people and quite a lot of them are on the 4/5/6th floors making it hard to choose one without having to go into a lift etc etc.Overall, a lovely hotel and we would definitely re-visit and recommend

The room temperature was too low. We were frozen in spite of switch off A/C. We called Service to solve it and there was not any Solution by them. They said the entire hotel temperature was that because of summer.

This is a 4 start hotel with 5 start people and service. Sure, then don't have a pool or a big gym, but the sympathy of the staff and their wiling to help is just amazing. It's not by chance that this is my favorite hotel in Tokyo so far. For breakfast you can choose between Japanese food and the normal croissant / bread. I think that the breakfast is where you can see that this is a 4 start hotel and not a 5 start, it's a bit poor, but I think it has more to do with the space available. The room are small, but give you amazing views over Tokyo. I had the luck of experience all the sides of this hotel, Tokyo bay, Tokyo tower and the train station. The location is great. Near by you have Ginza and Shimbashi where you can eat with the locals. Loots of Izakaya's, ramem stores and bars. If you want to visit the fish market this is the right hotel, it's only 15 min away walking. Remember you have to be there really early in the morning.If you booked the hotel without breakfast ask for breakfast coupons in the reception. Also they have free WI-FI.

This is a teeny tiny bit out of the way of most tourist attractions BUT it's very close to the train which can take you any where within city. I loved the room—clean, spacious and loved THANN products and spa. I was lucky to stay on a room with a view facing Tokyo Tower and it was spectacular. I would go back for sure, if only for the views. TIP: if it's your first time to Tokyo, I try to map out how you'll get there from train station before your trip. It's very easy to get there but easier to take a wrong turn. If all fails, look for the tall triangular building since it's easy to spot!

This hotel was a great find in a very interesting location . It was pretty easy to find from the station (once we'd realise we weren't booked into another Park Hotel practically next door! The Media tower where its located is pretty impressive, and the reception is on the 25th floor, so all rooms have a pretty spectacular view. It was great to see the Shinkansen travelling through Shimbashi station which runs practically under the hotel, at all times of day and night. The hotel was silent though- no noise from anywhere, except the odd rumble of thunder from an overhead thunderstorm! Amazing to watch the frequent lightening strikes from our window. If views are your thing, the reception has pretty cool view of the Tokyo Tower and we did see Mount Fuji to the right of it in the haze.There were lots of pluses and a few minuses to this hotel. Room was great, as was the reception service. In particular we needed to forward our luggage to a hotel Hiroshima- 3 huge cases- and this was done with no fuss for an amazing 12 pounds or so. Breakfast was pretty good, though can get busy and we ended up in a side room, which obviously hadn't been cleaned from dinners the night before- table clothes were grubby for example. Staff in the breakfast /bar area a bit miserable- and getting service for a drink in the early evening was a bit tricky. Happy hour drinks were pretty good value- about 800 yen for big beer. Drinks prices later in the evening were astronomical- but it is a hotel after all. Don't even ask what two single G&Ts cost. If you're loaded you could even try the dozens and dozens of whiskeys on offer- not surprisingly few people did so the late night bar was quiet.We liked the Park Hotel and wished we could have stayed longer.

We stayed here on our first trip to Tokyo.The location next to two stations made getting to and from the airports easy. Most central areas of Tokyo have direct trains from these station and were similar distances. The location is excellent.The staff were friendly and helpful and help us to confirm and book a restaurant reservation.The hotel is very nice and the room was good. We had a City view room which had great views.There was some noise from the station below, but not enough to spoil the stay or stop us sleeping.We would definitely recommend this hotel.

The Room was clean and big enough for two peolpe and baggages, the bed is very confortable, the view is simply priceless. The hotel staff is friendly and speaks good english. Overall the experence was perfect from any point of view!

Stayed here for a four day visit to Tokyo. It is right on the edge of Ginza but also had some streets to the North with real atmosphere cheap restaurants. Staff were friendly and let us check in at 12 after long flights. Breakfast was amazing and the view from the room was stunning. Loved this hotel

This is the fourth time that we have stayed at the Park Hotel. It always feels like our home away from home when we are in Tokyo. Though the rooms are compact, they are simply designed with large picture windows overlooking Tokyo. They provide a kettle, drip coffee, teas and wonderful toiletries. The view of the Tokyo Tower from the 25th floor lobby is fabulous.Location is fabulous - a 10 minute walk to the Ginza and the major subway lines.If you are going to Narita Airport, the shuttle bus stops at the hotel for the same price as the Narita Express: 60 minutes and no hassle with your luggage!Great value for the location and what you get.

Great location close to the subway. Nice and quiet area but with quite a good choice of restaurants and bars. Rooms are clean and also not too small compared to Tokyo standards. Wi-fi connection is working properly. The rooms are well equipped with all necessary items also in the toilet and a good hairdrier. Staff is very polite. I haven't tried breakfast.

Very nice experience.Nothing to complaint aboutService and location are great Breakfast buffet has a good quality and decent variety The location near ginza area and shopping mall district makes this hotel a good value for money accommodationHighly recommended

Stayed here for 3 nights and found some positives and negatives. ..Positives - good location for acess to station, great view from our room and reception, staff lovely and spoke good English, quiet room, clean and modern, laundry facilities were good and fairly priced.Negatives - tiny room for 2 people making it very tight for luggage to go anywhere you didn't have to step over it(most hotel rooms appear to be small in Japan though), breakfast was average that we only ate it once, couldn't get into gym.I would stay here again but would also look for an alternative as this is the only place I've stayed at in tokyo.

This hotel is located on multiple Japan Rail (JR) and Metro lines (JR Shimbashi, Ginza & Asakusa Shimbashi, Oedo Shiodome), although they take a bit of working out. Its also close to Ginza if you want to do a bit of shopping. The rooms are very small but had all you needed to be comfortable. There is a coin operated laundrette on the 26/f, you just put your clothes in and it does the rest, very handy. You had to pay to use the gym so I exercised in the room. The view I had was of an office block where the office workers were staring directly into my room. If they had not seen an naked Irish man before they have now! I asked for a change of room but they couldn't manage that. The lobby is on the 25/F and the rest of the rooms are on the 26th - 34th floors. The lobby is very nice but I was not staying in the lobby! On a clear day you can see Mt. Fuji, but it rained when I was there. The breakfast was expensive and there are lots of little cafes on the ground floor including Starbucks where you can eat much much cheaper. The buildings around the hotel have fantastic food courts and there are floors of restaurants, some were great. The location reminded me of the movie Bladerunner with the elevated walkways and over head trains, a really cool place. The staff were helpful when required and I could not fault them in anyway. This hotel is well located for things to do, the famous Tokyo fish market is a short 500m walk. From the metro station you can go where you want. I was just annoyed that that when I had paid a good price for the room I could not get a decent view and they could not change the room. As I say in all my reviews, would I go back. In this case no, there are better hotels with better views for a similar or lesser price so while it was good it was not good enough to bring me back, and I will be going back.

The hotel is very nice, the view is the best-all rooms are on the 26th floor and higher. Location perfect-few minutes to the subway station. The hotel has a shuttel and if making a tour you have pick up service. The room was not too big but inside you have a bed, a table and chair, an armchair and place to walk around. The only bad was the price of breakfast(2200 yen). We rather went to a nearby Starbucks.

Excellent location on multiple JR/Metro lines (JR Shimbashi, Ginza & Asakusa Shimbashi, Oedo Shiodome), vibrant Shidome/Ginza area with many diverse restaurant options. Rooms are tiny, but reasonably priced. Beautiful upper floor lobby. Decent breakfast. The cluster of Hotel Villa Shiodome, Royal Park Shiodome (closest to the JR and Metro stations by a couple minute walk) and Park Hotel are all quite similar, thus go for the one that has the best price.

I spent three nights at the Park Hotel, which sits atop a tall building in Tokyo, as the last hotel, while traveling for ten weeks in Europe and Asia. Of the fourteen hotels, it had the smallest room but the best view and the most amenities! The Towerside View Room was compact but very comfortable. Breakfast and dinner in the hotel restaurant was very good. The view was priceless! The hotel is very close to many of the main tourist areas and sits atop a train station somewhere down below but not too far away! Staff was very helpful.

We stayed at the Park Hotel for 3 nights in two rooms. Upon Check in we were told that the two rooms we had booked were on two completely different floors. When we asked if we could have that changed we were told 'no'- that was until we asked for a Tower view room which came at an extra 2000 Yen per room/night which then surprisingly meant they could accommodate us on the same floor... The Tower View room was very nice with a great view especially at night, although for some reason the Tower lights turned off at 22:00 and came back on at 22:30. The rooms although small were kept clean and tidy and had all the necessary amenities one might require. The only minor point in the room was that there were no complimentary water bottles.Breakfast at the hotel was satisfactory. The selection was ok for Western and Asian tastes however on hindsight I feel that possibly having breakfast in one of the cafes outside might have been cheaper and better quality. The biggest problem at breakfast was the lack of staff cleaning the tables, meaning dirty plates were left for over 10 minutes on people's tables, whilst the senior staff stood at the entrance to Breakfast looking at their watches. One thing I was not happy about was eating breakfast in the hotel lobby/atrium as whilst eating, many people would walk in and out of the hotel. Also, there was no view of the city which is one of the biggest selling points of the hotel!!The hotel's location above Shiodome Station and under a 10 minute walk from Shimbashi station makes it an ideal base for touring Tokyo as a tourist or for Business.

The hotel is really conveniently located for public transport, close to the fish market and also to Ginza. Rooms are reasonably sized for Japan and the staff are extremely helpful. I would only say the breakfast is a bit disappointing for the price.

We spent a week in Tokyo and overall we were very satisfied with the hotel. We had the Tower view King room - which was small but with wall to wall glass & view it felt big enough. The bed was very comfortable, the location was great and the staff couldn't have been more helpful or better! There was 1 area the Hotel could certainly improve upon - meal service. The Western breakfast buffet was weak in variety didn't offer an egg station.- frankly, the poorest of the 4 hotels we stayed in . AND meal service in the Japanese restaurant ended earlier, even though they publish 9 pm - leaving the only alternative heavy dishes in the French eatery. After a day touring we'd often get back to the hotel about 8, shower and have to leave the hotel to dine - not a bad idea either! Lots of spots in the nearby Ginza.

This hotel was recommended by a friend and it was an ideal start to our first visit to Japan.I got a good price, a room with a view, in a not too busy area with good travel links right on my doorstep. I booked the room direct with the hotel and received a better rate than hotel search engines at a very good price of only 19000+ yen a night.I found the hotel an excellent base to explore Tokyo. This hotel has a subway line next door and the main Shimbashi JR(Yamanote Line) station just 5 mins walk away which is a really cheap way to get round the city and see the sites for only 160 -200 yen one way. The JR stations are one of the few places that have maps and instructions in English. The area has many shops, bars, restaurants, to choose from, all a short walk away. I found the Shimbashi area around the hotel a bit more chilled than Shinjuku or Shibuya.I booked a twin corner room and the city views were breath taking from the 33 rd floor. Reception is on the 25 floor in this hotel and is located on top of an office block. The room had everything you could want and the beds were comfy, wi-fi worked well in the room and reception. The bathroom was a decent size for Tokyo and the beds comfortable for a good night sleep, and you could hear nothing being on such a high floor.I found all hotel staff in Japan to be very helpfull, but when i could not extend my stay at the Park Hotel due to it being fully booked the girl on reception really did go that extra mile for the customer. The young lady rang round hotels and managed to reserve me a room in their sister hotel, they got staff to carry my bags down to reception where they proceeded to get me a taxi and give him instructions for where to take me ... I have never stayed in a hotel where the staff are this helpful.Strongly recommend this is a quality hotel.

I stayed here with my nephew for three nights using it as a home base for Tokyo. The location was excellent, although it was a bit hard to find the very first time as we used the underground tunnels instead of the third floor pedestrian walkways, which is much easier and nicer to navigate. The reception is on the 25th floor with stunning views of the city. The staff and service was excellent. The room was on the small side, but clean and fine. We had a corner room and loved watching the trains run. The weather was hazy the whole time, so visibility was only about 10 miles. I had asked the hotel to reserve a restaurant for me, and there was a small misunderstanding with the price, but the hotel staff made up for it, which we were very grateful for. The Miyazaki clock was just outside the hotel, which was fun to see.

We stayed two wonderful nights in the corner king tower view room. What a view it was! Especially at night - so magical with those big windows, I kinda regret going out on our last night in Tokyo and not staying in bed staring at it. Good bed, staff were wonderfully helpful, whiskey bar is amazing downstairs, only thing I would fault is the limited options for room service. Just seemed a bit out of place considering the high quality of everything else about the place. But overall a very slick experience and will most definitely be back.

From the airport we took the Narita express train to Tokyo station. From the station it was a 1400 Yen (EUR 10/USD 14) taxi ride to the hotel. Because the entrance is not that prominent because the lobby of the hotel is on the 25th floor and the area around the hotel has a lot of corridors, we found it money well spent to have a taxi take us from the station to the entrance of the hotel.Check-in went smooth and although a lot of hotels in Japan have a strict policy about check-in times, the Park hotel was really accommodating even when we arrived rather early. The front desk was also helpful with tips about getting around the city. We had a triple room which was exceptionally spacious for Tokyo/Japanese standards. View over the city was nice. Room was clean and although design was a little bland, the room was good. Wifi was ok.We didn't have breakfast in the hotel but at Felt's on the basement floor of the Shiodome City Center building, enter the building from the outside left from the cooking studios. (In previous reviews reference was made to Vie de France, but we have not been able to find it and think it is possible that is has been taken over by Felt's). Breakfast at this bakery was delicious with fine croissants, pastries and bread,The best thing about the park hotel is the location. Within walking distance are Tsukiji fishmarket (10-15 minutes) and Ginza (15-20 minutes). Ask the front desk for directions.Furthermore It is is a 7 minute walk to the Shimbashi train station which is only a few minutes by local train away from two major Shinkansen stations in Tokyo, Tokyo station (for north bound Shinkansen trains) and Shinagawa station (for south bound Shinkansen trains). This station is also on the Yamamoto circular line which brings you in around 20 25 minutes to Shibuya and Shinjuku. Besides that both the Shiodome subway station (at the entrance of the hotel) and the Shimbashi subway station provide easy access to the major sightseeing points in town. It takes a little getting used to to get around the hotel because there are walkways on different levels. However, when you get used to it, it is really not that hard.To summarize it: this is a good quality hotel but what would make us return is the excellent location close to many transport options which makes it easy to get around Tokyo and beyond Tokyo.

The location is directly connected to Shiodme station.First,6 stars night view(I stayed at Tokyo tower side).Other two sides are also fabulous.Next,the staffs are kind and even spent almost half an hour teaching me Japanese grammar.Besides,they also help me send a package back to Taiwan so I don't need to go to the post with a heavy box.More over,they are very responsible that helped me keep tracking the package and noticed me four days later by email that my package was aboard.Pretty touched by the staff.Rooms are very modern,clean and comfort.Appliances in the bathroom are great.Room rates are a little bit too high but still acceptable.Smoking seems to be allowed in the lobby.

We stayed for 4 days and arrived before the 2pm check in. Our room was made available to us at midday which was much appreciated. We had a corner room with fabulous views of the tower. The room was spacious and the King size bed very comfortable. The area suited us as it was close to the JR line, and Quieter to come back to after a hectic day sightseeing. Also Liked the fact there's was coin operated laundry facility available in the hotel. The staff were helpful, and our room was always cleaned to a high Standard each day.
user_name:
Margaret P
Auckland Central, New Zealand

review_body: Stayed for 4 nights from 11 to 15 July. What I loved about the hotel:1. beautiful main areas complemented by artworks2. rooms were comfortably furnished and of decent size for Tokyo3. covered walkway connections to JR trains and subways 4. great location: 10 minute walk away from Ginza or Tsukiji market5. delicious breakfast buffet6. great value for moneyI would have given this hotel 5 stars except for two reasons: noise from the passing trains that could be heard on the 28th floor up until late night, and a non-stop creaking sound coming from the air conditioning duct that went on for a good hour at 2 a.m. of our first night.

Stayed for 8 days and 7 nights. Ate the breakfast buffet nearly everyday and it was really delicious so did not tire of it. I wonder if the chef is tired of making the same selection everyday though haha. Loved the art displayed on the 25th floor. The room is quite small but it was sufficient for 1 person. I spent most of my time outside anyway. Hotel location is really great, about 10-15mins from Haneda Airport by cab or approx 35mins by subway. Also, it is next to NTV tower and Shiodome station, and 5mins away from Shimbashi Station (linked by underpass and overpass). I love japanese tv, so really enjoyed walking past the glass studio each morning where they were filming PON! ^^ As for food, there are many restaurants or eateries nearby. For those who are not too adventurous when it comes to food, there is Subway and Mcdonalds nearby at Caretta Shiodome and Shiodome station. There's a Family Mart at the basement of the hotel building too. One thing that they could probably improve on is the aircon... it took very long for my room to become cool. Despite this, it was a pleasant stay overall and I would stay here again the next time I travel to Tokyo.

Clean, close to public transportation (jr and metro)Comfortable room, not a normal tokyo sized roomStaff is very helpfulCant wait for next time...........................................................,,,,,,,,..................

The hotel was beautiful and modern, the staff was courteous and welcoming. We stayed for 7 days and 7 nights. The rooms were small, but we did so much during the day and we were so exhausted when we returned to the hotel, we fell asleep as soon as we walked in the door.The hotel's lobby is on the 25 th floor so the views are great from every room. Check out the view behind the front desk to see Mt. Fuji. Subway is convenient to the hotel as are several restaurants. After a particularly exhausting day, my husband ordered a 75 minute massage for me in the room. That was wonderful. I would highly recommend this hotel.

Right on top of Shiodome Subway, this could not have been a better location for getting round Tokyo and visiting all the tourist attractions. Hotel is modern and the staff are very helpful in every way. Rooms are quite small, but for a 3 night stay they were more than enough for a good night sleep. Cost of breakfast is rather expensive for what it is but if you want to fuel up for the day ahead and are not keen on a Japanese breakfast of rice, miso soup & pickled vegetables which in Tokyo you probably won't get until around 11am, then this is probably the best option. If returning to Tokyo this hotel would definitely be top of my list to book again.

Chose this hotel due to its location and was pleased to find it was close to many things. It was above a subway so made it very easy to get around. It is located on the top of a building so the views are great and the lobby is on the 25th floor as well. We had a corner room, which I would recommend, it is small but these rooms had a little extra space for luggage etc. Staff were very helpful and you always felt like very welcome. THe concierge was very helpful, help use out with many suggestions. The building is part of several other building and a shopping complex so there are several restaurants to choose from, but it you want to experience some real Tokyo, cross the street and you will find many local restaurants and cafes to choose from.

Not to be confused with the Royal Park Hotel Shiodome in the tower close by. I stayed at the Shiodome for business before and got it confused with the Park Hotel.The price was decent for a room in the center of Tokyo near Ginza, Fish Market, etc. The room was a bit small by Western standards but average to slightly above average for a metropolitan area in Japan. Let's say I've stayed in much smaller.Clean, relatively up to date, and free wi-fi. Staff were super helpful when we needed find our way around.I would definitely stay here again.

Having stayed at this hotel a few years ago when travelling with my wife, we returned this year when holidaying with our 3 children and we stayed in two adjacent rooms - a king and a triple. Very comfortable hotel with attentive staff and a convenient location for many sights in central Tokyo such as the palace, Ginza shops, the fish market, Tokyo Tower or hopping over to Odiaba on the Yurikomome. There is a metro station in the basement and a JR station 5 minutes walk away at Shimbashi so it's very easy to travel anywhere in the city that you'd like to go. The Limousine bus also stops here. Many reasonably priced restaurants in the several shopping complexes that are in the downstairs Shiodome area. Good for anyone that wants a top quality hotel close to the sights but a little removed from the crowds of places like Shinjuku. The morning show of one of the TV studios films downstairs every day and the children loved seeing the cute mascots interacting with the crew and sightseers.

Obviously, there are a lot of options in Tokyo. I have struggled with the choice of staying at the ubiquitous 'mainline' hotels (Hilton, Starwood, etc) with their 'predictable' but western-friendly environment, vs. staying 'local' at a more traditional Japanese hotel (where I sometimes miss the usual 'amenities' like the 'Western breakfast'. There is only so much Miso soup I can handle at 7AM) and the occasional communication challenges with the front desk. The Park Hotel seems to have positioned itself very nicely with the best of both. For example, the staff is extraordinarily pleasant yet not confused when you 'wave off' the bell desk staff at check-in , indicating that you are fine with taking your luggage with you, on your own, to the room. The rooms are 'large' for Tokyo standards, the bathroom amenities are plentiful and of high quality, and there are actually face cloths (which is often not the case in Japan). Beds are really comfortable with a selection of pillows. Coffee and tea in the room. No mini-bar, but excellent restaurant choices (French and Japanese) on the lobby level. One of the restaurants has a fantastic selection of Scotch Whiskeys. Speaking of - the lobby is on the 25th floor with spectacular views of Tokyo Tower and (on the clear days) all the way to Mt Fuji.Location is fantastic, with easy walking underground to Shimbashi Station. There are certainly more expensive options in Tokyo, but for the price - this hotel can't be beat. Great value for the money.
user_name:
Ronn2pints
New York City, New York

review_body: We spent 3 nights in Tokyo which was our stopover from US to HK. Since we didn't look into lodging earlier, we missed many of the promotion deals for many hotels. The rate for this hotel was not inexpensive but we felt we got what we paid for.We're somewhat familiar with the small room size in major cities and not many hotels have rooms for a family of 4 (including two kids aged 11 & 13). This hotel has a room that allows 3 adults and 1 kid (11 and under). The room was quite spacious and well appointed including the bathroom for a big city. With our luggage and family size, we didn't feel cramped and we're able to comfortably move around. With the jet lag, we spent many hours being awake in the room too.Location - it is attached to a few plazas like office buildings and one - with also restaurants, convenient store, coffee shops and retail stores. Close and safe enough for our kids to go there to grab a snack or drink. The best part is that it's very close to the Fish Market - Tsukiji. It opens early enough for our jetlagged state to go check it out. We did miss the 4 am 'fish auction'. However, the market was bustling at about 4 or 5 am. Little stalls and stands were open including food and souvenirs when we walked there at 5. A few of the well known sushi restaurants (they're tiny - almost like diners) have lines already starting before the day breaks. Some lines take a few hours. We went to one of the diners at the last day 5 am ... we didn't go to the 'famous' ones as we didn't want to stand in lines but it was still amazing! The one we went to were like many with a counter seating about a dozen. After you placed the order, you watched the chef preparing your bowls. Beside Tsukiji, it's also about 20 min walk to Ginza. It is also at a subway stop. We used public transportation only while we were there. The system was not as easily navigated as other systems so if it is new, take the time to figure it out. Atmosphere - the hotel started on 25th floor. It sounded strange but once you arrived there, it seemed quite 'normal'. The lobby was quite trendy and modern and open. They had a buffet there that looked delicious. However, we decided to try out all the local foods instead. Staff - very courteous, polite and friendly. At the last day of check out, we left our luggage behind as our flight was in the evening. When we went to pick up our luggage, the staff told us we left a few belongings behind (and they were quite important). Thanks to the honesty of the staff, nothing was missing. Travel to/from airport - there is a shuttle that conveniently takes you from the airport to the hotel at a very reasonable cost. It is very comfortable, clean, air conditioned, not like some of the airport shuttles in US. Much cheaper than a cab. The hotel will book the shuttle for you as requested on the way out. We at first wanted to stay in Shinjuku. We're happy to stay here instead as it was a bit more quiet. If you look for a night life, this may not be the best location. For us, it has worked out quite well.

It's unusual for reception to be on the 25th floor of a hotel, but what a view you have from there. We stayed for 3 nights and thoroughly enjoyed our stay. All staff including reception, concierge and bellboys were efficient, friendly, polite and extremely helpful. Our room on the 29th floor had outstanding views of the city skyline and the Tokyo Tower. Our room was very comfortable. The hotel is very close to the metro and there are plenty of restaurants close by. Would stay again at this hotel

We stayed at the park hotel toyko for the first leg of our honeymoon. The hotel is perfect for a business trip- its near The subway and offices- but i wouldnt recommend the hotel for a pleasure/leisure trip. The hotel has a decidedly corporate feel to it. We found it to be out of the way of many of the things we wanted to see while in tokyo, although the location near the subway made up for that- we were able to walk to ginza and the fish market.The staff at the check in are very kind and helpful. They speak perfect english, and are always ready to assist. They lent us umbrellas during a rainy couple of days, and provided us with a little bottle of champagne to commemorate our honeymoon. The bell hop showed us how to use the appliances in the room, and was very helpful with our baggage.The restaurant that we visited in the hotel (the japanese one) is overpriced and underwhelming. I would recommend walking up the street to any of the sushi restaurants for a better experience. Our room was very small, and the air conditioning seemed to be struggling a little bit. The bed was fairly uncomfortable, but it was big. We had an amazing view that overlooked the tokyo tower. If the weather had been better, i think we might have been been able to see mt. Fuji.

We spent one week holidays with my wife and daughter at the Park Hotel Tokyo. Rooms are not big, but we guess that this is Tokyo. Everything is clean and in order. Excellent location, warm and friendly personnel giving advises and recommendations. Excellent service overall with short walking distance from one of the parks and nice views from the room.. We really enjoyed our stay in Park Hotel and Tokyo. We can recommend Park Hotel Tokyo.

We had a great 5 night stay at the Park Hotel Tokyo. The rooms are small - but to be expected of Tokyo. Everything was clean, modern, well maintained and the staff was incredibly friendly and helpful in booking dinner reservations, making recommendations, etc. The location is unbeatable. Walking distance (10 minutes) to Tsukiji Market, half a block to the Shidome train station and walking distance to several malls and food courts giving you lots of food options. I would definitely recommend this hotel and stay again!

Spent New Years 2014 in the Park Hotel. Nice place with very helpful staff and a great view of Tokyo. Unfortunately we moved across the Rainbow Bridge for the remainder of our stay at a overly priced Grand Pacific. Hotel located near city transportation and nice restaurants. Would highly recommend this place for a nice stay in a relatively expensive city.

This hotel is so convenient - subway just downstairs and the monorail to Tokyo Bay just next door. The view to the Tokyo Tower from the Lobby is amazing too. For a small fee, they can even organize a shuttle bus from the hotel to the Airport. Had some issues with the key card but overall the service is exceptional.

Our arrival at Park Hotel was disappointing. After a late night taxi ride from the airport, we arrived to find an office tower in near darkness. The entry to the hotel was obscure and there was no-one there. The hotel is located on the top floors of a soul-less office building.We had a standard room, so it was not expensive. However, it was also very small.The staff were very courteous but I felt rather like a fish out of water. The business guests were smartly dressed and their needs were clearly quite different from the tourists, who were all dressed like me.The atmosphere is very grim and formal, as befits business guests whereas tourists need something less formal and more laid back. I have nothing to compare to because this is the only Tokyo hotel we stayed at. It did the job but I was not holding back tears of nostalgia as we left.

Stayed here with a group of 4 in April... Booked the Tokyo Tower view rooms..excellent views with Mt Fuji in the background just behind the Tokyo Tower.Wonderful friendly staff and so close to everything...would stay again

This is my second review of this hotel (my earlier some two years ago). Again, not disappointed in any respect. Every small request was attended to immediately. The hotel itself is just immaculate, if not a little on the quirky side, whilst retaining peaceful common areas, decorated with art and photos.Staff just wonderful and non-intrusive. This hotel has all the amenities of the large, soul-less chains, but far more intimate.Convenient to both Shiodome and Shimbashi stations, plenty of eateries around to cater for all tastes, an all night super market downstairs, and not far from Ginza if one seeks more liveliness (Shinjuku not that far away on direct Oedo line from Shiodome if one wishes even more fun). The Narita airport to hotel bus service (if timed correctly) works well and is inexpensive, and even if that doesn't work so well, just change at Tcat station in Tokyo for cheap cab ride to and/or from hotel.This writer would not stay anywhere else in Tokyo (I am in the hotel business so see my fair share of hotels).

We stayed in this hotel over two parts of our trip. The first part we got a nice room but we had asked for non-smoking and told the room we had was a non-smoking room when it smelt strongly of cigarettes. The second part we payed extra for a view of the tokyo tower, highly recommended, spectacular view. This time no smell of cigarettes and again very nice, modern room. High standard of cleanliness , great amenities . Great location across from shinbashi station which links onto the major yamonte line. We have stayed at the park hotel several times and highly recommend it. Especially to first time travelers

This hotel has some fabulous features--larger than normal rooms for Japan, great service, clean, a washing machine (cost) on floor 26, a small exercise room, and a great view of the Tokyo Tower. As other reviewers have mentioned, it can be difficult to find but the desk provides a map of the connection from the subway to the hotel. Use the map.
